title: Could not locate IMember for the constructor of a type member
desc: Using M6, I got an error trying to locate the constructor of a member type. The added constructor is in the type org.eclipse.jface.action.ExternalActionManager.CommandCallback.  This means we are not checking the @since tag properly.

title: IllegalArgumentException when @since tags has the wrong format
desc: Using HEAD, we report this in the .log file when the @since tag format is wrong. We should treat it as an invalid tag that needs to be fixed.  java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: invalid format 	at org.osgi.framework.Version.<init>(Version.java:150) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.util.SinceTagVersion.<init>(SinceTagVersion.java:38) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.processSinceTags(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:1341) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.compareProfiles(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:849) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildDeltas(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:526) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:215) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: Hookup context help for API tooling
desc: Ensure we have context help hooked up for actions/wizards/dialogs, etc..

title: Not possible to have two API problems with the same ids on the same resource
desc: With the way the equals() method is defined in org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.problems.ApiProblem, it is not possible to have more than one problem of the same kind in the same resource.  If you set up API tools for the ui.workbench project, inside the class org.eclipse.ui.presentations.AbstractPresentationFactory, there are four new fields that are not tagged with @since tags, but we report the error only on one of them.  This is a serious limitation.  I think the fix is to use the charStart, charEnd, extra arguments into account in the equals method. This might required to also adjust the hashCode implementation.

desc: I restarted Eclipse after a crash and found the exception below multiple times in the error log. This is on Eclipse 3.4M6.  -- Error Log -- Date: Sat Apr 05 13:52:38 GMT-08:00 2008 Message: java.lang.NullPointerException encountered while running API Analysis Builder. Severity: Warning Plugin ID: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools Stack Trace: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.collectAffectedSourceFiles(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:581) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildDeltas(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:494) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:215) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: remove export from API component API
desc: API tooling does not currently use or plan to use the 'export(...)' API. This code and tests should be removed.

title: API tools use too much memory
desc: I20080401-0851  After working for a day, I ran out of memory with -Xmx350M, SDK from CVS (except help, update, p2). A memory snapshot showed that the 63 instances of ProjectApiDescription used around 53MB.  Please profile and reduce the heap usage.

title: 'API Problem Filters' properties page: Remove ellipsis from Remove...
desc: I20080408-0800  'API Problem Filters' properties page: Remove the ellipsis from the "Remove... " (since it does not ask the user).

title: [api tooling] Missing @since tags are not flagged for newly added types
desc: While missing @since tags are nicely flagged for newly added methods, fields and constants, I find that newly added interfaces or classes are not properly flagged.  For instance, take org.eclipse.rse.core plugin from 3.0M6 (CVS tag v20080411) and compare against API Baseline from RSE 2.0.3 -- following interfaces are not flagged as missing @since tag:     IRSEInitListener    IRSEModelInitializer  and probably more.  To reproduce, there are two simple possibilities: (a) Import the RSE Team Project Set from     http://www.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/development/rse-anonymous.psf     Select the org.eclipse.rse.core plug-in and Team > Switch to Another     Branch or Version : v20080411  b) Download and install RSE-runtime-core-3.0M6.zip from     http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/dsdp/tm/downloads/drops/S-3.0M6-200804112145/RSE-runtime-core-3.0M6.zip     or from Ganymede Update Site ("Remote Access and Device Development")     or from the TM 3.0 milestone update site at      http://download.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/updates/3.0      Then File > Import > Plug-In Development > Plug-ins and Features >      from the Target Platform > Plugin with source code > org.eclipse.rse.core  For the API Baseline, download RSE-runtime-core-2.0.3.zip from http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/dsdp/tm/downloads/drops/R-2.0.3-200802251530/RSE-runtime-core-2.0.3.zip

title: Addition or removal of filter should trigger an incremental build of the applicable type
desc: When adding or removing a filter to a type, the applicable type should be rebuilt since secondary errors might be affected by this (like removing or adding bundle version errors).

title: Make exact specification of @no* tags available in the SDK
desc: I20080415-1646  I still think the @no* tags should stand for themselves and the boilerplate description (usually redundant, but who knows?) is counterproductive.  Nevertheless, the API tools do implement a certain specification by producing the 'API Use' problems. That specification should be made readily available in the SDK. It should appear - on hover - in content assist as additional info - in help, especially for the 'API Errors/Warnings' preference/properties page  The specification should say more than the boilerplate, e.g. whether @nooverride is redundant for a method that is already tagged with @noreference (maybe not, if you want to support the case of a method that can be extended by client subclasses but should not be called from client code).

title: Extending non-API class is not always an API problem
desc: I got set of these problems for org.eclipse.core.resources  Extends non-API type org.eclipse.core.internal.events.InternalBuilder	IncrementalProjectBuilder.java	org.eclipse.core.resources/src/org/eclipse/core/resources	 line 31	 API Usage Problem  John added to add some comments.

title: Remove inheritDoc support
desc: I20080415-1646  When you compare org.eclipse.jdt.junit from HEAD with a 3.3.2 baseline, you get this error:  Missing @since tag	JUnitLaunchShortcut.java	org.eclipse.jdt.junit/src/org/eclipse/jdt/junit/launcher	line 422	@since tag problem  This method is an implementation of a method from the new super interface ILaunchShortcut2. ILaunchShortcut2 has the @since 3.4 tag.

Cleaning removes the error message.  -- Error Log -- Date: Thu Apr 17 18:15:16 PDT 2008 Message: Error logged from API Tools Core:  Severity: Error Plugin ID: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools Stack Trace: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.comparator.ApiComparator.compare(ApiComparator.java:99) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.compareProfiles(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:829) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildDeltas(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:497) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:320) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:137) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:235) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: filter for "Method with non-API parameter" breaks after rebuild
desc: I have added filters for a class in Mylyn that is leaking internals in method signatures:  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?> <component id="org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.ui" version="1">     <resource path="src/org/eclipse/mylyn/tasks/ui/editors/AbstractRepositoryTaskEditor.java">         <filter id="643846161" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.IRepositoryTaskAttributeListener"/>         <filter id="643846161" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.RepositoryTaskOutlineNode"/>         <filter id="643842064" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.RepositoryTaskOutlineNode"/>         <filter id="643842064" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.RepositoryTaskOutlinePage"/>         <filter id="643846161" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.IRepositoryTaskAttributeListener"/>     </resource> </component>  After a while the warning markers will reappear and I am seeing the markers all the time in other workspaces although the .api_filters file is shared in CVS.

desc: while I was debugging some new code for API tools I got the following NPE in my target workspace.  java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BuildState.write(BuildState.java:93) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.saveBuiltState(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:1678) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:344) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)  The error occurred while I was debugging our builder (specifically the usage analyzer), and I am not sure if I used HCR or not at the time...sorry no other steps to reproduce.

title: API Tools test failures in I20110729-1200
desc: http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/I20110729-1200/  There are 48 failures.  Several are failures because a 1.7 JRE is not available.  We do not want to fail in this case.  It seems likely the Java 7 support is the cause of all the failures, though the tests passed locally.

title: final keyword addition for a method should not be flagged as a breakage if the enclosing type is tagged with @noextend
desc: When a type is tagged as @noextend, we should allow the final keyword to be added for visible methods (public or protected).  The case arose inside org.eclipse.ui.actions.RefreshAction. In this case, it is worse since that type was not supposed to be subclassed and can now be subclassed in 3.4. I don't see how we can capture this use case inside the tooling since the 3.3 baseline is not "built" with API tooling information (.api_description file).

title: Error message is confusing for removed types
desc: If a type is removed from API, we report the error (as expected). However, if the 'type removal' is due to the x-internal directive being used, it would be better to have an error message that the type has been removed from API (or something similar) and not just the generic "The type Foo has been removed".

title: [api tooling] extending @noextend method not detected
desc: We do not create errors for extending a @noextend method. The reason for this is that we do not create IReference objects for extending methods (we do not have a reference type for this).  I'm not sure what the most efficient way is to implement this feature. It feels like keeping all @extend references for methods would be slow/inefficient.

title: [api tooling] plug-in version number validation
desc: Based on comparison with an API baseline, we should validate that a plug-in's version number has been updated correctly (and create errors markers when there is a problem with plug-in version numbers).  I think it only makes sense to perform the validation if two API profiles represent successive versions (i.e. comparing what will be released in 3.4, compared to 3.3). For example comparing 3.4 to 3.2 could provide misleading results if new API was added in 3.3 and 3.4 - as this would require to major version updates (and we would only be able to infer one?).

title: Undo 'Add missing @since tag' quick fix is not atomic
desc: I20080422-0800  Given a type with missing @since tag error/warning (org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.correction.proposals.AssignToVariableAssistProposal) 1. Ctrl-1 on error (or problem hover) 2. Add missing @since tag 3. Undo Is:  it is required to make 2 undos to remove the added tag Should:  only one undo  It looks like the insertion is done in two steps: 1: /**  * blablabla@since 3.4  * */ 2: /**  * blcblabla  * @since 3.4  * */ Maybe insert and then format?  Is this contributed? PDE?

title: Occasional "Missing @since tag" error on internal class
desc: I20080415-1646  Occasional "Missing @since tag" error on internal class, e.g.:  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type Missing @since tag	JUnitClasspathFixProcessor.java	org.eclipse.jdt.junit/src/org/eclipse/jdt/internal/junit/ui	line 34	@since tag problem  When I clean the affected project, the error goes away. I cannot give steps to reproduce, but after more builds, it reappears.

title: [api tooling] tag scanner silently fails without class files
desc: When we are scanning source files for javadoc tags we try to resolve methods using their associated .class files.   Scanning will fail silently if there are no class files for the source we are scanning. This case can happen if you turn off autobuild and add source tags to a method. The scanner silently fails with an NPE that is never exposed...  There are a few things we could do here:  1. we could queue up the unresolvable methods in the api tool builder and the next time a build is activated we could try again to resolve them.  2. we could try to resolve using the java model if no class file are available

title: 'restrictions have changed' errors abound
desc: using: I20080408-0800  I started to see a pile of the following error showing up for the debug plugins: Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type The restrictions have been changed	ArchiveSourceContainer.java	org.eclipse.debug.core/core/org/eclipse/debug/core/sourcelookup/containers	line 27	Compatibility Problem  It is confusing exactly what 'restrictions' are being referred in the error, since no source has changed on the example class, only that an @noextend tag has been added.  The problem description should probably be a bit more descriptive, and maybe we should supress these errors until baseline(s) have restrictions in them.

title: URL[] urls = PluginPathFinder.getPluginPaths(location); doesn't return the list of bundles at location anymore
desc: This call doesn't return the list of bundles located inside the given location anymore. So the api profile wizard is broken as it doesn't initialize the profile with the appropriate api components. The end result is that the created baseline is wrong.

title: [api tooling] @noreference not working on inherited interface method
desc: If interfaceA implements foo(), and interfaceB extends interfaceA, a call to foo() on an implementor of interfaceB is not found as an error (if foo() has a @noreference flag).

title: [api tooling] API tooling set up should present as refactoring
desc: It was suggested that API tooling adopters would appreciate the initial API tooling setup to work like a refactoring - i.e. preview the edits of component.xml application to source code before pressing Finish.

title: Timing issue on removing filters
desc: When removing filters, an auto build is triggered before the dialog pops up asking to rebuild the corresponding component when the user clicks on "Apply". This auto-build is a waste of time and should be canceled if possible.

title: API breakage reported against private class
desc: I20080427-2000.  When checking org.eclipse.jdt.ui against R3.3.1.1 I get the following breakage reported:  Compatibility Problem org.eclipse.jdt.ui/ui/org/eclipse/jdt/ui/actions/AddDelegateMethodsAction.java	 The method getCompilationUnit() has been removed	 line 156	  Note that the method  		public CompilationUnit getCompilationUnit() { 			return fUnit; 		} was part of inner private static class AddDelegateMethodsContentProvider.

title: [api tooling] Refactoring participants required for filters
desc: In our code we have many places that record/cache/persist qualified names/sigatures/etc. for reuse.  If a refactoring is done on one of these referenced types then the cached information about the (previous) type is stale and never gets removed.  We need to add in refactoring participants for:  1. api descriptions, for package/type/member rename/signature changes 2. api filters, for package/type/member rename/signature changes

title: API Usage Problem "Execution environment references were not checked"
desc: I've just moved my workspace from 3.7 to 4.2M2. Plugins in the workspace that have API tooling enabled now show an error marker and the message:  Execution environment references were not checked for 'plugin' because no environment descriptions are installed.  It is not clear what this message means or how to correct it. I have not been able to locate it in any documentation.

title: Incremental build performance improvement
desc: Currently when we start an incremental build we visit the collection of IResourceDeltas to know if the manifest has changed or not (to know if we should do a full build). If a full build is not needed at this point we then go over all of the IResourceDeltas again to flatten the list (for finding source files with changes). After that step we then go over the flattened list to actually collect the changed files from the deltas. So in this simp-le example we are in effect going over the same collect 3 times.  Suggested Improvements:  To determine if the manifest has been changed we use an IResourceDeltaVisitor; we could look for changed source files at the same time while visiting the deltas. This way we can get rid of the flattening of deltas altogether, and we only ever examine the project(s) deltas once.

title: ICompilationUnit.findPrimaryType called for no reason
desc: during an incremental build, when we try to find the qualified names for all types in a given compilation unit we have the code:  IType type = unit.findPrimaryType(); if(type == null) {    continue; }  which does nothing other cause 1-2 seconds of additional work for the builder (by leading to IJavaElement.exists() calls). The variable type is not used after the null check.

title: Usage problem messages should be more descriptive
desc: Since we have a done a very good job at making pretty all of our other problem messages more descriptive, we should do the same for the API usage problems.  For example:  We have 'Implements non-API interface {0}', where 0 is the name of the non-API interface. We should augment this message to include the name of the type that is implementing the offending interface: '{1} implements non-API interface {0}'

title: [api tooling] Workspace profile needs to update after resource changes
desc: currently if you remove a resource from the workspace, the workspace api profile is not updated. For example I removed the jdt.debug project from my workspace and was barraged by errors like the following:  org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: Resource '/org.eclipse.jdt.debug' does not exist. 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkExists(Resource.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkAccessible(Resource.java:192) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Project.checkAccessible(Project.java:113) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.assertCreateRequirements(Folder.java:32) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:88) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:118) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.PluginProjectApiComponent.getProjectSettingsPath(PluginProjectApiComponent.java:234) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.PluginProjectApiComponent.persistApiFilters(PluginProjectApiComponent.java:369) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.PluginProjectApiComponent.saving(PluginProjectApiComponent.java:336) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ApiPlugin.saving(ApiPlugin.java:815) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.executeLifecycle(SaveManager.java:343) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager$1.run(SaveManager.java:160) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.broadcastLifecycle(SaveManager.java:163) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.save(SaveManager.java:989) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.DelayedSnapshotJob.run(DelayedSnapshotJob.java:44) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

desc: With these updated settings it should be easy to catch the current problems

title: markers not cleaned up after replace
desc: If you convert a project to be 'api aware' and then replae it with a 'non-api aware' version from SCM, any markers created by the api builder are not removed after the replace finishes. This is technically working as it should, since the api builder only runs on project with the api tool nature, but it feels wrong that we are leaving behind 'garbage' in a case like this.  We should look at ways to remove any api tool markers from projects like this (without being too invasive or expensive).

title: test suite required for incremental builder
desc: with incremental building added to api tooling we need to have a fairly extensive test suite for it. A good place to start would be to examine how jdt tests their builders.

title: dynamic plug-in project API description and API component
desc: As plug-ins are modified in the workspace, the associated API descriptions, components, and workspace profile need to be kept up-to-date.  Implemented a new API description for plug-in projects that dynamically retrieve API description information from the workspace, using modification timestamps to know when the data is stale.  Modified the API profile manager to dispose the workspace API profile when a manifest, build.properties, or classpath changes. This way our OSGi state stays up to date. A new workspacep profile is created on demand.

title: adding plug-in from CVS broke workspace profile
desc: I had these plug-ins in my workspace, API tooling enabled:  * org.eclipse.debug.ui * org.eclipse.jdt.debug  I added "org.eclipse.debug.core" to the workspace from CVS (which was not API tooling enabled). This seemed to break the workspace profile (i.e. it had resolution errors that caused extra API build problems to appear).

title: persist project API descriptions
desc: We should persist project API descriptions so they can be re-used across workbench invocations. (Since the format of the descriptions for projects changed, we no longer do this). We should ensure the save participant is smart enough to know to only save the description if it is dirty.

title: illegal implementor error disappears after clean/build
desc: Steps:  * Auto-build is ON * Check out these projects and setup API tooling:    org.eclipse.core.variables    org.eclipse.debug.core    org.eclipse.debug.ui    org.eclipse.jdt.debug    org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui    org.eclipse.jdt.launching * Notice there are 3 errors in jdt.debug.ui:  (1) Illegally implements org.eclipse.debug.ui.ILaunchConfigurationDialog (2) llegally implements org.eclipse.jdt.launching.IRuntimeClasspathEntry (3) Invalid @since tag: 3.4; the @since tag value cannot be greater than the component version 3.3.0.qualifier  * Clean org.eclipse.deubg.core, wait for build to complete. Now there are only two errors in jdt.debug.ui:  (1) Illegally implements org.eclipse.jdt.launching.IRuntimeClasspathEntry (2) Invalid @since tag: 3.4; the @since tag value cannot be greater than the component version 3.3.0.qualifier  NOTE: Cleaning jdt.debug.ui makes the missing problem re-appear.

title: more efficient scoped class file container
desc: For incremental builds we use a search scope consisting entirely of types within one component. The general implemenation visits all class files in the entire component, using the scope as a filter.   Since we know the exact set of types to visit it is more efficient just to visit those types. Created new TypeScope and use it in the builder. Added a test to SearchScopeTests for the new scope.

title: only write filter file if the project has API nature
desc: I replaced a project in my workspace (effectively removing its API nature). However, the .api_filters file was still written to the .settings folder on the next workspace save. The project is still part of the workspace profile, but we should not save filters unless the project actually has the API nature.

title: IReference should keep unresolved and resolved target locations
desc: Currently, we slam IReference's that get resolved - the target location is slammed with the resolved target location. It is useful to have both unresolved and resolved locations in some cases (for example, when re-resolving references in a different profile to see determine if a different version of a required bundle satifies all references).  Modified IReference to have 'referenced location' and 'resolved location'. Modified those that use IReference to reflect the change.

title: .api_filters not updated when it becomes empty
desc: I created a filter for an API problem (illegal implements). I re-built the project to ensure that the problem was filtered. This worked as expected.  Then I  * removed the filter * shutdown the workspace * restarted the workspace  > When I re-built the workspace I noticed the problem was still missing - and found that the .api_filters file still contained XML to filter the problem, and that the filter re-appeared in my project properties.

title: creating a no-op change causes API builder to run for 20 seconds
desc: Using  I20080226-1155  I have these projects in my workspace as source:  org.eclipse.jdt.doc.isv org.eclipse.jdt.doc.user org.eclipse.jdt-feature org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.doc org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv org.eclipse.platform.doc.user org.eclipse.releng org.eclipse.test.performance.win32 org.apache.ant org.eclipse.ant.core org.eclipse.ant.tests.core org.eclipse.ant.tests.ui org.eclipse.ant.ui org.eclipse.core.variables org.eclipse.debug.core org.eclipse.debug.examples.core org.eclipse.debug.examples.ui org.eclipse.debug.ui org.eclipse.jdt.debug org.eclipse.jdt.debug.jdi.tests org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui org.eclipse.jdt.launching org.eclipse.jdt.launching.j9 org.eclipse.jdt.ui.examples.javafamily org.eclipse.pde.api.tools org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.tests org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui org.eclipse.pde.core org.eclipse.pde.ui org.eclipse.test.performance org.eclipse.ui.console org.eclipse.ui.externaltools org.eclipse.ui.views.log org.objectweb.asm  Removing/adding a semi-colon in ApiUseAnalyzer causes the API builder to run for about 20 seconds.

title: [api tooling] Improve changes in EE
desc: The API analysis builder should improve the detection of changes inside Execution Environments of a project. Right now the tool reports a breakage as soon as a previous EE has been removed from the list. It doesn't check the compatibility of EEs.

title: Wording and casing in wizards
desc: I20080305-1100  - Open context menu on a PDE project   Sub menu PDE Tools:   'Api Tooling Setup...' should be 'API Tooling Setup...'  Open the wizard - First page Window title is 'API Tooling Setup...' no dots required here. Change to: 'API Tooling Setup'  'Configure projects for...' would better be the wizard description, and 'Select the Java projects to update would better be the label of the table' If not, 'Configure projects...' needs a dot at the end.  - Preview page Title is missing  Open preference page: - API Profiles > New API Profile 'Execution Environment:' should be 'Execution environment:' (Sentence capitalization) 'Browse' need dots: 'Browse...'  - API Errors/Warning:   columns (':') required on labels in 2nd and 3rd tab

title: Adding new profile blocks UI
desc: I20080305-1100  - Open preference page: API Profiles - Press 'New API Profile' button - Press 'Browse' - Select an existing Eclipse installation. Press OK.  While the install is investigated, the UI is blocked. Should be run in the modal context thread.

title: Improve labels on Usage Restriction tab
desc: I20080305-1100  - Open preference page: API Error/Warning On the first tab:  'Extending a restricted member'. Wouldn't that better say 'Extending a restricted type'? I assume only types can be extended.  'Referencing a restricted member'. Is that types, methods and fields? 'Member' is confusing here. Member of what? Is a type a member? Would it be better to call this 'Referencing an internal type'  Out of curiosity: How does this play together with the JDT access restrictions? Would it make sense to link to the JDT Error/Warning compiler page?  Maybe avoid 'restriction' and be explicit: Extending a type marked with '@noextend' Instantiating a class marked with '@noinstantiate' (what about enums?)

title: problem reporter should not clean problems
desc: Problems are cleaned by the builder (incrementally), so the problem reporter should not clean problem markers - it does not know which files to clean.  After an incremental build all markers disappear.

title: failing tests in Build N20080317-2000
desc: there are some problem factory / problem tests that are failing.

title: With fix for 357110, member types are processed more than once
desc: Bug 357110 was backported to 3.7.2 causing test failures (bug 364749).  We therefore need to backport this fix.  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #358414 +++  Inside the processing of tag validation, the enclosing compilation unit is retrieved for each type that is processed. Now member types are returned and this means they end up being processed more than once. This caused test failures in I20110920-1501.

title: [api tooling] "Illegally instantiates" should not be flagged when extending an @noinstantiate class
desc: Build Id: I20080502-0100 (3.4M7)  In following example, an API Usage Problem "Illegally instantiates org.eclipse.dstore.core.miners.Miner" is flagged on the class declaration of CommandMiner. Am I misunderstanding the meaning of @noinstantiate, or is this a bug?  My understanding is that clients are allowed to extend the Miner and have it registered by some means (extension point or similar), as long as they leave instanatiating the class to the Framework.   We have a separate @noextend tag for disallowing extension, so I cannot see why this is folded into @noinstantiate.  /** @noinstantiate Clients should not instantiate this class. The framework  *                 will take care of instantiating the Miners.  */ public abstract class Miner { }  public class CommandMiner extends Miner { }

title: map files still refer to CVS locations for pde.api tools features
desc: Please update them to point to Git repos  feature@org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.cdcfoundation10_feature=v20091027-1300,:pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:/cvsroot/eclipse,,pde/apitools/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.cdcfoundation10-feature feature@org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.j2se14_feature=v20091027-1300,:pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:/cvsroot/eclipse,,pde/apitools/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.j2se14-feature feature@org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.osgiminimum12_feature=v20091027-1300,:pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:/cvsroot/eclipse,,pde/apitools/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.osgiminimum12-feature

title: 'Set all to:...' preference action does not set all
desc: The 'Set all to:..' action does not set all of the preferences to the selected severity level.  Preferences not set:  1: Annotation -> the superinterfaces heirarchy has been reduced 2: Interface -> super interfaces have been reduced

title: Similar problems are being dropped from analyzer
desc: If we find N problems that match (have the same id and arguments, but have different line number, charstart, charend) in the base analyzer, we end up only returning 1 of them (the first one to be added to the backing collection.  Consider the following code example (where NoInstantiateClazz2 has been tagged @noinstantiate):  public abstract class Clazz2 extends TestPlugin2Clazz { 	Object o = new NoInstantiateClazz2(); 	/** 	 * Constructor 	 */ 	public Clazz2() { 		Object o = new NoInstantiateClazz2();  		Object o2 = new NoInstantiateClazz2(); 	} }  In this example only the first usage problem is returned, the other two are 'pruned', since the problem already exists in the base analyzer collection.

title: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools exports a package it does not have
desc: I was testing a new M4 eclipse-SDK build (I20111205-2330), and imported "all source bundles from runtime target" and noticed a red-X in org.eclipse.pde.api.tools manifest.mf file that said "this package does not exist in this bundle", for   org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.tasks  I'm guessing this does not hurt much ... but figure it is incorrectly stating its "contract" and should be fixed?

title: Filter quick-fix should use filter icon
desc: The quick-fix for creating an API filter should use the 'standard' filter icon.

title: Accurately catching constructor problems inside constructors
desc: With the fix in for 230209 we now properly flag (and ignore) implicit constructor calls. There is one problem: if you explicitly call the constructor of your super-class within your constructor, it does not get flagged properly.  Example: class A extends B, where B is tagged as noinstantiate and A explicitly calls 'new B()' in one of its constructors.

title: Producer oriented API Use Scan Migration task
desc: Build Identifier:   There is a new API Tooling feature in Eclipse 3.7 M4, which allows API use scans to be compared to a workspace. We would like to be able to do this in a headless build via an ANT task. The task would take as inputs scan report URLs(local or remote) and also an Eclipse site(baseline) against which to do the scanning. This will automate our process in terms of discovering when a build producing API could break it's API build consumers.  Reproducible: Always

title: 'Test project missing from workspace baseline' test failures
desc: Failed in the M20120111-0800 build, but I have seen it fail before.  the test project api component must exist in the workspace baseline junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: the test project api component must exist in the workspace baseline at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.tests.AbstractApiTest.createProject(AbstractApiTest.java:147) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.util.tests.ProjectCreationTests.setUp(ProjectCreationTests.java:60) at org.eclipse.test.EclipseTestRunner.run(EclipseTestRunner.java:501) at org.eclipse.test.EclipseTestRunner.run(EclipseTestRunner.java:259) at org.eclipse.test.CoreTestApplication.runTests(CoreTestApplication.java:36) at org.eclipse.test.CoreTestApplication.run(CoreTestApplication.java:32) at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppContainer.callMethodWithException(EclipseAppContainer.java:587) at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppHandle.run(EclipseAppHandle.java:198) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:110) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:79) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:344) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:179) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:622) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:577) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1410) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:1386) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:34)

title: Conversion of org.eclipse.update.core is causing weird results
desc: When convertion this bundle, the api restriction tags inside the type org.eclipse.update.configuration.IActivity are duplicated and you can find: @noextend null multiple times.  This should be fixed to help people to convert.

title: API Use Scan archives require directory entries starting with "xml"
desc: Build Identifier: eclipse-SDK-I20110222-0800-win32.zip  The "API Use Scans" preference page allows adding API use scans so they can be compared to the workspace to ensure that the API references still exist. The API use scans can be added as archives. However, whatever I tried I always got an error saying that my archive is invalid. I eventually looked into the code and found out that method "ApiUseScanPeferencePage.valditeArchive(File file)" requires the archive file(jar or zip) to have directory entries(which are not essential to the structure of a zip file). And it also requires a root directory which starts with "xml" which seemed odd to me. The last part appears to be related to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=338488. I think there are two problems here: 1. Requiring directory zip entries. 2. Requiring entries to start with "xml".  Reproducible: Always

title: avoid "finding" types when building API description nodes
desc: When creating nodes for types in "project" API descriptions, we are using IJavaProject.findType(...) to locate the associated IType. We already have the parent IType or IPackageFragment, so it should be faster just to create an appropriate java element handle.

title: Confusing error message in "New API Profile" dialog
desc: For "Location", I selected the folder containing the "eclipse" folder instead of the "eclipse" folder itself. The error message said something about "not bound to execution environment", which confused me. Could this be something like "Cannot detect a valid profile at the given location"?

title: Improve API description memory usage
desc: Currently the single largest use of memory in API tools are the API descriptions since descriptions are directly dependent on the API package / type count. We should look at ways to minimize the use of LRU / MRU caches for components / packages and we should examine our usage of HashMaps (avoid default sized aps if smaller will suffice and make intellgent guesses at default mapo siezs to minimize map resizing / rehashing).  Some classes to consider (which hold, or are part of, the largest amount of retained memory)  ApiDescriptionManager ApiProfile ProjectApiDescription BundleApiComponent ReferenceTypeDescriptorImpl FieldDescriptorImpl

title: API tooling wizard: "Use Reset..." error  in banner shouldn't be
desc: 3.4 RC1 0510-2000  1) Preferences -> PDE -> API Baselines  2) Fill in name 3) Pick a valid location  A progress bar will appear.  During that moment, an error note was visible in the banner saying something like, "Use Reset to scan the <something or other>"  Observations: A) It seemed to be telling me something that wasn't required since it was already scanning the directory B) It shouldn't have had the error icon beside it, it was at most info

title: API tooling wizard: adding baseline should select it
desc: 3.4 RC1 0510-2000  1) Preferences -> PDE -> API Baselines->Add Baselines 2) Fill in name, location, Finish 3) Back in the preference page, the newly added baseline appears but is unchecked.    Observation: It should probably be checked, since the reason I added it was likely so I'd use it.  That I assume is the most common workflow.

title: [api tooling] @since tag quickfix should use the version from the Manifest, and not what it thinks is right
desc: Build id: I20080327-2251  I'm comparing my HEAD version (org.eclipse.rse.core_3.0.0) against baseline 2.0.  I have reved up the version in MANIFEST.MF to 3.0 for good reason, but API Tooling thinks it should be at 2.1 because it cannot find any breaking change - although I know that there is breaking binary change.  Now API Tooling finds several "missing @since tag" problems, and using Quickfix inserts @since 2.1 - what API Tooling thinks is correct. But it's wrong, so the quickfix is useless for me.  The @since quickfix should insert the version that it finds in the Manifest, even if it thinks that the version is wrong. This gives the user the chance to configure behavior in the correct way (in case the tooling is right and the user is wrong, user can still change the Manifest to 2.1 first and then fix the @since problems).

title: [api tooling] The enclosing type should not be returned as a default member
desc: When trying to locate the @since tags for a new member, we should not return the enclosing type as a default member. Otherwise we can end up reported invalid @since tags errors on the enclosing type. See bug  224685.

title: Got "The super interfaces set has been reduced" but I didn't
After fixing breaking API changes, error about bundle version still there
desc: I have a project with breaking API changes, leading to errors being reported for the breaking change, the @since tags and the bundle version number. After fixing the breaking change (adding back a removed API field), I was expecting that the other errors went away, but I had to do Project>Clean... manually.

title: bundle version error disappears on incremental build
desc: I20080513-2000  I noticed today that the errors on the Ant plugins for incrementing the minor version with no API changes were disappearing and re-appearing. It seems that they sometimes get cleaned on an incremental build, and are not re-created.

title: Cannot add back a baseline with same name
desc: Steps to reproduce: 1) create a first baseline named "3.3.2" 2) Click finish 3) Reopen the baseline wizard and remove the 3.3.2 baseline 4) Try to create a new baseline without clicking finish with the same name. You get an error saying that a baseline with the same name already exists.

title: "Tag '@noinstantiate' is unsupported on a class" should say "abstract class"
desc: I20080513-2000  Tag '@noinstantiate' is unsupported on a class	RefactoringContribution.java	org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring/src/org/eclipse/ltk/core/refactoring	Unsupported Tag Problem	line 71  => Should be "... unsupported on an *abstract* class".

title: Wording in the API Tooling setup wizard
desc: 20080401  - The wizard page description needs a dot.  - When pressing 'Next' on the first page of the 'API Tooling setup' you can see progress message 'Scanning projects for javadoc changes' Should be 'Javadoc', maybe even 'Javadoc comment'.

title: Scanning 'project' message is not descriptive
desc: Now that our progress reporting has been fixed, I often see the message "Scanning 'project name'". I'm not sure exactly which phase of the API analysis this is, but it's not very descriptive for the user. We should likely update this to something more descriptive.

title: Fix mixed line delimiters
desc: The following change messed up the line delimiters for several files:  http://git.eclipse.org/c/pde/eclipse.pde.ui.git/diff/apitools/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.cdcfoundation11/build.properties?id=9eb2c6bee2afc8c16abdf52aacc798dcd3a617f0  How could this happen?

title: API builder seems slower in I20080515-2000
desc: Testing on Windows XP and Linux using I20080515-2000 it feels as though the API  builder is a bit slower. Talking with Olivier it could be that some additional time has been added with the fix for the @noreference support, where we now request the restrictions for each member.  It would be good to profile the builder again and compare...

title: Could not locate IMember for the constructor of a type member
desc: Using M6, I got an error trying to locate the constructor of a member type. The added constructor is in the type org.eclipse.jface.action.ExternalActionManager.CommandCallback.  This means we are not checking the @since tag properly.

title: IllegalArgumentException when @since tags has the wrong format
desc: Using HEAD, we report this in the .log file when the @since tag format is wrong. We should treat it as an invalid tag that needs to be fixed.  java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: invalid format 	at org.osgi.framework.Version.<init>(Version.java:150) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.util.SinceTagVersion.<init>(SinceTagVersion.java:38) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.processSinceTags(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:1341) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.compareProfiles(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:849) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildDeltas(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:526) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:215) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: Hookup context help for API tooling
desc: Ensure we have context help hooked up for actions/wizards/dialogs, etc..

title: Not possible to have two API problems with the same ids on the same resource
desc: With the way the equals() method is defined in org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.problems.ApiProblem, it is not possible to have more than one problem of the same kind in the same resource.  If you set up API tools for the ui.workbench project, inside the class org.eclipse.ui.presentations.AbstractPresentationFactory, there are four new fields that are not tagged with @since tags, but we report the error only on one of them.  This is a serious limitation.  I think the fix is to use the charStart, charEnd, extra arguments into account in the equals method. This might required to also adjust the hashCode implementation.

title: NPE in API Analysis Builder after crash
desc: I restarted Eclipse after a crash and found the exception below multiple times in the error log. This is on Eclipse 3.4M6.  -- Error Log -- Date: Sat Apr 05 13:52:38 GMT-08:00 2008 Message: java.lang.NullPointerException encountered while running API Analysis Builder. Severity: Warning Plugin ID: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools Stack Trace: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.collectAffectedSourceFiles(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:581) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildDeltas(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:494) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:215) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: The same API Problem is reported several in Problem View
desc: build I20080519-2000 1) open a new workspace 2) checkout org.eclipse.jdt.core from dev.eclipse.org 3) add an API Baseline 4) do a full build 5) open org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.BuildContext.java In the Problem View the type BuildContext.java has 6 problem: BuildContext extends non-API type CompilationParticipantResult BuildContext extends non-API type CompilationParticipantResult BuildContext extends non-API type CompilationParticipantResult Constructor for BuildContext with non-API parameter type SourceFile Constructor for BuildContext with non-API parameter type SourceFile Constructor for BuildContext with non-API parameter type SourceFile  In fact there is only 2 problems but each problem has three occurrences.  6) add a space in the editor of BuildContext.java 7) save and build There is only 2 problems: BuildContext extends non-API type CompilationParticipantResult Constructor for BuildContext with non-API parameter type SourceFile  8) do a full build There is the same 6 problems as before

title: Add Eclipse-BundleShape: dir to api tools tests
desc: Bug 379728 fixed most of the tests, but the API tools test plug-in was skipped.

title: remove export from API component API
desc: API tooling does not currently use or plan to use the 'export(...)' API. This code and tests should be removed.

title: Unused NLS strings should be cleaned up
desc: API tools has quite a few unused NLS'd strings, which need to be cleaned up.

title: API tools use too much memory
desc: I20080401-0851  After working for a day, I ran out of memory with -Xmx350M, SDK from CVS (except help, update, p2). A memory snapshot showed that the 63 instances of ProjectApiDescription used around 53MB.  Please profile and reduce the heap usage.

title: search engine returns emtpy search results
desc: Currently when our SearchEngine returns, the collection of returned items contains (on average) 90% empty values; which causes us to iterate over a lot of search results only to do no work. One of the last things we do in the search(..) method of our search engine is to copy search results over to a new collection; we could be a bit smarter here and only return search results that are not empty.   For example searching org.eclipse.jdt.core will return 273 search results, of which only 3 of them are not empty. So for the one plugin alone we can save 270 pieces of garbage to be collected, and 270 unneeded no-op iterations.

title: 'API Problem Filters' properties page: Remove ellipsis from Remove...
desc: I20080408-0800  'API Problem Filters' properties page: Remove the ellipsis from the "Remove... " (since it does not ask the user).

title: IOExceptions if baseline name is invalid file name
desc: 3.4 M7 Vista Home  If I name a baseline with characters that would not constitute a valid file name, I get IOExceptions performing operations that would cause an workspace save to happen.  Steps:   1 - create a new API baseline and name it "product foo v2.2.*" 2 - create a new project (any type), or close an existing project - you should get the exception below:   Started getting the following exception logged once in a while (makes sense, it is during workspace snapshot save):  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 120 2008-05-21 23:19:49.228 !MESSAGE Error logged from API Tools Core:  !STACK 0 java.io.IOException: The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect 	at java.io.WinNTFileSystem.createFileExclusively(Native Method) 	at java.io.File.createNewFile(Unknown Source) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiProfileManager.persistStateCache(ApiProfileManager.java:276) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiProfileManager.saving(ApiProfileManager.java:396) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.ApiPlugin.saving(ApiPlugin.java:459) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.executeLifecycle(SaveManager.java:343) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager$1.run(SaveManager.java:160) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.broadcastLifecycle(SaveManager.java:163) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.save(SaveManager.java:989) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.DelayedSnapshotJob.run(DelayedSnapshotJob.java:44) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: [api tooling] Missing @since tags are not flagged for newly added types
desc: While missing @since tags are nicely flagged for newly added methods, fields and constants, I find that newly added interfaces or classes are not properly flagged.  For instance, take org.eclipse.rse.core plugin from 3.0M6 (CVS tag v20080411) and compare against API Baseline from RSE 2.0.3 -- following interfaces are not flagged as missing @since tag:     IRSEInitListener    IRSEModelInitializer  and probably more.  To reproduce, there are two simple possibilities: (a) Import the RSE Team Project Set from     http://www.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/development/rse-anonymous.psf     Select the org.eclipse.rse.core plug-in and Team > Switch to Another     Branch or Version : v20080411  b) Download and install RSE-runtime-core-3.0M6.zip from     http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/dsdp/tm/downloads/drops/S-3.0M6-200804112145/RSE-runtime-core-3.0M6.zip     or from Ganymede Update Site ("Remote Access and Device Development")     or from the TM 3.0 milestone update site at      http://download.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/updates/3.0      Then File > Import > Plug-In Development > Plug-ins and Features >      from the Target Platform > Plugin with source code > org.eclipse.rse.core  For the API Baseline, download RSE-runtime-core-2.0.3.zip from http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/dsdp/tm/downloads/drops/R-2.0.3-200802251530/RSE-runtime-core-2.0.3.zip

title: Scan for unsupported tags creates duplicate problems
desc: We are scanning source files more than once for unsupported javadoc tags. Since we traverse the class file container and process assoicated source, we are scanning source once for each top level type, and then once for each inner type. This results in duplicate problems, and we are doing more work than needed.

title: Close baseline profile after build
desc: From bug 233441, we should probably close the baseline API profile after each build as well. It may not be as critical, but it means we have zip files open that will prevent others form deleting them (until the workspace is closed).

title: API builder performance bad for incremental build
desc: I20080520-2000  In a development workspace with JDT, Debug and PDE plug-ins from CVS, open DebugPlugin.java, type a space (that does not change the class file), and save the file. The Java builder takes less than 0.5 seconds, but the API Tools builder needs about 30 seconds to finish.  This makes it a pain to work with compilation units that have a lot of incoming dependencies, and there's no way for me to improve the situation (except for disabling auto build).

title: Addition or removal of filter should trigger an incremental build of the applicable type
desc: When adding or removing a filter to a type, the applicable type should be rebuilt since secondary errors might be affected by this (like removing or adding bundle version errors).

title: Make exact specification of @no* tags available in the SDK
desc: I20080415-1646  I still think the @no* tags should stand for themselves and the boilerplate description (usually redundant, but who knows?) is counterproductive.  Nevertheless, the API tools do implement a certain specification by producing the 'API Use' problems. That specification should be made readily available in the SDK. It should appear - on hover - in content assist as additional info - in help, especially for the 'API Errors/Warnings' preference/properties page  The specification should say more than the boilerplate, e.g. whether @nooverride is redundant for a method that is already tagged with @noreference (maybe not, if you want to support the case of a method that can be extended by client subclasses but should not be called from client code).

title: Extending non-API class is not always an API problem
desc: I got set of these problems for org.eclipse.core.resources  Extends non-API type org.eclipse.core.internal.events.InternalBuilder	IncrementalProjectBuilder.java	org.eclipse.core.resources/src/org/eclipse/core/resources	 line 31	 API Usage Problem  John added to add some comments.

title: Support the @noreference Javadoc tag on types
desc: SWT has a class GCData that is a public type in an API package. However, the class is documented as: * IMPORTANT: This class is not part of the public * API for SWT. It is marked public only so that it can be shared * within the packages provided by SWT. It is not available on all * platforms, and should never be called from application code. The class has a binary incomatibililty in it (vs 3.3 a removed field), however the problem should not be flagged. It can be filtered, but really, the type should have a @noreference or @private tag on it so clients would be warned about any reference to it, and all problems would be filtered automatically.

title: Remove inheritDoc support
desc: I20080415-1646  When you compare org.eclipse.jdt.junit from HEAD with a 3.3.2 baseline, you get this error:  Missing @since tag	JUnitLaunchShortcut.java	org.eclipse.jdt.junit/src/org/eclipse/jdt/junit/launcher	line 422	@since tag problem  This method is an implementation of a method from the new super interface ILaunchShortcut2. ILaunchShortcut2 has the @since 3.4 tag.

desc: I've been seeing these today.  Working from API Tools in HEAD.  I see "Missing @since tag" messages being reported for internal classes.  Cleaning removes the error message.  -- Error Log -- Date: Thu Apr 17 18:15:16 PDT 2008 Message: Error logged from API Tools Core:  Severity: Error Plugin ID: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools Stack Trace: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.comparator.ApiComparator.compare(ApiComparator.java:99) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.compareProfiles(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:829) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildDeltas(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:497) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:320) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:137) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:235) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

desc: I have added filters for a class in Mylyn that is leaking internals in method signatures:  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?> <component id="org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.ui" version="1">     <resource path="src/org/eclipse/mylyn/tasks/ui/editors/AbstractRepositoryTaskEditor.java">         <filter id="643846161" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.IRepositoryTaskAttributeListener"/>         <filter id="643846161" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.RepositoryTaskOutlineNode"/>         <filter id="643842064" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.RepositoryTaskOutlineNode"/>         <filter id="643842064" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.RepositoryTaskOutlinePage"/>         <filter id="643846161" messageargs="org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.tasks.ui.editors.IRepositoryTaskAttributeListener"/>     </resource> </component>  After a while the warning markers will reappear and I am seeing the markers all the time in other workspaces although the .api_filters file is shared in CVS.

desc: while I was debugging some new code for API tools I got the following NPE in my target workspace.  java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BuildState.write(BuildState.java:93) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.saveBuiltState(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:1678) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:344) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)  The error occurred while I was debugging our builder (specifically the usage analyzer), and I am not sure if I used HCR or not at the time...sorry no other steps to reproduce.

title: Re-order compatibility options
desc: I think we should re-order the top level groupings of compatibility options to the following (since classes/interfaces are generally more widely used than enums and annotations):  Bundle Class Interface Enum Annotation Field Method  Constructor

title: final keyword addition for a method should not be flagged as a breakage if the enclosing type is tagged with @noextend
desc: When a type is tagged as @noextend, we should allow the final keyword to be added for visible methods (public or protected).  The case arose inside org.eclipse.ui.actions.RefreshAction. In this case, it is worse since that type was not supposed to be subclassed and can now be subclassed in 3.4. I don't see how we can capture this use case inside the tooling since the 3.3 baseline is not "built" with API tooling information (.api_description file).

title: Tons of API tooling errors after importing binaries
desc: I20080805-0100.  1. started my workspace (which had no errors) using I20080805-0100.    ==> all good 2. imported all unshared binary plug-ins from I20080805-0100.    ==> tons of API tooling errors on interfaces: The super interfaces set has been reduced for type 'T' (T stands for the concrete type)     plus: errors on many manifest files:  The major version should be incremented in version 3.5.0.qualifier, since API breakage occurred since version 'v' (v differs from plug-in to plug-in)   Similar errors were already reported but are marked as fixed (see bug 224969 and bug 233426).

title: Error message is confusing for removed types
desc: If a type is removed from API, we report the error (as expected). However, if the 'type removal' is due to the x-internal directive being used, it would be better to have an error message that the type has been removed from API (or something similar) and not just the generic "The type Foo has been removed".

title: Undo 'Add missing @since tag' quick fix is not atomic
desc: I20080422-0800  Given a type with missing @since tag error/warning (org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.correction.proposals.AssignToVariableAssistProposal) 1. Ctrl-1 on error (or problem hover) 2. Add missing @since tag 3. Undo Is:  it is required to make 2 undos to remove the added tag Should:  only one undo  It looks like the insertion is done in two steps: 1: /**  * blablabla@since 3.4  * */ 2: /**  * blcblabla  * @since 3.4  * */ Maybe insert and then format?  Is this contributed? PDE?

title: temp ee files left around
desc: I was poking around my hard drive and found a mess of .ee files in the normal tempfile location (under the user dir).  these appear to be something related to debug and is creation or parsing of ee files.  Looks like hter eis a leak in the clean up code.  I had about 100 of them in there.  Not too big but still a leak

title: Occasional "Missing @since tag" error on internal class
desc: I20080415-1646  Occasional "Missing @since tag" error on internal class, e.g.:  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type Missing @since tag	JUnitClasspathFixProcessor.java	org.eclipse.jdt.junit/src/org/eclipse/jdt/internal/junit/ui	line 34	@since tag problem  When I clean the affected project, the error goes away. I cannot give steps to reproduce, but after more builds, it reappears.

title: Smoke test plan published on web site
desc: We should polish the existing API Tooling smoke test on the WIKI, and post a read-only copy on the PDE web site. Existing plan can be found here:  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Api_Tooling_Testing

title: Performance test suite
desc: API Tooling needs a performance test suite that covers these scenarios:  * full build * incremental build with few dependencies * incremental build with many dependencies * tag scanning (for API description building) * tag scanning (for unsupported tags) * searching

title: 'restrictions have changed' errors abound
desc: using: I20080408-0800  I started to see a pile of the following error showing up for the debug plugins: Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type The restrictions have been changed	ArchiveSourceContainer.java	org.eclipse.debug.core/core/org/eclipse/debug/core/sourcelookup/containers	line 27	Compatibility Problem  It is confusing exactly what 'restrictions' are being referred in the error, since no source has changed on the example class, only that an @noextend tag has been added.  The problem description should probably be a bit more descriptive, and maybe we should supress these errors until baseline(s) have restrictions in them.

title: URL[] urls = PluginPathFinder.getPluginPaths(location); doesn't return the list of bundles at location anymore
desc: This call doesn't return the list of bundles located inside the given location anymore. So the api profile wizard is broken as it doesn't initialize the profile with the appropriate api components. The end result is that the created baseline is wrong.

title: Creating a usage problem filter doesn't remove it from Problems view
desc: I20080903-1200  1. Check out org.eclipse.jdt.core v_911 2. Build 3. In Problems view, select  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type AST.convertCompilationUnit(int, CompilationUnitDeclaration, char[], Map, boolean, CompilationUnit, int, IProgressMonitor) has non-API parameter type CompilationUnit	AST.java	org.eclipse.jdt.core/dom/org/eclipse/jdt/core/dom	line 305	API Usage Problem 4. Quick fix 5. Create a usage problem filter... Observe: The problem is still reported in Problems view

title: Associate a comment to a problem filter
desc: I20080903-1200  When adding a problem filter, one must have a good reason. However this reason is not recorded and after a while we may forget why the problem filter was added.  It would be good if one could associate a comment to a problem filter (preferably at creation time, or using the "Properties>Plug-in Development>API Problem Filters" UI. Of course this comment would be stored in the ".settings/.api_filters" file.

title: Timing issue on removing filters
desc: When removing filters, an auto build is triggered before the dialog pops up asking to rebuild the corresponding component when the user clicks on "Apply". This auto-build is a waste of time and should be canceled if possible.

title: @extend violation not detected for local and anonymous subclasses
desc: N20080904-2000.  @extend violation is not detected for inner and anonymous subclasses.  test 1) I added this code to ide.ui: 	OpenWithMenu openWithMenu= new OpenWithMenu(PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getActiveWorkbenchWindow().getActivePage(), (IAdaptable)selectedElement) {           some code here }   test 2) I added this code to jdt.ui: 	void test() { 		class foo extends OpenWithMenu { 			foo() { 				super(null, null); 			} 		} 	}  OpenWithAction has this tag: @noextend This class is not intended to be subclassed by clients.  If I turn the class into a top-level class the problem is detected.

title: restricted constructors from public static inner types not flagged
desc: if you have a public static inner type with a public constructor which has a noref tag on it, and you call the constructor, it does not get flagged as a problem.  Tests to uncomment once this has been fixed:  ConstructorUsageTests#testConstructorUsageTests1F ConstructorUsageTests#testConstructorUsageTests1I

title: Remove implementation of primitive types
desc: We have implementations of primitive types in our element descriptor hierarchy. Only the tests use these interfaces/classes, and they can be removed.

title: collapse IType and IReferenceType descriptors
desc: Since we've done away with element descriptors for primitive and array types, the ITypeDescriptor and IReferenceTypeDescriptor interfaces can be combined. As well, we can get rid of the constants for primitive and array types.

title: consolidate element descriptors/structures used by delta compare & usage analysis
API breakage reported against private class
desc: I20080427-2000.  When checking org.eclipse.jdt.ui against R3.3.1.1 I get the following breakage reported:  Compatibility Problem org.eclipse.jdt.ui/ui/org/eclipse/jdt/ui/actions/AddDelegateMethodsAction.java	 The method getCompilationUnit() has been removed	 line 156	  Note that the method  		public CompilationUnit getCompilationUnit() { 			return fUnit; 		} was part of inner private static class AddDelegateMethodsContentProvider.

title: Incremental build performance improvement
desc: Currently when we start an incremental build we visit the collection of IResourceDeltas to know if the manifest has changed or not (to know if we should do a full build). If a full build is not needed at this point we then go over all of the IResourceDeltas again to flatten the list (for finding source files with changes). After that step we then go over the flattened list to actually collect the changed files from the deltas. So in this simp-le example we are in effect going over the same collect 3 times.  Suggested Improvements:  To determine if the manifest has been changed we use an IResourceDeltaVisitor; we could look for changed source files at the same time while visiting the deltas. This way we can get rid of the flattening of deltas altogether, and we only ever examine the project(s) deltas once.

title: 7 failing tests
desc: There are 7 tests that continuously fail. Also, there seem to be some open outdated bugs regarding API Tools tests.  In the arch call we decided that we want all tests green again.

title: Improve API tooling test turnaround
desc: Running the API tooling compaitibility tests is time consuming for developers and for the automated build. The slowness is in creating/deleting an entire workspace for each test. The tests grow slower as we add more and more test data (classses) for new tests...  We should look at ways to improve this.

title: Infrastructure support for source or binary analysis
desc: An m3 plan item for API tooling was to enhance our implementation to support either source or binary type structures. The idea is to design our analyzers such that the "type structure" abstraction could be derived from .java files or .class files without the analyzers needing to worry about it.

title: incremental build performance test
desc: We should have one or two incremental build tests for the performance suite to stress performance of analysis of dependent types (i.e. ripple/analysis caused by changing a type that has many dependent types).

title: fix enclosing type resolution for nested types
desc: The method ApiType#getEnclosingType() is incomplete for member/local/anonymous types.

title: ICompilationUnit.findPrimaryType called for no reason
desc: during an incremental build, when we try to find the qualified names for all types in a given compilation unit we have the code:  IType type = unit.findPrimaryType(); if(type == null) {    continue; }  which does nothing other cause 1-2 seconds of additional work for the builder (by leading to IJavaElement.exists() calls). The variable type is not used after the null check.

title: Usage problem messages should be more descriptive
desc: Since we have a done a very good job at making pretty all of our other problem messages more descriptive, we should do the same for the API usage problems.  For example:  We have 'Implements non-API interface {0}', where 0 is the name of the non-API interface. We should augment this message to include the name of the type that is implementing the offending interface: '{1} implements non-API interface {0}'

title: Test failures in recent builds
desc: testImportJavadocTestSource:  http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20130129-2000/testresults/html/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.tests_macosx.cocoa.x86_5.0.html   ApiToolingApiuseAntTaskTests.test1: http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20130129-0800/testresults/html/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.tests_linux.gtk.x86_6.0.html  At least the latter probably fails because of ordering issues (order is not guaranteed when using Java 7). Use org.eclipse.test.OrderedTestSuite#OrderedTestSuite(Class).
