title: yellow performance tests need tuning
desc: Many of the incremental build performance tests are yellow (standard deviation is too high to be considered consistent). For example:  http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/I20090106-0800/performance/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.php?fp_type=0

title: Unused api filters should not be reported when corresponding checks have not been run
desc: If you check in jdt.core and you don't set up an api baseline, after the build is done, some api filters are reported as unused, but they are actually used if a reference api baseline is set for a compatibility check.

title: Incremental compiler takes too long to react on Cancel
desc: I20090603-2000  I was waiting for more than a minute until the incremental compiler really canceled after I clicked the cancel button. During that time, stackdumps looked like the one below, with differences inside the ASTParser and with different objects on this line: - locked <0x25ab2d28> (a org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ProjectApiDescription$TypeNode)  Please check that you properly pass the monitor to the ASTParser. It also wouldn't hurt to check for cancellation manually before calling ASTParser#createAST(..). title: Compatibility and Usage tests do not respect specified compiler compliance
desc: Currently in our test suite we have a framework method getTestCompliance() which allows us to set the compiler compliance level on a per-test basis. While running the new tests for bug 258101 I noticed that the code that should be running was not: the test code was compiled to 1.5 even though the getTestCompliance() method returned 1.4.  After a bit of digging I found that our method for importing a project was toasting our project settings after-the-fact. Not sure on a fix yet, since it will affect a lot of tests...

desc: I20090127-0100  Each time the API Errors/Warnings preference or property page is opened, 12 fonts  are leaked. The allocations all look like this:  java.lang.Error 	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Device.new_Object(Device.java:804) 	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Resource.init(Resource.java:85) 	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Font.<init>(Font.java:110) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.preferences.ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.initializeInstalledMetatadata(ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.java:1297) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.preferences.ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.createPage(ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.java:944) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.preferences.ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.createControl(ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.java:839) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.preferences.ApiErrorsWarningsPreferencePage.createContents(ApiErrorsWarningsPreferencePage.java:105) 	at org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferencePage.createControl(PreferencePage.java:235) 	at org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferenceDialog.createPageControl(PreferenceDialog.java:1468)

title: The group for execution environment datas should be disabled
desc: When the option to check the references in the system libraries is set to ignore, the contents of the group (all widgets including labels, links,...) should be disabled.

title: NPE running API use scan
desc: I20090605-1444 + API tools code from HEAD  Scanning the type com.certicom.ecc.asn1.DSASigCodec$a I get the following NPE reported. It appears as though we are failing to look up a method and continuing on our merry way to an NPE. As shown in the visitor details the method we are trying to find clearly exists in the owning type.  visitor details:  method name= "a"  method desc= "(I)[B"  method owner= Type : access(8) com.certicom.ecc.asn1.DSASigCodec$a superclass: com.trustpoint.asn.AsnSequence;  Methods :  Method : access(8) ()V <clinit>; Method : access(1) ()V <init>; Method : access(1) ([B[B)V <init>; Method : access(1) (I)[B a;  Fields :  Field : access(10) [Lcom/trustpoint/asn/AsnMember; info isEnum constant false; Field : access(25) Ljava/lang/String; a isEnum constant false = S; Field : access(25) Ljava/lang/String; if isEnum constant false = R;  The problem I found from a bit of debugging is that the type $a appears to have a method 'byte[] a(int)' that is not a constructor, but our code for resolving a method name assumes that any method with the same name as the simple name of the enclosing type must be a constructor - so in our code we end up trying to look up 'byte[] <init>(int)'  java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ReferenceExtractor.visitMethod(ReferenceExtractor.java:1175) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ReferenceExtractor.processInnerClass(ReferenceExtractor.java:1147) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ReferenceExtractor.visitInnerClass(ReferenceExtractor.java:1126) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.ApiType.extractReferences(ApiType.java:161) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.getResolvedReferences(ApiSearchEngine.java:139) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.access$0(ApiSearchEngine.java:134) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine$ReferenceExtractor.visit(ApiSearchEngine.java:89) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.ArchiveApiTypeContainer.accept(ArchiveApiTypeContainer.java:168) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.AbstractApiTypeContainer.accept(AbstractApiTypeContainer.java:56) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.AbstractApiComponent.accept(AbstractApiComponent.java:58) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.searchReferences(ApiSearchEngine.java:216) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.search(ApiSearchEngine.java:285) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.usage.internal.ui.search.ApiUsageSearchPage$1.run(ApiUsageSearchPage.java:188) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: Optimize .api_description generation on export
desc: See bug 258822 comment #4.    In the particular case of exporting from the workspace with the new option to use the class files compiled in the workspace, .api_description adds significant time to the export.  Since we are using .class files from the workspace instead of recompiling, the time spent generating the api_description could in theory be spent before export.  We should investigate reusing the results of the API Analysis Builder during export.

title: Inconsistent result in incremental build for org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.builder.tests.usage.UnusedApiProblemFilterTests.testUnusedFilter2I()
desc: Using HEAD, it seems that the unused filter detection doesn't work in incremental build when the corresponding type is removed. This test only runs the usage check and that check gets an empty array of types to check in this case. This requires investigation.

title: API usage report shows internal references from fragment bundles
desc: Fragment bundles at runtime are considered as "part" of the host they are attached to.  Fragments should have access to any internals of their host bundle.  They do not need to import or get special access to packages available in their host (internal or API).  The current reports show internal references from fragment bundles to their host.  For example the usage reports for the SDK (available at http://www.eclipse.org/pde/pde-api-tools/) show internal references from org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry -> org.eclipse.equinox.registry  org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry is a fragment and should be able to reference internals from its host org.eclipse.equinox.registry.  I do think the information is useful.  Perhaps there should be another column showing references to internals from fragments, or maybe the internal references from fragments can be included in the Internal-Permissible References column?

title: test failures in N20090218-2000
desc: There are 16 suspicious test failures on the Mac only in the N20090218-2000 build.

title: NoSuchElementException in ReferenceExtractor
desc: Running a test API use scan against Galileo I encountered a NoSuchElementException when our reference extractor tried to process a local or anonymous type that has no references.

title: API tools wastes memory re-creating API types
desc: Created attachment 138933 [details] caching  I20090605-1444  Trying to scan a bundle that had a type with many (~1000) inner / anonymous types API tools will quickly produce an out of memory exception. The reason for this is that when we scan a class file we automatically scan dependent types - which we do to resolve local and anonymous enclosing elements. This is fine, but we are currently also not caching any of the API type handles that we create while scanning - which I found would quickly reach an instance count of ~6000.  We must cache elements / handles to prevent more than one element being created for a type at any one time. I propose that we mimic the JavaModelCache and use their OverflowingLRUCache mechanism.

title: ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock should use handler service to execute commands
desc: ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock should use handler service to execute commands. See bug 348584 for details.

title: Search engine should report results after a threshold has been hit
desc: I20090611-1540  Currently our search engine reports any results it has found when it finishes searching a package. It can happen that a package can contain many many types, which leads to our search engine running out of memory.  We should include a threshold (max reference count) that if hit would also report.

title: Support the API use report conversion outside of the Ant tasks
desc: Currently the default tooling for converting an API use report to an HTML report to completely implemented in the ant task that uses it. This code should be usable outside of the Ant task world so we can provide IDE support for reporting (report conversion).

title: ReferenceModifiers class should not exist
desc: Currently in our code base we have a class ReferenceModifiers which contains nothing but constants representing the different kinds of IReferences. These constants should be part of IReference.

title: Update incremental performance tests
desc: Now that we are getting some solid results from our incremental performance tests, we should update the Java 5 incremental perf tests the same way we did for the 'normal' incremental perf tests: remove all but the 'build all problems' from the global footprint.  This would require the removal of:  AnnotationIncrementalBuildTests#testIncrementalAnnotCompat() AnnotationIncrementalBuildTests#testIncrementalAnnotTags() EnumIncrementalBuildTests#testIncrementalEnumCompat() EnumIncrementalBuildTests#testIncrementalEnumTags() EnumIncrementalBuildTests#testIncrementalEnumUsage() EnumIncrementalBuildTests#testIncremetalEnumLeak()  No performance data will go missing with the removal, as building these problems is done in the main incremental perf tests:  AnnotationIncrementalBuildTests#testIncrementalAnnot() EnumIncrementalBuildTests#testIncremantalEnum()

title: No quickfix available for usage problem in ant.core
desc: Using I20090310-0100,  Steps to reproduce: 1) Check out ant.core from CVS (HEAD stream) 2) Set up a baseline (3.4.2) 3) You should get two usage problems. 4) Try quickfix of any of them 5) => Error: no quick fix available. Nothing in the .log file.

title: changing API baseline name triggers re-build
desc: Using  I20090310-0100  * If I change the name of an API baseline, it triggers a full build. It should not be required, since the content of the baseline has not changed.

title: Javadoc tags incorrcetly not proposed
desc: Consider the following code example:  /**  *   */ public class ClassUsageClass {   /**    * @noextend This class is not intended to be subclassed by clients.    * @noinstantiate This class is not intended to be instantiated by clients.   */   public static class inner {} 	 }  neither @noextend or @noinstantiate will be proposed for ClassUsageClass because they have been defined on an inner class. The cause is in our tag extactor - we are not ensuring the only type we are extracting tags from is the type we have activated the completion context on.

title: Usage tests do not perform incremental builds
desc: Using I20090310-0100 running the usage tests and debugging I found that the usage tests do not cause incremental builds to happen - each test is run as a full build.

title: Default API use search requestor does too much work configuring backing scope
desc: I20090611-1540  The default search requestor for API use searches does too much work when creating its backing scope object. For some reason it is trying to get all of the visible dependent API components and also add them to the scope - when all it should be doing is sorting the scope.

title: API tooling performance must be improved
desc: I20090611-1540 (and previous)  It has been experienced that the first build - upon starting the workspace - takes up to a few minutes to complete regardless of the kind of change actually made.   Part of the reason for this is that we have to re-build the API descriptions - that being said we have to find a way to improve this process and lessen the amount of work done on the first build.  One way we could potentially improve this is to make our build context just a bit smarter for our usage scans, where we end up loading / visiting API descriptions for dependent bundles of the one currently being built, even if the change(s) made does not effect them.

title: UI for API use scans
desc: Provide a user interface for creating API use scans. The UI should provide flexibility to:  * analyze an API baseline, target platform, or the workspace * specify the source scope to be searched (i.e. where to extract references from) * specify the target scope of interest (i.e. only collect references to specific things) * limit the scan to API and/or internal references  Source/target scopes could be an entire baseline, or a specific set of bundles within the baseline. We also need to consider other ways of grouping bundles to make it simpler to specify searches like "find all references between WTP and the SDK". For example, we might consider features.

title: Better handling of unused problem filters
desc: 3.6.  I switched my API tooling baseline from 3.4 to 3.5 which resulted in several new 'unused API filter' problems being reported. On some projects this even appears as errors because they changed the corresponding setting (see bug 280618).  I would expect smarter handling of those filters, e.g. simple remove or ignore outdated ones.

title: Incremental usage build does not work when restrictions are changed
desc: If you change the restrictions on a type and save (causing an incremental build) some API usage types are not reported.  Steps:  1. make sure you have done a clean full build  2. open InspectPopupDialog from org.eclipse.debug.ui and ExceptionInspector from org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui 3. add an @noinstantiate tag to InspectPupupDialog and save  Expected:  ExceptionInspector should have a usage problem created for illegally instantiating InspectPopUpDialog (on line 95)  Happens:  nothing, no problem is reported unless I do a full build on org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui or I edit ExceptionInspector and save it.

title: Add tests for search implementation
desc: We should add tests to cover the code located into the two packages: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.search

title: Pick one API scope and use it
desc: We have two API scopes in our tooling, both of them used to prune down the IApiElements to inspect (for some purpose). We should just turn the two classes into one and use that globally as our scope.  the interfaces in question are:  1. org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.model.IApiScope 2. org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.IApiSearchScope

title: New API Baseline dialog: Does not resize vertically
desc: Created attachment 139442 [details] Screenshot  I20090611-1540  New API Baseline dialog: Does not resize vertically.

title: Investigate removing the use of file handles in the API framework
desc: Currently in our API baselines and (some) type containers we hold onto file handles and open streams, which is what requires us to open / close baselines (both the workspace and default) during a build. In the full build world this is not so bad / noticeable, but in the incremental world this adds a significant percentage of time to the build (from my testing 24 - 48ms of time in a ~900 ms operation).   For the sake of not doing this extra work in the builds and to prevent leaking file handles / stream we should remove the use of file handles in favour of something else, URIs perhaps?

title: API search engine could continue searching when an error occurs
desc: Created attachment 140526 [details] proposed fix  I20090611-1540  Currently the search engine forwards all exceptions and stops searching when an error occurs. We could make the search engine simple report the error and move on to the next element in the scope - this would allow it to make a best effort to complete the search.

title: [perfs] Regression on 'Incremental Build - All' test
A lot of failing API tools tests in recent N builds (for Windows)
desc: N20090705-2000 and previous builds  There are hundreds of API tools errors in the nightly builds in the compatibility tests.  It seems that for some reason each of the tests is failing to find a testing API component, which causes the NPE when we try to create the API description.

title: Offer multi-quick fix for unused API filter problems
desc: R3.5.  Currently I have to remove each unused API filter problem one by one. We should offer a multi-quick fix here.  See org.eclipse.ui.views.markers.WorkbenchMarkerResolution.findOtherMarkers(IMarker[]) on how to make this happen.

desc: Once a baseline is selected, we should be able to remove it by pressing the "delete" key.

title: Incremental build should only analyze structural and description changes
desc: The API analysis incremental build should only analyze types that have structural changes or have API description changes (and all their dependents). Currently, we analyze all types that change (structually or non-structurally), and all their dependents).  As well, only API visible types should be considered for analysis. A change to a non-API type does not effect API compatibility or API use.

title: ReferenceExtractor is failing to lookup method signatures (caching problem)
desc: I20090707-0800  Running our smoke tests trying to find why our tests fail, I found that in our reference extractor we are trying to look up methods with differing signatures (qualified vs. unqualified).  Example: ReferenceExtractor is trying to look up:  name - m1 signature - ()Linternal/x/y/z/internal;  in API type:  Type : access(33) x.y.z.testMRL2 superclass: java.lang.Object;  Methods :  Method : access(1) ()V <init>; Method : access(2) ()Linternal; m1; Method : access(2) ()Linternal; m2; Method : access(2) ()LIinternal; m3; Method : access(2) ()LIinternal; m4;  The method in question is there, just that it is not correctly qualified.  I get the feeling this is a cache update problem - as I had dragged the type 'internal' from the default package to the 'internal.x.y.z' package

title: Compile warnings in official build
desc: http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/N20140813-2000/compilelogs/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui_1.0.600.N20140813-2000/@dot.html  We have several of these after suppressing the unused local variable warnings:  1. WARNING in /src/org/eclipse/pde/api/tools/ui/internal/preferences/ApiErrorsWarningsConfigurationBlock.java  (at line 1190) } catch (@SuppressWarnings("unused") ExecutionException ex) { Unnecessary @SuppressWarnings("unused")   The reason are different compiler settings for the project and the official build (unused locals isn't reported by the build).

title: IllegalArgumentException visiting type instruction with a type name that is one char
desc: Created attachment 142788 [details] proposed fix  I20090721-1200  The use scanning uncovered a problem in our method visitor when we visit a type instruction in a method. The problem comes from a type instruction where the type description is only one character in size.   Consider the following example:  void method() {   A a = new A(); }  It so happens that in our visitor we end up passing A to Signature.getTypeSignatureKind(..) which throws the IllegalArgumentException since A is not known as a kind in Signature.  The attached patch changes the behavior slightly by trying to ask JDT about the description if its size is 1 character, but falling back to ask ASM if JDT fails to return successfully.

title: cleaning project should not "remove" API description
desc: When a project is cleaned, its API description should be cleaned but not removed from the API description manager cache. It should remain in the cache until the project is removed/deleted (else it is no longer managed, but remains in the API component and will be visited/used in potentially wrong states).  This is the cause of the 100% peformance increase in the perf tests - the description is not actually cleaned and the visit is a no-op.

title: Baseline 'workspace' is disposed logged and API tooling wrongly reports missing @since tag problem
desc: Build id: I20090728-1414.  I get this in my log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 123 2009-07-29 17:38:09.613 !MESSAGE Baseline 'workspace' is disposed  and then API tooling wrongly reports missing @since tag problem.  Steps to reproduce: 1. start new workspace 2. check out 'org.eclipse.ui.workbench' from CVS    ==> no error reported (good) 3. set API tooling baseline to R3.5 named 'a'    ==> no error reported (good) 4. clean all (which triggers rebuild) ==> "Baseline 'workspace' is disposed" gets logged ==> wrong error problem about missing @since tag.  Marking as 'major' as I see an error in my workspace which shouldn't be there and I get "Baseline 'workspace' is disposed" in my log without any clue what the consequences are (e.g. is API tooling now busted? does a restart fix it?).

title: Edit Api baseline wizard not properly initialized
desc: I20090407-1430  When you double-click an API baseline to edit it the location combo has nothing in it but the list is populated with bundles  Steps:  1. double-click a non-default baseline to edit it  expected:   all fields are properly initialized  happens:  the location combo has nothing in it even though there are bundles in the list

title: API tools should tolerate bad classfiles
desc: I20090809-2000  Using our use scanning tooling to scan some third party bundles I encountered a case where we try to scan a classfile that is bogus - in my example it was a classfile that had no class definition in it. The net effect was a pile of NPEs and ClassFormatExceptions.  We should just skip bad classfiles.

title: API baseline manager should not hold on to java.io.File handles
desc: I20090407-1430  while fixing bug 272196 I noticed that the ApiBaselineManager hangs on to java.io.File handles once it has initialized its state cache. These handles are used to lazily load the infos for a baseline when more than its name are needed. We should change this to be locations and not hold the java.io.File handles.

title: Provide mechanism to remove API tooling
desc: It would be nice if there was a way to remove api tooling setup from a project (remove the builder and nature). I suppose it could even be super-deluxe and recreate the component.xml file based on tags it finds (and removes).

title: Adding a constant to an API interface then removing causes incorrect @since error
desc: Build id: I20090818-0800  Steps to recreate  - Have a baseline setup for 3.5.0 - Check a bundle out from R3_5 tag that contains a interface that is API - Add a constant to the interface - You correctly get an error/warning about missing @since tag - Perform the quick fix to get rid of the error/warning - Replace the local copy of the interface with the content from R3_5 - Notice that an error/warning shows up against the interface about missing @since tag.  Clean and rebuild the project does not help.  You must restart and then do a clean build of the project.

Please add a link (for getting to the preference page) or a button (for adding an API baseline) to that dialog!

title: API setup wizard accepts binary projects
desc: I20090428-0100  If I activate the API Tooling setup wizard on a binary project nothing appears in the table of projects, but the checked counter says one project is selected and the next button will show me proposed chnages for adding the API tools nature to the binary project.  Steps:  1. start new workspace 2. import org.junit into your workspace as a binary project 3. open the API tooling setup wizard on the project  Expected:  the wizard will open and there will be no projects in the table or selected and the finish / next buttons will be disabled.  Happens:  the wizard opens, there is nothing in the table, but the checked counter says there is one project selected and pressing Next will show me proposed changes to the binary project.  The problem comes from the getWorkbenchSelection() method in the wizard, it does not prune binary projects like the method for deriving the overall input does.

desc: !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2009-05-05 07:31:33.664 !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiFilterStore.getStoreAsXml(ApiFilterStore.java:403) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiFilterStore.access$2(ApiFilterStore.java:391) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiFilterStore$1.runInWorkspace(ApiFilterStore.java:135) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)  It looks like all accesses to fFilterMap should be synchronized.

title: Cheese in the progress view
desc: I20090818-0800  While waiting for a full build I noticed that in the progress view the current job info said "Checking @since tags..." followed by the info from the Java builder.

title: Provide summary of missing required bundles
desc: I20090818-0800  With the new details provided for why bundles have not been searched (for use reporting), it would be nice if there was an additional page listing all of the bundles required for a complete search.  This information is available on the details page, but it is quite annoying to have to check the details for every single skipped bundle when a nice summary page could tell you what bundles are missing in a simple list.

title: Reverting workspace only works for compatibility tests
desc: FUP to bug 275005, the usage tests were attempting to use the revertible workspace, which was found to only work for compatibility tests (reliably). The reverting workspace should be updated to allow all tests to leverage it.

title: API use scan UI should make a default selection of what to analyze
desc: I20090825-1032  When you create a new use scan configuration, there is no default selected in the Analyze section. Once you make a selection pressing the revert button (which becomes enabled) does nothing.

title: 10 Unnecessary @SuppressWarnings("unused") warnings in official build
desc: N20160320-2000.  10 Unnecessary @SuppressWarnings("unused") warnings in official build.  http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/N20160320-2000/compilelogs/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui_1.1.0.N20160320-2000/@dot.html   This got surfaced by wrong change: https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/68136/

title: API use XML could be a bit smaller
desc: I20090825-1032  Darin found that some of our API use XML output could shrunk a bit by removing some duplication of 'referee' information.

title: Html report could not be generated from ui.views api changes
desc: I20090901-0800  Using the "Compare with API baseline" for the ui.views bundle, I could not generate the HTML report once the comparison was complete.

title: Missing @since tags for split plug-ins repeatedly reported on the MANIFEST.MF
desc: I20090915-0100  Strange things happen when I add API to a class in a plug-in that has been extracted from a depending plug-in.  Concretely, I have org.eclipse.jdt.junit.core from HEAD in my workspace and 3.5 set as API baseline. Now when I add a method to org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestRunListener, I would expect an error on the method if its Javadoc doesn't declare @since 3.6.  But in my main workspace, I get an error on the MANIFEST.MF:  Missing @since tag on org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestRunListener.sessionLaunched(ITestRunSession)	MANIFEST.MF	/org.eclipse.jdt.junit/META-INF	@since tag problem	line 2  Each time I save the CU, another error marker is added.  When I tried to reproduce in a fresh workspace, I go no error at all when I only checked out org.eclipse.jdt.junit.core. When I added org.eclipse.jdt.junit, it started to behave the same as in my main workspace.  In 3.5, there was only org.eclipse.jdt.junit. In HEAD, org.eclipse.jdt.junit.core has been added. The latter is required and re-exported by the org.eclipse.jdt.junit plug-in, and some APIs have been moved to the core plug-in.

title: [use scan] show everything about a package/type at once
desc: Pascal commented that he would like to be able to look at an API use scan to see everything about how a package and its types are used all at once... rather than having to see it by consumer, etc.

desc: From the console logs for I20090506-2000  An NPE was logged trying to get the resolution errors for a BundleApiComponent:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 2 2009-05-07 02:34:26.360 !MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.core.resources". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.osgi.internal.resolver.StateImpl.getResolverErrors(StateImpl.java:909) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.BundleApiComponent.getErrors(BundleApiComponent.java:1167) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.analyzeComponent(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:180) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildAll(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:363) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:227) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:627) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:42) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:42) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: Full build run after removing unused API problem filter
desc: While verifying the combined fix for bug 274515 I found that a full was occurring when I would add / remove API problem filters for jdt.core.  Steps:  1. remove the final keyword from CompilationParticipant#READY_FOR_BUILD 2. save   Expected  CompilationParticipant is rebuilt  Happens all of jdt.core is rescanned by the API tools builder - notice in the progress view that all packages are re-scanned for unsupported tags and usage

title: Issues with quickfix for adding @noreference tag
desc: The quickfix for adding a @noreference tag when an API-method leaks a non-API type (see bug 229824) is not very useful currently.  (1) It doesn't silence the warning for which it is offered.     Additionally a @nooverride tag is needed (see bug 229824 comment 6).  (2) Since one tag doesn't silence the warning the quickfix can be applied     any number of times -> creating any number of identical tags.  Easiest solution would be to add both tags by one quickfix if that's not too inconsistent with other quickfixes (I can't think of another quickfix that performs two actions in one).  A weaker solution would be to offer two quickfixes, one for each tag. In that case each quickfix should additionally check whether it has been applied before .. do you see why I consider the other solution as simpler?

title: Report the list of the bundles that contain references
desc: It would be good if on the first page of the report, there was a link to a list of all the bundles where references had been found. This would allow for a quick identification of the interesting plug-ins. In my case this is of interest so I could easily load the code of these plug-ins and look at their code.

title: ApiType#getSimpleName() fails for local types with numbers for simple names
desc: I20090508-2000  when we process the type name of a local ApiType to derive its simple name we do not consider that the name of the local type might be a number (like an anonymous type name). This causes our code to return null for the simple type name when in fact the local type has a name: for example local type x.y.z.Class$1 the simple name for the local type is '1'. It is not common to have a local type named with number like this but the compiler can generate code like this.

title: Add summary metadata to the index page of a use / migration scan
desc: I20091006-0800  When a use or migration scan is done, there is no simple way to tell what the scans were done against - for example that a use scan was done against an Eclipse 3.4 baseline. It would be extremely useful to have a summary or some kind of metadata on the index page of the scan that outlines some (all) of the information from the scan like:  1. baselines used 2. locations 3. scan parameter(s) 4. date of the scan  for example.

title: Allow nested archives to be filtered from a use scan
desc: Created attachment 150265 [details] fix  I20091020-0931  It would be good to have the ability to filter select nested archives from a given bundle during an API use scan. This would allow reused / compatibility code made available in a bundle (and on the bundle classpath) to not show up during a scan.  Arguably, one could say that they should not appear on the bundle class path, but if they do this could be used to prune reported usage for those bundles.  The attached patch updates the apitooling.apiuse Ant task to accept a comma separated listing of archive identifiers to ignore, as well the external tools UI has been updated with a new wizard to help create patterns

title: Provide ability to filter during API use scan report generation
desc: I20091110-0800  When we are generating HTML reports it would be very handy to be able to filter the kinds of things shown in the resulting report. For example, support for a simple list of regular expressions that could be supplied to the Ant task to prune generated infos.

title: API builder fails to build dependent types
desc: I20091124-0800  Performing a dependent type smoke test between Ant and Debug I found that not all dependent types are being built during an incremental build.  Steps  1. get debug.core and ant.launching from HEAD 2. open Launch and AntLaunch 3. add an @noextend tag to Launch 4. save  Expected An API tools warning would appear on AntLaunch  Happens NOTHING!  Confirmed on Linux and Windows

title: API tools code has a lot of JDT warnings
desc: Created attachment 135598 [details] proposed fix  - code from HEAD  Confirming our compiler options for our projects (core, tests and UI) I found that we have a lot of JDT warnings about no-thrown exceptions, unnecessary else statements, synthetic accessors, etc. These should be cleaned up for RC1.

title: PluginProjectApiComponent#createApiTypeContainers() should be synchronized
desc: Created attachment 136330 [details] proposed fix  I20090518-2000  FUP to bug 275338 we synchronized the createApiTypeContainers() method for BundleApiComponent but did not do so for the overriding method in PluginProjectApiComponent.

title: Dialog help does not show unless page content is selected
desc: Created attachment 137066 [details] fix  3.5RC2  On the API baselines preference page if you select the page from the tree and press the ? help button the default preferences help is shown. If you select the table in the page, for example, and then press the ? button the correct help for the page is shown.

title: NPE running API use scan
desc: I20090605-1444 + API tools code from HEAD  Scanning the type com.certicom.ecc.asn1.DSASigCodec$a I get the following NPE reported. It appears as though we are failing to look up a method and continuing on our merry way to an NPE. As shown in the visitor details the method we are trying to find clearly exists in the owning type.  visitor details:  method name= "a"  method desc= "(I)[B"  method owner= Type : access(8) com.certicom.ecc.asn1.DSASigCodec$a superclass: com.trustpoint.asn.AsnSequence;  Methods :  Method : access(8) ()V <clinit>; Method : access(1) ()V <init>; Method : access(1) ([B[B)V <init>; Method : access(1) (I)[B a;  Fields :  Field : access(10) [Lcom/trustpoint/asn/AsnMember; info isEnum constant false; Field : access(25) Ljava/lang/String; a isEnum constant false = S; Field : access(25) Ljava/lang/String; if isEnum constant false = R;  The problem I found from a bit of debugging is that the type $a appears to have a method 'byte[] a(int)' that is not a constructor, but our code for resolving a method name assumes that any method with the same name as the simple name of the enclosing type must be a constructor - so in our code we end up trying to look up 'byte[] <init>(int)'  java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ReferenceExtractor.visitMethod(ReferenceExtractor.java:1175) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ReferenceExtractor.processInnerClass(ReferenceExtractor.java:1147) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ReferenceExtractor.visitInnerClass(ReferenceExtractor.java:1126) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.ApiType.extractReferences(ApiType.java:161) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.getResolvedReferences(ApiSearchEngine.java:139) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.access$0(ApiSearchEngine.java:134) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine$ReferenceExtractor.visit(ApiSearchEngine.java:89) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.ArchiveApiTypeContainer.accept(ArchiveApiTypeContainer.java:168) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.AbstractApiTypeContainer.accept(AbstractApiTypeContainer.java:56) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.AbstractApiComponent.accept(AbstractApiComponent.java:58) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.searchReferences(ApiSearchEngine.java:216) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.provisional.search.ApiSearchEngine.search(ApiSearchEngine.java:285) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.usage.internal.ui.search.ApiUsageSearchPage$1.run(ApiUsageSearchPage.java:188) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: Investigate using the PDE state for our workspace baseline
desc: Currently API tools creates and manages its own OSGi state for our workspace baseline. This effort is basically cloning the work PDE already does. We should investigate using the PDE state for our workspace baseline to avoid all the state management work altogether.   We can also reap benefits from:   1. not having to include the entire target platform in the workspace baseline 2. we can better compute the complete dependency trees for bundles in the workspace baseline

title: Folder type container has poor performance
desc: Created attachment 153580 [details] complete thread dump  I20091201-1600  My dev workspace was completely compiled. I accepted several incoming changes, one of which caused a compile error (org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.preferences.ComplianceConfigurationBlock can't resolve import BundleDefaultsScope).  The incremental build took very long. After a while, I took a thread dump and started tracing, which confirmed that most of the time was burned in FolderApiTypeContainer.collectPackageNames(..). I didn't see disk activity, just one CPU core at 100%.  I could not reproduce by reverting and restoring ComplianceConfigurationBlock, so the compile error may not be the actual problem. title: Wrong unused api filters warning are reported
desc: Using I20091201-1600,  1) check out JDT/Core from HEAD  2) set incremental compilation on 3) Do a full build of JDT/Core 4) Open org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTParser 5) Add a space and save 6) You get a warning saying that The API problem filter for: 'Invalid @since tag '3.5.2' on IGNORE_METHOD_BODIES; expecting two fragments' is no longer used ICompilationUnit.java /org.eclipse.jdt.core/model/org/eclipse/jdt/core line 36 Unused API Problem Filter Problem 7) Do a full build and the problem is gone  It looks like all api filters are being checked on incremental build. Not just the ones from recompiled types.

title: NPE from API Freeze Report Conversion task when new bundle is added

title: Remove use of the word "profile" to mean baseline
desc: Created attachment 153733 [details] fix  There are several places in our code where we still refer to an API baseline as an API profile. There are even a few builder messages - NLS'd and visible to users - that do this.

title: Errors while resolving a baseline inside ant tasks should be reported somehow
desc: Using HEAD, I got many problems with unresolved bundles inside an API baseline initialized using an SDK zip.  I took me lots of time to realize that all problems came from missing Execution Environments set up in my self-hosting workspace.  The ant task should report this to the user somehow. I would say all resolved errors for a state should be reported because unresolved bundles or resolved errors will have a direct impact on the accuracy of the API tools analysis.

title: API Freeze check leads to a NPE
desc: When trying to fix 344976 I got a NPE while running the ant task.

title: Restore Defaults doesn't swich two options in API Errors preferences
desc: Build id: I20091207-1800  In API Errors/Warnings > API Compatibility > Bundle two last options are not switched by Set All As/Restore Defaults buttons.

title: Message from an aborted build needs to be more fine grained
desc: 3.6M4 (FUP to bug 297096)  With the new support to abort a build when a fatal JDT error is detected, we need to more finely tailor the message we report based on what fatal errors we found. Right now we broadly look at model failures on the project, but we should be checking the markers we found to report differing reasons i.e. it would be more clear to the user why we aborted our build.  Also we should make a separate problem category for these build-abort problems, as they are now piggy-backed on the API component resolution category which can be ignored - and we should never be able to ignore a build-abort problem.

title: ZipException scanning bundle with other entries on bundle classpath
desc: I20090605-1444  It seems that when trying to open + scan a bundle that has '.' and something else on the bundle classpath we are creating a bogus tmp file and saying that it is the location for an archive. One of the bundles that caused this exception had a bundle classpath defined like:  Bundle-ClassPath: .,constraints/  The code that is dumping these api*tmp files is in title: API tools wastes memory re-creating API types
desc: Created attachment 138933 [details] caching  I20090605-1444  Trying to scan a bundle that had a type with many (~1000) inner / anonymous types API tools will quickly produce an out of memory exception. The reason for this is that when we scan a class file we automatically scan dependent types - which we do to resolve local and anonymous enclosing elements. This is fine, but we are currently also not caching any of the API type handles that we create while scanning - which I found would quickly reach an instance count of ~6000.  We must cache elements / handles to prevent more than one element being created for a type at any one time. I propose that we mimic the JavaModelCache and use their OverflowingLRUCache mechanism.

title: Memory leak due to requesting delta but never using it
desc: PDE API tools adds a save participant in the ApiPlugin class. In this participant you invoke ISaveContext#needDelta, which causes the resources plugin to record the workspace tree state from the save point to supply you with a delta when your bundle next starts up. However, when you startup, you never process the resource delta, which causes the workspace to retain that delta indefinitely. This results in a growing memory leak as the workspace continues to change (the old tree state is remembered as a delta against the current tree state, so that delta keeps growing). We eventually discard this delta automatically, but you should either:  1) Stop calling ISaveContext#needDelta  OR  2) Process the delta on startup by calling ISavedState#processResourceChangeEvents(IResourceChangeListener) when you register your participant.  We could likely optimize the memory usage within the workspace, but regardless there is no point in us recording the delta if you are never going to use it.  I'm marking this major since in my case it resulted in a 72MB delta in memory after several days of running. However I will also open a bug on the resources side to see if we can improve this.

title: Search engine should report results after a threshold has been hit
desc: I20090611-1540  Currently our search engine reports any results it has found when it finishes searching a package. It can happen that a package can contain many many types, which leads to our search engine running out of memory.  We should include a threshold (max reference count) that if hit would also report.

title: Refactoring fails to update model caches
desc: Build Identifier: I20091210-1301 Seems PDE do some additional work often fails. I Paste my eclipse latest error log: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.refactoring.RefactoringUtils.createDeleteFilterChanges(RefactoringUtils.java:49) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.refactoring.FilterMoveParticipant.createPreChange(FilterMoveParticipant.java:56) at org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring.participants.ProcessorBasedRefactoring.createChange(ProcessorBasedRefactoring.java:307) at org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring.CreateChangeOperation.run(CreateChangeOperation.java:124) at org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring.PerformChangeOperation.run(PerformChangeOperation.java:209) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run(Workspace.java:1857) at org.eclipse.ltk.internal.ui.refactoring.WorkbenchRunnableAdapter.run(WorkbenchRunnableAdapter.java:87) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:121) The NPE because this invocation: /** * Gets the {@link IApiFilterStore} for the given {@link IProject} * @param project * @return the filter store for the given project or null * @throws CoreException */ static IApiFilterStore resolveFilterStore(IProject project) throws CoreException { IApiComponent component = ApiPlugin.getDefault().getApiBaselineManager().getWorkspaceBaseline().getApiComponent(project); if(component != null) { return component.getFilterStore(); } return null; } IApiComponent fails. Reproducible: Sometimes Steps to Reproduce: 1.this kind error often kill me.:) 2.I paste my log file at the attatchment

title: Default API use search requestor does too much work configuring backing scope
desc: I20090611-1540  The default search requestor for API use searches does too much work when creating its backing scope object. For some reason it is trying to get all of the visible dependent API components and also add them to the scope - when all it should be doing is sorting the scope.

title: [api tooling] comments from Eugene
desc: For reference:  Chris Aniszczyk/Austin/IBM@IBMUS  2008-01-08 08:36	 	To 	Darin Wright/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA 	cc 	Olivier Thomann/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA, Michael Rennie/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA, Jeff McAffer/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA 	Subject 	Fw: PDE API tools and ASM bytecode manipulation framework 	 	 	 	  FYI, I asked my friend Eugene (author of ASM) for some comments about PDE API Tools usage of ASM. Here they are:  I'd recommend possibly opening bugs for the issues that you think are relevant.  Cheers,  --- Chris Aniszczyk | IBM Lotus | Eclipse Committer | http://mea-bloga.blogspot.com | +1.860.839.2465 ----- Forwarded by Chris Aniszczyk/Austin/IBM on 01/08/2008 07:34 AM ----- From:	Eugene Kuleshov <eu@md.pp.ru> To:	pde-ui-dev@eclipse.org Cc:	Chris Aniszczyk/Austin/IBM@IBMUS Date:	01/07/2008 11:59 PM Subject:	PDE API tools and ASM bytecode manipulation framework    Hi everyone,    Chris Aniszczyk mentioned another day that PDE API tools are using ASM  framework. Since I am one of the developers of ASM, I thought it would  be useful to share my thoughts and comments about PDE usage of ASM as  well as few questions that could help me to get better understanding of  your implementation and use cases. My observations are more or less  random and mostly based on a quick scanning trough ASM API calls and  don't assume deep analysis of the PDE implementation. Please don't take  those notes as criticism, those simply suggestions for better usage of  the ASM API that could help to improve performance and memory usage for  your application. I think it is really great application for ASM library  and I am very excited about it.    First of all I see that PDE API tools is using "asm" and "asm-tree"  jars. However "asm-tree" jar is usually used for complex in-memory class  transformations and method analysis, which doesn't seem the case for PDE  API tools. I found two uses of the "tree" classes and they both can be  removed: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.comparator.TypeDescriptor  and org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.search.ClassFileVisitor   Basically those classes are making inefficient use of ClassNode, where  it can be replaced either with org.objectweb.asm.commons.EmptyVisitor  from "asm-commons" jar or your own dummy implementation of all ASM's  visitor interfaces, like the  org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.util.ClassVisitorAdapter you have.  That would improve processing performance and eliminate unnecessary  memory allocation.    If I understood TypeDescriptor.initialize() method correctly, it is  not interested in the method code, so you could use  classReader.accept(visitor, ClassReader.SKIP_CODE); to completely skip  all methods code from visiting. Same applies to implementation of  SearchEngine.getExtraction(..) and TagScanner.Visitor.getMethods(..)  methods, where you also can add ClassReader.SKIP_CODE to avoid visiting  method code.    There is a feature in ASM that allows to skip unneeded methods and  other class artifacts. So you can return a null from visitMethod() call,  then method code will be also skipped (that also happens when you visit  an abstract or native method). For example, in  Converter.MyClassFileAdapter.visitMethod() you could rewrite the  following code:              MethodVisitor visitor = super.visitMethod(accessFlags,  methodName, desc, signature, exceptions);             if (visitor != null) {                 if (reportRefs) {                     visitor = new MyMethodAdapter(visitor);                 } else {                     visitor = new ClearCodeAttributeMethodAdapter(visitor);                 }             }             return visitor;    like this :              MethodVisitor visitor = super.visitMethod(accessFlags,  methodName, desc, signature, exceptions);             if (visitor != null) {                 if (reportRefs) {                     visitor = new MyMethodAdapter(visitor);                 } else {                     visitor.visitEnd();  // for safety                     visitor = null;                 }             }             return visitor;    The above essentially eliminating ClearCodeAttributeMethodAdapter,  which should probably have been implementing MethodVisitor directly  instead of extending MethodAdapter, or  org.objectweb.asm.commons.EmptyVisitor should have been used instead of it.    If none of your visitors actually cares about StackMap information,  you may as well add ClassReader.SKIP_FRAMES flag to  ClassReader.accept(..) call when reading or transforming classes.    It is better to not extend ClassAdapter when visitor doesn't do any  transformations and it is used only to collect data, like  ClassFileDescriptorBuilder does. I would suggest to use something like  EmptyVisitor for that. Though it is worth to mention that  org.objectweb.asm.commons.EmptyVisitor is flattening the visiting  events, i.e. it don't make difference between method and fields  annotations, but you can return new instance of the EmptyVisitor  subclass if you need to keep hierarchy.   Also, code in ClassFileDescriptorBuilder.visitMethod() that extracts  value for default annotation look fairly similar to the code in   org.objectweb.asm.util.TraceAnnotationVisitor class from ASM's  "asm-util" jar, but your version doesn't seem add separator between  array entries.     In ClassFileVisitor.visitMethod(..) method. The following code:     switch(type.getSort()) {       case Type.LONG :       case Type.DOUBLE :         argumentcount += 2;      default:         argumentcount++;     }    can be replaced with: argumentcount += type.getSize();    The state machine used in Converter.MyMethodAdapter (passing  stringLiteral between visitLdcInsn() and visitMethodInsn() methods) is  probably going to work for classes compiled by javac or JDT, but there  could be legal bytecode that won't fit into that pattern, but I am not  sure what is the implication of that for PDE API tools.    I think I understand what MyMethodAdapter does about reference types  (which seem very neat idea), but I'd be interested to learn why you have  special processing for ASTORE, IRETURN, RETURN, ATHROW and POP opcodes  and not all INVOKE* opcodes?    In Converter.MyClassFileAdapter.visit(..) it is better to use  Opcodes.V1_5 instead of magic number "49". Though I wonder why you need  to use that version instead of version from the original class?   In the same method, it might be better to use annotation instead of  custom attribute. Annotations are usually easier to access (in the  bytecode as well as trough reflectio API) and you can still store them  into classes with version <49. Though that is obviously matter of  personal preferences.   I also curious what Converter.MyMethodWriter is used for? I don't see  any use of collected lastOffset value.    Hope you would find these notes somehow useful. Please let me know if  I could be at any help in regards to ASM framework and thanks again for  using it.

title: None of the API Errors/Warnings preference pages has mnemonics
desc: I20100107-1410.  None of the API Errors/Warnings preference pages has mnemonics

title: API tooling performance must be improved
desc: I20090611-1540 (and previous)  It has been experienced that the first build - upon starting the workspace - takes up to a few minutes to complete regardless of the kind of change actually made.   Part of the reason for this is that we have to re-build the API descriptions - that being said we have to find a way to improve this process and lessen the amount of work done on the first build.  One way we could potentially improve this is to make our build context just a bit smarter for our usage scans, where we end up loading / visiting API descriptions for dependent bundles of the one currently being built, even if the change(s) made does not effect them.

title: UI for API use scans
desc: Provide a user interface for creating API use scans. The UI should provide flexibility to:  * analyze an API baseline, target platform, or the workspace * specify the source scope to be searched (i.e. where to extract references from) * specify the target scope of interest (i.e. only collect references to specific things) * limit the scan to API and/or internal references  Source/target scopes could be an entire baseline, or a specific set of bundles within the baseline. We also need to consider other ways of grouping bundles to make it simpler to specify searches like "find all references between WTP and the SDK". For example, we might consider features.

title: PDE wizard doesn't properly set the API Tools nature and builder when creating a new plug-in project
desc: Build Id: 4.2 I20111205-0805  Apologies if I'm missing something here, but I thought that, providing I had definitions for my various Executable Environments installed (Preferences > Plug-in Development > API Errors/Warnings), that those definitions were used to validate system library usage without needing a corresponding JRE to be installed.  But this does not seem to be the case.  In my situation, I had a plugin with BREE set to J2SE-1.5, but I only had a Java6 JDK.  I was was inadvertently using Java6's String#isEmpty() with no errors, despite that my "Invalid references to execution environments" was set to an error.  My expectation was based on Ankur Sharma's blog [1]     Another major difference is that API Tooling does not need JRE/JDK.    It checks the usage against the environment descriptions. The    descriptions are just the environment API and thus occupy very    less space. For example, the 1.5 JRE takes close to 50MB while the    descriptions for the same takes less than 2 MB.  And the brief discussion on bugs 213027 and 253693 makes no mention of requiring a matching JRE to be installed.  Is this a regression?  Or a deliberate change?  I noticed the screenshots have changed since Ankur's blog entry which referenced "Invalid references to system libraries".  I bring this up as although I was able to find and install a J2SE 1.5 JRE to enable the check, it was somewhat difficult to find and install (Apple only supports Java6 JVMs now).  I don't think I could find a working 1.4 JVM, let alone a 1.3 JVM if that was required.  And JDT's Installed JREs dialog is rather unforgiving if the JRE directory layout doesn't meet its expectations.  [1] http://blog.ankursharma.org/2009/07/system-library-validation_17.html

title: ee.osgiminimum 1.2 is missing X500Principal
desc: I have org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ee.osgiminimum12_1.0.200.v20120530-1420 installed and it seems to be missing the following as defined by the OSGi min 1.2 execution environment.  javax/security/auth/x500/X500Principal.class

title: Better handling of unused problem filters
desc: 3.6.  I switched my API tooling baseline from 3.4 to 3.5 which resulted in several new 'unused API filter' problems being reported. On some projects this even appears as errors because they changed the corresponding setting (see bug 280618).  I would expect smarter handling of those filters, e.g. simple remove or ignore outdated ones.

title: [api tooling] polish API profile creation wizard
desc: We should polish the API profile creation wizard. Perhaps it would be simpler for users to create profiles if we separate "how" to create the profile into a different page.  For example, currently the wizard has a drop-down/text box to specify the location of the bundles to place into the profile. If we put this on a first page we could support differnt creation methods (I can see that this may be different when targeting a p2 install). As well, this may allow us to infer the execution environment for the profile, rather than making the user select one.

title: New API Baseline dialog: Does not resize vertically
desc: Created attachment 139442 [details] Screenshot  I20090611-1540  New API Baseline dialog: Does not resize vertically.

title: API search engine could continue searching when an error occurs
desc: Created attachment 140526 [details] proposed fix  I20090611-1540  Currently the search engine forwards all exceptions and stops searching when an error occurs. We could make the search engine simple report the error and move on to the next element in the scope - this would allow it to make a best effort to complete the search.

title: A lot of failing API tools tests in recent N builds (for Windows)
desc: N20090705-2000 and previous builds  There are hundreds of API tools errors in the nightly builds in the compatibility tests.  It seems that for some reason each of the tests is failing to find a testing API component, which causes the NPE when we try to create the API description.

title: Offer multi-quick fix for unused API filter problems
desc: R3.5.  Currently I have to remove each unused API filter problem one by one. We should offer a multi-quick fix here.  See org.eclipse.ui.views.markers.WorkbenchMarkerResolution.findOtherMarkers(IMarker[]) on how to make this happen.

title: Name collision for certain method keys causes false-positive illegal use to be reported
desc: I20100107-1410  Testing the new support for reporting illegal API use in the API use scans, I found that under certain circumstances key collisions would occur in our illegal method reference detector.  The example I found to debug was:  1. CompareEditorInput.dispose() would be added to the listing of restricted methods - CORRECT as it has a @noreference tag on it 2. any other method reference to any dispose() method - not just in CompareEditorInput - would be reported as illegal use. For example the following is reported as illegal use:    From: org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.AntEditor#void dispose()  Resolved To: org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.TextEditor#void dispose()  Kind: INVOKED_SPECIAL  which it is not - INCORRECT.

title: [api tooling] @noreference on compile-time constant does not work
desc: I have the following projects in my workspace:  org.eclipse.core.variables org.eclipse.debug.core org.eclipse.debug.ui org.eclipse.jdt.debug org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui org.eclipse.jdt.launching org.eclipse.ui.console  I added a @noreference flag to ILaunchConfiguration.LAUNCH_CONFIGURATION_FILE_EXTENSION.  The reference in LaunchingPlugin.start(BundleContext) is not flagged as an error. But, a @noreference flag on ILaunchConfigugration.ATTR_SOURCE_LOCATOR_MEMENTO does produce errors for its references.

title: Race condition causes API filters to be removed
desc: I20100107-1410  testing the fix for bug 280619 and using the steps from comment #13 on that bug, I found that the workspace job to save filters was being preempted by the workspace baseline being disposed. This would cause the filter store to be closed, which would flush the filter map. Then when the job ran to save the filters it would delete the existing file thinking that there are no filters.  Steps 1. new workspace 2. bring in org.eclipse.ui.navigator 3. set baseline to 3.5 4. after build unused filters reported: OK 5. set project setting to remove filters automatically 6. after build the .settings/.api_filters file is gone and 4 problems are reported - which should remain filtered: BUG

title: Unused strings in plugin.properties for api tools UI
desc: Created attachment 141133 [details] fix  I20090707-0800  stumbled across a bunch of unused strings in our plugin.properties files for API tools UI.

title: API use scan reports can be hard to read
desc: I20100107-1410  Thinking of ways to make the use scan reports look a bit better, I think it would be a good idea to have the version information not appear as part of the bundle name. Perhaps moving it to be alt text for the bundle name, or its own column would make it easier to immediately read the bundle name.

title: Update to the latest version of ASM (3.2)
desc: To be good citizens, we should upgrade to the latest version of ASM in the 3.6 stream.  I have filed a CQ:      http://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=3427

title: Internal code usage scan does not consider split bundles
desc: I20100112-0800.  If a tool references internal code from bundle A and A gets split into A and B (or more general into B and C) with all fully qualified types names kept the same, then this is wrongly reported as breakage.  Test Case: org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.ITestKind.getDisplayName().

title: Internal code usage scan report should indicate return type change
desc: I20100112-0800.  The internal API scan report should indicate return type changes since those are hard to track down otherwise.

title: NPE when opening existing workspace, I20100115-1100
desc: Created attachment 156382 [details] NPEs in the error log  I picked up a new build, I20100115-1100, and opened my existing 3.6 workspace.  It does a build, and then I got NPEs from API tools in the log.  I've attached the 3 errors, here's the example.  ex: !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 75 2010-01-18 09:34:22.958 !MESSAGE Errors occurred during the build. !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 75 2010-01-18 09:34:22.958 !MESSAGE Errors running builder 'API Analysis Builder' on project 'org.eclipse.ui.workbench'. !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.BundleComponent.createApiDescription(BundleComponent.java:365) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.Component.getApiDescription(Component.java:105) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.comparator.ClassFileComparator.collectAllInterfaces(ClassFileComparator.java:963) ...

title: UI does not allow report of just illegal API use
desc: The API Use report now shows illegal API use. However, the UI enforces the user to select API references and or internal references. It would be useful to be able to run a report for just "illegal use".  I think this is just a UI validation that is not necessary.

title: Versions are truncated in use scan report
desc: For some reason, bundle versions are truncated in the new "Version" column of the API use report.

title: [api tooling] API tooling needs to support fragments
desc: I was testing API tooling setup on SWT and discovered that the setup does not currently support fragments.

title: [use scan] scope not honored in various report scenarios
desc: Using HEAD.  I ran an API use report with the following settings:  Includes API References: true  Includes Internal References: true  Includes Illegal Use: true  Baseline Location: C:\SDK-I20100115\eclipse  Scope Pattern: org\.eclipse\.jface\..*  Reference Pattern: org\.eclipse\.debug\..*  Report Location: c:\temp\jface-scan\xml  API Patterns: None  Internal Patterns: None  Archive Patterns: None  Filter Pattern: None   The report showed *all* API references made by debug.* bundles rather than just those references to jface.*. It also included all references to system library code.

title: Field references are not always resolved to the correct owning member
desc: Created attachment 156877 [details] field resolution  I20100121-0800  When our reference extractor handles field references it does not correctly report references to fields from the class hierarchy- for example setting / getting a field value from a parent class.  I our current state we always consider field get / set instructions to belong to the type that the reference appears in. We should be resolving field get / set to make sure they are talking about the correct field.  The patch provides field resolution for class hierarchies, but I have not tested it to see if it will properly resolve the owning class for a field reference in an inner type where the field comes from the hierarchy of the enclosing type.

title: NPE when compatibility error is on compilation unit
desc: I get the following NPE when a problem marker is to be created for a compilation unit.  In this case, the builder is attempting to find a member to create a problem on, but finds none (the delta is not for a member, code in Util.getIMember(delta, project)), and then the charStart value is 0 (which is > -1), so the builder attempts to find a member in the compilation unit at charStart (0), which is also null.  	IJavaElement element = null; 	if (compilationUnit != null) { 		if(charStart > -1) { 			element = compilationUnit.getElementAt(charStart); 		} else { 			element = compilationUnit; 		} 	} else { 		element = project; 	}  java.lang.NullPointerException     at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiToolBuilder.createMarkerFor(ApiToolBuilder.java:1009)     at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiToolBuilder.processDelta(ApiToolBuilder.java:1287)     at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiToolBuilder.compareProfiles(ApiToolBuilder.java:1233)     at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiToolBuilder.buildAll(ApiToolBuilder.java:406)     at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiToolBuilder.build(ApiToolBuilder.java:316)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633)     at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253)     at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.build(Workspace.java:330)     at org.eclipse.ui.actions.GlobalBuildAction$1.run(GlobalBuildAction.java:180)     at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)

title: non-API supertypes show as leaks even when they don't expose/leak anything
desc: Example:  JavaBreakpointConditionEditor extends non-API type AbstractJavaBreakpointEditor  I think this is a regression - API tools is reporting extension of non-API supertypes as a warning. However, the non-API supertype does not expose any additional methods/fields.

title: ReferenceExtractor is failing to lookup method signatures (caching problem)
desc: I20090707-0800  Running our smoke tests trying to find why our tests fail, I found that in our reference extractor we are trying to look up methods with differing signatures (qualified vs. unqualified).  Example: ReferenceExtractor is trying to look up:  name - m1 signature - ()Linternal/x/y/z/internal;  in API type:  Type : access(33) x.y.z.testMRL2 superclass: java.lang.Object;  Methods :  Method : access(1) ()V <init>; Method : access(2) ()Linternal; m1; Method : access(2) ()Linternal; m2; Method : access(2) ()LIinternal; m3; Method : access(2) ()LIinternal; m4;  The method in question is there, just that it is not correctly qualified.  I get the feeling this is a cache update problem - as I had dragged the type 'internal' from the default package to the 'internal.x.y.z' package

title: Investigate to let external JAR builder run on auto-build
desc: 3.6 M5.  The pde.api.tools project has an external builder to build a JAR (good). If it's not too slow I would also register the auto-build target.  Two reasons for doing that: 1. it will build the JAR automatically for you when you modify the resources 2. the 'Build All' action which gets enabled and made visible in the toolbar due     to the missing auto-build functionality will go away again  On a side note: you probably also want to enable 'Refresh', so that the newly generated JAR automatically appears.

title: IllegalArgumentException visiting type instruction with a type name that is one char
desc: Created attachment 142788 [details] proposed fix  I20090721-1200  The use scanning uncovered a problem in our method visitor when we visit a type instruction in a method. The problem comes from a type instruction where the type description is only one character in size.   Consider the following example:  void method() {   A a = new A(); }  It so happens that in our visitor we end up passing A to Signature.getTypeSignatureKind(..) which throws the IllegalArgumentException since A is not known as a kind in Signature.  The attached patch changes the behavior slightly by trying to ask JDT about the description if its size is 1 character, but falling back to ask ASM if JDT fails to return successfully.

title: [api tools] standardize on 'API' or 'Api' or 'api'
desc: In the code and through the preference pages, I've seen various capitalizations of the 'API' acronym. We should at least standardize this in two fronts:  1) to end users I recommend 'API'  (currently the pref page looks weird with 'Api' https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=89533)  2) in code I recommend 'Api', ie., 'ApiProfile'  Or you can choose one style across everything.

title: TVT35:TCT335: CHS: Duplicate Mnemonic Keys
desc: <response_by> Ma Xiao Long at 2009.07.29.03.53.04 </response_by> NLS Build Label: 20090728-1200 Language: S.Chinese Must-Fix: No  - Steps To Recreate Problem: Start Eclipse From the main menu bar click on Window --> Preferences Click on Plugin Development Click on API Errors /Warnings Make sure that the API Use  is selected Expand General Expand  Restrictions Expand Leaks Under General --> Supported Environments click on the Install them now link  Click on the API Compatibility tab  - Problem Description: We found duplicate mnemonic keys, pls help to check. Thank you!  <response_by> Matthew McClintock at 2009.07.29.12.53.15 </response_by> To recreate this problem:  1)  Select Window -> Preferences from the main menu. 2)  Expand Plug-in Development and select API Errors/Warnings. 3)  Select the API Compatibility tab.  Thank you, Matthew McClintock  <response_by> Matthew McClintock at 2009.07.29.12.53.28 </response_by> This article was reassigned from Category:''TVT/Testing,Inbox''.
