title: Baseline 'workspace' is disposed logged and API tooling wrongly reports missing @since tag problem
desc: Build id: I20090728-1414.  I get this in my log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 123 2009-07-29 17:38:09.613 !MESSAGE Baseline 'workspace' is disposed  and then API tooling wrongly reports missing @since tag problem.  Steps to reproduce: 1. start new workspace 2. check out 'org.eclipse.ui.workbench' from CVS    ==> no error reported (good) 3. set API tooling baseline to R3.5 named 'a'    ==> no error reported (good) 4. clean all (which triggers rebuild) ==> "Baseline 'workspace' is disposed" gets logged ==> wrong error problem about missing @since tag.  Marking as 'major' as I see an error in my workspace which shouldn't be there and I get "Baseline 'workspace' is disposed" in my log without any clue what the consequences are (e.g. is API tooling now busted? does a restart fix it?).

title: API tools should tolerate bad classfiles
desc: I20090809-2000  Using our use scanning tooling to scan some third party bundles I encountered a case where we try to scan a classfile that is bogus - in my example it was a classfile that had no class definition in it. The net effect was a pile of NPEs and ClassFormatExceptions.  We should just skip bad classfiles.

title: Adding a constant to an API interface then removing causes incorrect @since error
desc: Build id: I20090818-0800  Steps to recreate  - Have a baseline setup for 3.5.0 - Check a bundle out from R3_5 tag that contains a interface that is API - Add a constant to the interface - You correctly get an error/warning about missing @since tag - Perform the quick fix to get rid of the error/warning - Replace the local copy of the interface with the content from R3_5 - Notice that an error/warning shows up against the interface about missing @since tag.  Clean and rebuild the project does not help.  You must restart and then do a clean build of the project.

title: UseScanParser should parse out IReferenceDescriptors
desc: code from HEAD  with the addition of the descriptor IReferenceDescriptor our UseScanParser / UseScanVisitor should be updated to use this descriptor rather than passing a collection of data into the visitReference(..) method.  public void visitReference(int refKind, int refFlags, IMemberDescriptor fromMember, int lineNumber, int visibility)  should be:  public void visitReference(IReferenceDescriptor reference)  This will also allow extensibility if someone wants to create their own parser and visit a specialized IReferenceDescriptor.

title: Update API use Ant task to match the new searching story
desc: I20090818-0800  FUP to bug 280467.  With the new search story for API use searching we need to update the corresponding Ant tasks accordingly.

title: API builder throws error when deleting a project
desc: I20100217-1031 (broken since R3.5).  1. check out 'org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring' from HEAD    (any other project with enabled API tooling should do the trick too) 2. wait until build is done 3. delete the project including files on disk ==> boom! error dialog appears and error logged.   Boy, this was hard to figure out because the API builder returns status messages it gets instead of wrapping them with the correct context, see bug 303285.

title: Cheese in the progress view
desc: I20090818-0800  While waiting for a full build I noticed that in the progress view the current job info said "Checking @since tags..." followed by the info from the Java builder.

title: Provide summary of missing required bundles
desc: I20090818-0800  With the new details provided for why bundles have not been searched (for use reporting), it would be nice if there was an additional page listing all of the bundles required for a complete search.  This information is available on the details page, but it is quite annoying to have to check the details for every single skipped bundle when a nice summary page could tell you what bundles are missing in a simple list.

title: Add "change" to setup for project nature addition
desc: There should be a visible change in the setup for the API tooling nature addition to each project. This way, projects with no component.xml will still show that they will have changes applied.  Ideally, the change would not be able to be disabled (but not sure that is possible).

title: Filtering using patterns in api usage report seems to be too aggressive
desc: I tried to filter references to mylyn bundles inside mylyn api scan results so that I don't get references to mylyn from mylyn using the pattern: org\.eclipse\.mylyn\..*  and it ended up filtering all bundles. The result is empty where before I had multiple usage scan results outside of mylyn bundles.

title: API use scan UI should make a default selection of what to analyze
desc: I20090825-1032  When you create a new use scan configuration, there is no default selected in the Analyze section. Once you make a selection pressing the revert button (which becomes enabled) does nothing.

title: Save cycle causes out of sync resources
desc: currently for persisting api filters, we are using a java.io.File to do saving. This has the net effect of causing out of sync errors in the workspace as no notification is sent to indicate that the underlying file has been changed.  We should be using IFile and IFile.setContents(..)

title: API use XML could be a bit smaller
desc: I20090825-1032  Darin found that some of our API use XML output could shrunk a bit by removing some duplication of 'referee' information.

title: Log entry each time I delete a *.java file
desc: I20100224-2242 - works fine in 3.6 M5.  Each time I delete *.java file I get a log entry from org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.cleanupUnsupportedTagMarkers(IResource)   Test Case: 1. check out 'org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring' from HEAD    (any other project with enabled API tooling should do the trick too) 2. wait until build is done 3. delete a *.java file ==> log entry

title: Remove tag extension point
desc: Moving closer to M6 we need to remove the javadoc tag extension.   In its current state the extension only allows an alias for a tag we define to be contributed (not terribly useful). The framework for handling the extension should remain in the event we provide extensible tags again.

title: Html report could not be generated from ui.views api changes
desc: I20090901-0800  Using the "Compare with API baseline" for the ui.views bundle, I could not generate the HTML report once the comparison was complete.

title: Missing @since tags for split plug-ins repeatedly reported on the MANIFEST.MF
desc: I20090915-0100  Strange things happen when I add API to a class in a plug-in that has been extracted from a depending plug-in.  Concretely, I have org.eclipse.jdt.junit.core from HEAD in my workspace and 3.5 set as API baseline. Now when I add a method to org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestRunListener, I would expect an error on the method if its Javadoc doesn't declare @since 3.6.  But in my main workspace, I get an error on the MANIFEST.MF:  Missing @since tag on org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestRunListener.sessionLaunched(ITestRunSession)	MANIFEST.MF	/org.eclipse.jdt.junit/META-INF	@since tag problem	line 2  Each time I save the CU, another error marker is added.  When I tried to reproduce in a fresh workspace, I go no error at all when I only checked out org.eclipse.jdt.junit.core. When I added org.eclipse.jdt.junit, it started to behave the same as in my main workspace.  In 3.5, there was only org.eclipse.jdt.junit. In HEAD, org.eclipse.jdt.junit.core has been added. The latter is required and re-exported by the org.eclipse.jdt.junit plug-in, and some APIs have been moved to the core plug-in.

title: Improve wording of EE related messages
desc: I noticed this in my workspace...  The method Boolean.parseBoolean(String) referenced in   org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.search.dialogs.FilteredIUSelectionDialog.IUWrapperLabelProvider.getImage(Object) is not   defined in bundle's required execution environment: J2SE-1.4  Are we missing a "the" there? in THE bundle's required...

title: [use scan] show everything about a package/type at once
desc: Pascal commented that he would like to be able to look at an API use scan to see everything about how a package and its types are used all at once... rather than having to see it by consumer, etc.

title: Entries in .api_filters should also be sorted by arguments
desc: I20100302-0800  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #269163 +++ [..] To keep the file as stable as possible, you should sort by <resource>'s "path" and "type", and inside by the <filter>'s "id".   Looks like that's still not enough. You should also sort by the message arguments' values. See e.g. /org.eclipse.jface/.settings/.api_filters.

title: Issues with quickfix for adding @noreference tag
desc: The quickfix for adding a @noreference tag when an API-method leaks a non-API type (see bug 229824) is not very useful currently.  (1) It doesn't silence the warning for which it is offered.     Additionally a @nooverride tag is needed (see bug 229824 comment 6).  (2) Since one tag doesn't silence the warning the quickfix can be applied     any number of times -> creating any number of identical tags.  Easiest solution would be to add both tags by one quickfix if that's not too inconsistent with other quickfixes (I can't think of another quickfix that performs two actions in one).  A weaker solution would be to offer two quickfixes, one for each tag. In that case each quickfix should additionally check whether it has been applied before .. do you see why I consider the other solution as simpler?

title: Error message for bad regular expression should be improved
desc: The messages displayed in the launch dialog for a bad regex need to be improved, as they talk about a text field of the wrong name:  /org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui/src/org/eclipse/pde/api/tools/ui/internal/use/messages.properties  ApiUseScanTab_regex_problem_search_for=Search For regular expression problem: {0} ApiUseScanTab_regex_problem_search_in=Search In regular expression problem: {0}  should be merged into something better like:  #{0} is the invalid regular expression the user entered The regular expression is not valid: {0}

title: Report the list of the bundles that contain references
desc: It would be good if on the first page of the report, there was a link to a list of all the bundles where references had been found. This would allow for a quick identification of the interesting plug-ins. In my case this is of interest so I could easily load the code of these plug-ins and look at their code.

title: unused loal var compiler warning in N20080225-0010
desc: 1. WARNING in /src/org/eclipse/pde/api/tools/internal/ApiProblemFilter.java  (at line 91) IApiProblemFilter filter = (IApiProblemFilter) o; The local variable filter is never read

title: Incorrect errors that API exception filters are unnecessary when code is changed
desc: I20100225-1936  To reproduce:  In o.e.ui.navigator StructuredViewerManager in HEAD, add a println somewhere.  You will get this error:  The API problem filter for: 'StructuredViewerAccess illegally references method StructuredViewerInternals.setAssociateListener(StructuredViewer, StructuredViewerInternalsAssociateListener)' is no longer used  It seems to happen whenever classes that have these filters are changed.

title: [api tooling] check for new apis after a build freeze
desc: The api tooling builder should be able to diagnose new apis added after an API freeze. If we use 3.4M6 as the baseline, we should be able to detect all new APIs. This should be investigated as a use case for 3.4.

title: ApiDescriptionXmlCreator NPE in test suite
desc: There have been a handleful of times now that we have seen this NPE crop up. In the I20100305-1011 build for example. title: Add summary metadata to the index page of a use / migration scan
desc: I20091006-0800  When a use or migration scan is done, there is no simple way to tell what the scans were done against - for example that a use scan was done against an Eclipse 3.4 baseline. It would be extremely useful to have a summary or some kind of metadata on the index page of the scan that outlines some (all) of the information from the scan like:  1. baselines used 2. locations 3. scan parameter(s) 4. date of the scan  for example.

title: [api tooling] Increment minor/major version error should have a detailed message
desc: When we report an error about incrementing the minor or major version of a bundle, we should provide a list of the new APIs. This would help the user to know why the bundle version should be modified. This could be done inside the quickfix action.

title: In API usage report, more details should be provided for illegal usage
desc: Trying to run api usage report on STAN IDE bundles, I found it quite difficult to know exactly what is wrong with report ILLEGAL_API usage.  The report doesn't give much details for: org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.IPropertySheetPage.  It only reports two ILLEGAL_API. With the context, we can guess this is because some types are implementing org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.IPropertySheetPage which has a superinterface with restrictions (IPage).

title: Allow nested archives to be filtered from a use scan
desc: Created attachment 150265 [details] fix  I20091020-0931  It would be good to have the ability to filter select nested archives from a given bundle during an API use scan. This would allow reused / compatibility code made available in a bundle (and on the bundle classpath) to not show up during a scan.  Arguably, one could say that they should not appear on the bundle class path, but if they do this could be used to prune reported usage for those bundles.  The attached patch updates the apitooling.apiuse Ant task to accept a comma separated listing of archive identifiers to ignore, as well the external tools UI has been updated with a new wizard to help create patterns

title: namespace problems with api profiles
desc: Api profiles are handled based on their name (id). It is possible with the current tooling to give more than one profile the same name. Under the covers only one will ever exist with the duplicated name, but in terms of the UI it can be confusing.  Steps:  1. open the api profiles pref page and add a new profile called 'Eclipse' 2. add another profile with the name 'Eclipse' (notice 2 profiles in the viewer with the same name) 3. press 'ok' to close the pref dialog, and reopen it 4. notice that only one of the 'Eclipse' profiles remains.  Expected:  that a name (id) collision would be detected and flagged as an error (or something), to force me to change it.  We could add something as simple as a flat namespace for profiles, and provide a suggested default name (similar to the launch dialog)

title: Filters for api usage report should specify on what they are applied
desc: The filters defined inside the api usage launching configuration are applied on package names and not bundle names. It would be good if this could clearly be stated in the corresponding UI.

title: Unusable options should not be enabled on Use Scan tab
desc: I20100307-2000  If you select the Analyze option to only generate HTML reports the options to clear the report location and the description should be disabled, as they have no effect during report-only creation.

title: DBCS3.6: NL Characters in the API Use Report are displayed as question mark "?".
desc: Build Identifier: I20100313-1044  Non US ASCII characters are displayed as question mark "?" when US ASCII characters are used in API Use report configuration. For instance, non US characters in the directory name for Report Output Location, and Description, the characters are corrupted. Instead, the characters are displayed as question mark "?".   Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: Steps to recreate problem: 1. Run > External Tools > External Tool Configurations. 2. Double click "API Use Report" in the left pane. 3. Click "Baselines" button in the New_configration. 4. Click "Add Baseline" button.  5. Enter NL characters in the name field.  6. Click "Reset" button, and click "Finish" button. 7. Click "OK" button. 8. Select the API baseline created in the API baseline field. 9  Enter a directory name including NL characters in the report output location. 10. Enter org\.eclipse\.debug\..* in the Reference to: field, and enter org\.eclipse\.jdt\..* in the Bundles matching: field. 11. Check "Internal references", "Clean report directory before... ", "Create HTML reports", "Clean HTML report location", and "Open report when search completes" 12. Enter NL characters in the "Description" 13. Run the API tools. (Run> External Tools > Select configuration name e.g., New configuration) 14. The report appears in the workbench but all NL characters are corrupted.  15. Browse the html files in the report created.  16. The charset in the html file is hard coded as ISO-8859-1.   Expected output: All NL character should be displayed. The charset in the html files should be the default charset.

title: Provide ability to filter during API use scan report generation
desc: I20091110-0800  When we are generating HTML reports it would be very handy to be able to filter the kinds of things shown in the resulting report. For example, support for a simple list of regular expressions that could be supplied to the Ant task to prune generated infos.

title: Failure to write meta-data should not prevent index page from being written
desc: Created attachment 164584 [details] fix  found diagnosing bug 308885, using I20100406-1034.  If any exception occurs while trying to write the meta-data section of the index page, the entire page is not written. We should trap an exception from trying to write the meta section and continue on writing the rest of the index page.

title: API builder fails to build dependent types
desc: I20091124-0800  Performing a dependent type smoke test between Ant and Debug I found that not all dependent types are being built during an incremental build.  Steps  1. get debug.core and ant.launching from HEAD 2. open Launch and AntLaunch 3. add an @noextend tag to Launch 4. save  Expected An API tools warning would appear on AntLaunch  Happens NOTHING!  Confirmed on Linux and Windows

title: Setting / removing API baseline makes .settings/.api_filters dirty
desc: N20100418-2000  Setting / removing an API baseline makes .settings/.api_filters dirty. This causes a lot of unnecessary outgoing changes.  Steps: Check out org.eclipse.compare and then set the API baseline to 3.5.

title: Investigate using the PDE state for our workspace baseline
desc: Currently API tools creates and manages its own OSGi state for our workspace baseline. This effort is basically cloning the work PDE already does. We should investigate using the PDE state for our workspace baseline to avoid all the state management work altogether.   We can also reap benefits from:   1. not having to include the entire target platform in the workspace baseline 2. we can better compute the complete dependency trees for bundles in the workspace baseline

title: Unused filter problems should not be filterable
desc: I20100414-1200  Using the quick-fix to add problem filters can create a problem filter for an unused problem filter problem  Steps: 1. create a Java class that has an unused filter problem and at least one other kind of API problem 2. activate the quick-fix for a non-unused filter problem 3. select all of the problems to apply the filters to (should be selected be default) 4. hit ok  Happens:  You get a problem filter for the unused filter problem  Expected:  You get problems filter(s) for all problems *except* for the unused filter problem  when this happens it adds an immense amount of confusion as you will immediately get another unused filter problem for the filter you just created, if you then use the quick-fix on that one to remove it you immediately get another problem for the original unused filter.

title: workspace profile loaded when it doesn't need to be
desc: On our first version of a workspace profile, we load it the very first time the profile manager was instantiated to make sure we caught all updates of interest from the workspace.   With the 'next gen' of workspace profiles we no longer need to do this, which can allow the api profile manager to be a little bit more lazy. This will have a dramatic effect for operations that query the profile manager the first time after it has been instantiated, but do not ask about the workspace profile.  For example: when you run the setup wizard once the workbench has started (and have not done anything else), the workspace profile is force loaded when we try to notify about a default api profile being set. Profiling or the mentioned example has shown that on average 5100 ms is spent loading the workspace profile just to ask if there is a default api profile set (considering the two notions are disjoint).

title: Folder type container has poor performance
desc: Created attachment 153580 [details] complete thread dump  I20091201-1600  My dev workspace was completely compiled. I accepted several incoming changes, one of which caused a compile error (org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.preferences.ComplianceConfigurationBlock can't resolve import BundleDefaultsScope).  The incremental build took very long. After a while, I took a thread dump and started tracing, which confirmed that most of the time was burned in FolderApiTypeContainer.collectPackageNames(..). I didn't see disk activity, just one CPU core at 100%.  I could not reproduce by reverting and restoring ComplianceConfigurationBlock, so the compile error may not be the actual problem. title: Cannot enter Report Conversion Patterns on API Use Report External Tool Launch
desc: Build ID: I20100608-0911 (3.6rc4a)    1. Create an External Tool Launch for an API Use Report 2. Switch to the "Patterns" tab 3. Press "Add..." 4. Pick "Report Conversion Pattern", Next 5. Enter any Pattern, Finish  --> On the Launch Config dialog, the "Apply" button is not enabled --> When switching to the "API Use Report" tab and back, the new pattern is gone --> When choosing "Run", the new pattern is gone  It looks like the lack of a defined "Kind" for the report conversion pattern might be causing the problem that it cannot be saved.  I once got an NPE logged while playing with API Tooling, but it's likely not related to this issue:  java.lang.NullPointerException at title: API Use Report provides no Common tab
desc: Build ID: I20100608-0911 (3.6rc4a)  I used File > Export > Run/Debug > Launch Configurations in order to export my API Tools Report setup and share it with others in the team. Since the exported Launch is in my Workspace, I now have 2 identical copies of my API Use Report.  It looks like the "Common" tab which is used to show private vs. shared Launch Configurations is missing from the API Usage Report LaunchTabGroup.

title: Consistently use "API Tools" (not "API Tooling")
desc: 3.6.  We should consistently use "API Tools" (not "API Tooling"). Especially in the documentation.

title: Baseline wizard does not indicate what it is doing
desc: I20101123-0800  When you go to create a new API baseline the wizard reports progress correctly, but it no longer says what it is doing - just progress with no message any more.

title: listen for changes to .api_filters
desc: For a team sharing scenario, we don't properly update API problem filters. For example, developer 1 updates and releases API filters. Developer 2, synchs and brings in the new filter file. However, the filters are not updated in response to the file change.  In fact, developer 2 may end up deleting the incoming file when his workspace is saved (if he has no filters).

title: Use scan preference page does not validate archives
desc: code from HEAD  The new Use scan preference page allows you to select an archive that contains a use scan, which is pretty cool, but currently you can select *any* archive, and no validation is done on it to see if it actually has a use scan in it.  When the build runs with an archive that does not contain a use scan you get this handsome exception:  java.lang.Exception: The directory that contains xml reports must be specified at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.search.UseScanParser.parse(UseScanParser.java:230) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.search.UseScanManager.fetch(UseScanManager.java:181) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:54)  The longer the build went the more of these exceptions I got. I am assuming I get one per project that got built (before I cancelled the build).

title: Polish Use Scan Feature
desc: I had no performance issues in my tests.  I haven't tried with an overly large (100+ project workspace) yet.  Issues:  1) I think we should revisit the pref page name.  The current one is long (doesn't fit in the default sized dialog), not very clear and does not start with 'API' like the other API tooling pages.  My suggestions would be: "API Use Dependencies" "API Dependency Scans" "API Use Scans" Make the API tooling pages have their own branch in the pref tree)  We originally moved away from using 'use scans' as it is not a user friendly term.  However, only users that are familiar with use scans will ever have a use for this tool.  2) Problem category should match up exactly with the preference page name.  We need to use a consistent name, otherwise users won't understand where the problems are coming from.  3) The problems should be associated with the type name if it can be calculated so they show up in the editor.  4) Preference page should have a link to the error level page.  5) Error levels should not be ignore by default.  Currently the user sets up the scan on the preference page, it asks you if you want to build and you say "great, go for it".  No errors are reported, which is perfect until you realize that there are no errors being reported period.  6) Is there any value to letting the user change the cache size?  As a user I have know idea what a reasonable value it and whether it would be beneficial for me to change it.  No need to give the user an advanced option unless there is a definite need by some users.  7) The text at the top of the page needs a bit of work.  It shouldn't say *the* api use scan problems.  Second sentence should perhaps read "The dependencies found in the use scans will be compared against workspace projects to ensure they still exist."  8) Edit locations button should be removed, it adds no real value.  9) There is no help doc for the page, we should file a bug to remind us to write doc in M6.

title: api filters file should be written immediately when changes are made
desc: Currently wen you add or remove an api filter, the changes are persisted to disk on the next workench save cycle. This works ok, but will cause problems once the filter are shared via SCM. It can happen that you have made changes to your filters, accept incoming changes to the file, then the save cycle over-writes the file.

title: polish progress messages for API builder
desc: We should review/polish the progress messages displayed by our builder.  "Full API build: analying API use" does not give a good sense of progress :-)

title: Edit button is the new delete button
desc: code from HEAD  Steps:  1. add an location on the API use scans page 2. edit the location 3. do not change the location in any way, press OK on the file dialog 4. watch as your location is deleted.

title: Wrong unused api filters warning are reported
desc: Using I20091201-1600,  1) check out JDT/Core from HEAD  2) set incremental compilation on 3) Do a full build of JDT/Core 4) Open org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTParser 5) Add a space and save 6) You get a warning saying that The API problem filter for: 'Invalid @since tag '3.5.2' on IGNORE_METHOD_BODIES; expecting two fragments' is no longer used ICompilationUnit.java /org.eclipse.jdt.core/model/org/eclipse/jdt/core line 36 Unused API Problem Filter Problem 7) Do a full build and the problem is gone  It looks like all api filters are being checked on incremental build. Not just the ones from recompiled types.

title: Remove use of the word "profile" to mean baseline
desc: Created attachment 153733 [details] fix  There are several places in our code where we still refer to an API baseline as an API profile. There are even a few builder messages - NLS'd and visible to users - that do this.

title: Warning/Error for missing API Tools EE description
desc: N20110109-2000  Set the option "Preferences > API Errors/Warnings > API Use > General > Invalid references to system libraries" to Warning or Error.  => When no environment descriptions are installed and a project would need the descriptions in order to flag bad references (because there's no strictly compatible JRE for the execution environment available), then API Tools should show a warning/error on the project.  Background: Currently, some of our projects have the option "Preferences > Java Compiler > Building > No strictly compatible JRE for execution environment found" set to Error to make sure nobody accidentally writes new code against a newer JRE than allowed.  This was OK as long as older JREs were still available, but nowadays, it's difficult (or e.g. on the Mac even impossible) to get a 1.4 JRE install to compile against. We should eventually set the JDT/Core option to Ignore and rely on the API Tools option, but we currently can't do that because the environment descriptions are not installed by default and the API Tools compiler silently skips that problem.  An alternative to this solution would be to make it easier to add a dummy EE install for every EE. In the rt CVS repository, /org.eclipse.osgi/osgi/ contains dummy *.ee files for the OSGI-Minimum and CDC/Foundation-1.1 environments, but similar files are not available for other EEs (e.g. J2SE-1.4).

title: Searching only for illegal API Use throws exception
desc: Build Identifier: 3.7M4  When searching only for illegal API with the following attributes set: considerapi="false" considerinternal="false" considerillegaluse="true"   This exception is thrown by the API Use Ant Task: Exception: "Build stopping - neither API nor internal references are being searched for at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.tasks.ApiUseTask.assertParameters(ApiUseTask.java:265)"    Reproducible: Always

title: UseReportConverter prints out reference plus value(s) for "API patterns"
desc: Build Identifier: 3.7M4  To reproduce: 1. Run the API Use Ant Task with attribute:   apipatterns=".*"  2. Convert the XML report to HTML using the API Use Report Conversion Ant Task. The resulting HTML will report the used API patterns as :  API Patterns: 	[Ljava.lang.String;@b524aa.*  I looked at the code and the problem appears to be in class UseReportConverter, where the API patterns string array is appended directly:  String[] patterns = this.metadata.getApiPatterns(); if(patterns != null) { 	buffer.append(this.metadata.getApiPatterns()); 	for (int i = 0; i < patterns.length; i++) { 		buffer.append(patterns[i]).append(BR); 	} }  Reproducible: Always

title: Consumer Based API Use Report
desc: API Use Reports are currently producer based - i.e. given a bundle, the report details how all the other bundles use and abuse that bundle. This request is to produce a report from the other point of view - i.e. given a bundle, the report details all the API and internals it is using from other bundles.

title: Create Profile: forced to use highest execution environment
desc: I20080226-1155.  To begin with: I don't know when/how API tooling is using the execution environment given in the profile.  When creating a profile the execution environment must be at least as high as the highest from all plug-ins. This seems wrong as the source plug-ins I work on must depend on 1.4. Hence I should be able to set 1.4 EE in my profile. Or am I wrong? Does the EE not matter? If so, why do I have to spec it?  Also, if this is intended, then the drop down should be adjusted to only contain the valid values.

desc: I got this error trying to edit an existing profile  Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiProfile.addApiComponents(ApiProfile.java:341) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.wizards.ApiProfileWizardPage$WorkingCopyOperation.run(ApiProfileWizardPage.java:235) 	at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext.runInCurrentThread(ModalContext.java:407) 	... 49 more   STEPS TO REPRODUCE: 1) Create a new profile pointing to the 3.3.0 eclipse install. 2) Close the preference page 3) Go to the profile page and click the edit button. title: API profiles pref page polish
desc: A few things we could polish around api profiles:  1. remove the refresh button from the wizard page (since you cannot remove anything from the viewer you don't need to refresh it).  2. move the missing api profile pref to its own tab on the errors /warnings page (as we will have more options for api profiles, like unresolved bundles etc. to report)  3. remove the group from the api profile pref page and add a spacer between the message to the 'Profiles:' text (vertical space between the two)

title: [api tooling] Failures in N20080310-0010
desc: Failures in: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.util.tests.ApiDescriptionProcessorTests.testProcessMethodAdditionNoDocElement org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.util.tests.ApiDescriptionProcessorTests.testProcessMethodAddition org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.util.tests.ApiDescriptionProcessorTests.testProcessInnerMethodAddition

title: API Tools builder doesn't detect classpath changes
desc: Fup of bug 336632, the API Tools builder doesn't force a full build when org.apache.ant is replaced with a newer version. apt.core project has this project on its classpath and should therefore be rebuilt if org.apache.ant is replaced with a newer version. This happens in AUTO_BUILD mode where the Java builder detects the classpath change and does a full build of apt.core. The API Tools builder doesn't see the classpath change and as there is no other changes, it doesn't rebuild the apt.core project. This is causing some problems not to be removed. See bug 336632 comment 7.

title: UI glitches on 'API Use Report' launch configuration page
desc: 3.7 M7.  - mnemonic clashes for 'n', 'c', 'y' (BAD as it hides Apply) - labels in sentence style (e.g. "Report Output Location", "Report Type")

title: [api tooling] Deleted compile-time constant interface field not flagged as a problem
desc: When going from TM-RSE version 2.0 to 3.0, we renamed a compile-time constant field of an interface (which can be seen as Delete API Field Constant + Add API Field Constant). API Tools flags the new field as "missing @since" but it should really flag the deleted constant as breaking API Change.  At least if I'm reading the API Guide right: http://wiki.eclipse.org/Evolving_Java-based_APIs_2#Evolving_API_Interfaces says that "Delete API Field ... Breaks compatibility".  Personally I'm not 100% sure if this is actually true, since the API Guide  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Evolving_Java-based_APIs_2#Evolving_API_interfaces_-_API_fields also says in annotation "(2) Java compilers always inline the value of constant fields" so deleting a constant field from an API interface would not break binary compatibility. It definitely breaks source compatibility, but we usually dont care about that; It might also break contract compatibility, if the client expects a particular behavior from setting the constant; but even that is not necessarily the case when the constant is just renamed.  So perhaps this bug is INVALID, API Tooling does the right job and the API Guide needs to be updated to talk about interface field constants specifically in  http://wiki.eclipse.org/Evolving_Java-based_APIs_2#Evolving_API_Interfaces  Anyways, here is the concrete example in code:  Version 2.0: interface IHostSearchConstants {     public static final int CANCELLED = 2; }  Version 3.0: interface IHostSearchConstants {     public static final int CANCELED = 2; }  CANCELLED was renamed to CANCELED, and API Tools flags the new name as "missing @since tag" which is not really correct in this case. Perhaps the API Tools should support an "@renamed" annotation in Javadoc to handle this case?

title: Progress message during build
desc: When there are API errors, the progress message in the Progress View ends up prefixed with "Creating problem marker on: .....{resource name}...". The message never gets cleaned up.  We should likely just remove the progress message.

title: Restore Defaults doesn't swich two options in API Errors preferences
desc: Build id: I20091207-1800  In API Errors/Warnings > API Compatibility > Bundle two last options are not switched by Set All As/Restore Defaults buttons.

title: Filters show outgoing change but did not modify them
desc: I loaded PDE UI from HEAD and found that I immediately had an outgoing change in the .api_filters file. I did not make any changes to the file, but there are whitespace differences. My workspace has indendation, while the CVS file does not (which can be caused by using different JREs/XML implementations).\  My file:  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <component id="org.eclipse.pde.ui" version="1">     <resource path="src/org/eclipse/pde/ui/launcher/IPDELauncherConstants.java">         <filter id="134742272" messageargs=""/>     </resource> </component>   CVS file:  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <component id="org.eclipse.pde.ui" version="1"> <resource path="src/org/eclipse/pde/ui/launcher/IPDELauncherConstants.java"> <filter id="134742272" messageargs=""/> </resource> </component>

title: Clean up EE description fragments
desc: 3.7.  The Eclipse project update site (http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/updates/3.7) lists the JRE execution environment descriptions. There are some issues with them:  1. "PDE/API Tools Environment Descriptions" EE description. The details section says it is for JRE-1.1 but below there is already: "PDE/API Tools Environment Descriptions JRE 11" ==> "PDE/API Tools Environment Descriptions" entry needs to be removed or fixed.  2. Use a better name: those are not API Tools Environment descriptions but    JRE Execution Environment descriptions.  3. Don't use plural: each of the entries is one description.  4. Use the correct EE names as listed on the 'Execution Environments'     preference page (e.g. "JavaSE-1.6" instead of "J2SE 16").       For example: "PDE/API Tools JRE EE Description for 'J2SE-1.6' or: "PDE's JRE EE Description for 'J2SE-1.6'

title: Clean up 'API Errors/Warnings' preference page
desc: 3.7.  The 'API Errors/Warnings' preference page has several issues:  1. The naming is confusing:    - the group label talks about "environments"    - the first sentence talks about "execution descriptions"    - and then it talks about additional "environment descriptions"    ==> those are executions environments   2. It says "Additional are available" even if I already installed all of    them.    ==> Either we know when all are  installed or we use another label, e.g.:    "<Install additional execution environments>. I would make that as a link.  3. After clicking the 'install them now' link, the user is lost. He has no    clue which site to choose and what to select.    ==> Best would be if we can feed the site plus pre-select the correct IUs.        If that's not possible, we need to give more hints on the preference        page itself.  4. The F1 help should have a link to    http://wiki.eclipse.org/Execution_Environments

title: Duplicate error for missing API baseline
desc: I20080325-0100  Somehow I ended up with duplicate errors in each API tooling enabled project in my workspace - missing default API profile. I had auto-build off and had triggered two full builds: the first build was an entire workspace clean/build; the second build was triggered by changing the compiler's default compliance setting.  As well, I see that the problem "Type" has "Api" rather than "API".   Will attach screenshot.

title: Do not allow users to filter missing EE description problems
desc: Created attachment 201103 [details] fix  FUP to bug 333866 - we should not be providing the 'create problem filter...' quick-fix for the missing EE description problems.  The attached patch prevents the filter quick-fix from being presented and also provides a quick-fix to directly install the EE descriptions.

title: [api tooling] Removing all profiles doesn't trigger a rebuild
desc: Removing all profile including the default baseline doesn't trigger a full build. All existing markers (including errors) are left behind.

title: API Errors/Warnings severity fishy
desc: N20110810-2000.  Something is fishy when determining the severity of an API Errors/Warnings problem.  1. start new workspace 2. set 'Missing execution environment descriptions' to 'Warning' 3. checkout 'org.eclipse.ui.navigator' from HEAD ==> WRONG: error after build due to missing EE description 4. open the 'API Errors/Warnings' property page for the project ==> OK: the page  indicates that the problem should be reported as warning

title: Incremental build produces an additional missing EE description marker for each build
desc: Version: 3.8.0 Build id: I20110823-0925  Steps 1. new workspace 2. remove all EE descriptions you have installed 3. check out org.eclipse.ui.navigator 4. wait for a build you get an error marker for no ee descriptions (OK) 5. edit any file in ui.navigator and save - you get another error marker for no ee descriptions (BAD)

title: Message from an aborted build needs to be more fine grained
desc: 3.6M4 (FUP to bug 297096)  With the new support to abort a build when a fatal JDT error is detected, we need to more finely tailor the message we report based on what fatal errors we found. Right now we broadly look at model failures on the project, but we should be checking the markers we found to report differing reasons i.e. it would be more clear to the user why we aborted our build.  Also we should make a separate problem category for these build-abort problems, as they are now piggy-backed on the API component resolution category which can be ignored - and we should never be able to ignore a build-abort problem.

title: Many tests are not Java 7 friendly
desc: Version: 3.8.0 Build id: I20111005-0925  code from master.  While running a bunch of tests using Java 7 I was getting some odd and inconsistent failures. One was an NPE in ClassFileScannerTests#testScanInnerStaticInnerClass() - caused because the test relies on an earlier test to set up the environment.  We should do a full pass of the test suite to find other tests that could fail in the same manner.

title: Removed constructor reported as breaking change for @noextend @noinstantiate class
desc: I have an abstract class that is marked as @noextend, but the tooling reports the removal of a constructor as a breaking API change.

title: Checked count on setup wizard has white background on Linux
desc: Created attachment 188002 [details] screenshot  Version: 3.7.0 Build id: I20110127-2034  The background colour for the label about the number of checked elements in the API Tools set up wizard has a white background on Linux.

title: Bundle versioning scheme should be based on problem filtering and project preferences
desc: When the user decides that he/she wants to ignore a certain "compatibility" error, we should not propose a new bundle version that still consider this error. Right now if the user renames a static field and decides this is fine as the field is a static field with a compile-time constant and therefore cannot break existing clients (binary compatible). It might be possible to break existing clients, but the user decides that this worths the risk. So we should propose a new version as if the plugin only contains new APIs (micro + 1) and no API breakage (major + 1).

title: [1.8] Adopt Java 8 in API Tools
desc: API Tools needs to switch to the new JLS8 AST and adjust the tooling for new language features like default methods.

title: NPE during API usage scanning

title: API leak detection does not respect @noreference for public field
desc: if we have a field in an API class the leaks an inner type (via the field type) it should not be reported as an error if I have a noreference tag on it.  Consider the following example:  1. Create a plugin project P with two packages a and a.internal and API tooling set up 2. Create two classes a.Clazz and a.internal.InnerClazz 3. add a field to Clazz that is of the type a.internal.InnerClazz and has a @noreference tag on it 4. Set up the manifest to have package a exported and package a.internal as internal 5. build the project  Expected:  I get no error that Clazz leaks InnerClazz  Happens:  I do get the error saying Clazz leaks InnerClazz

title: [1.8] Support default methods
desc: We need to support the following for default methods:  1. Illegal use 2. binary compare 3. tag / annotation validation 4. completion proposals  Testing so far (using ASM 3.3):  1. illegal use is working out of the box 2. tag / annotation validation is working, but has to be updated to support the @nooverride tag on a default method 4. has to be updated like (2) above - when a default method is defined it can now take the @nooverride tag / annotation 5. binary compare fails completely (see bug 427493)

title: [1.8] Support type annotations
desc: There really isn't any special support to provide in API tools for type annotations we just have to test that having them in code / classfiles does not break the builder or comparator.   Some test coverage would be good here as well.

title: 67 pde.api.tools.tests errors in junit tests
desc: See http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/N20140329-1500/testResults.php  I debugged into it and found out the violation of @noreference on a method is not reported.   Further on, I saw that  type.extractReferences(fAllReferenceKinds, null);  doesn't extract all the methods with the new ASM ( 28th March ASM). 11th March ASM (org.objectweb.asm) extracts all the method with the same set of arguments.

title: leaking types: don't warn when API is non referencable
desc: 20080401  in the following code /**  * @noextend This class is not intended to be subclassed by clients.  */ public class OverrideIndicatorLabelDecorator {   /**    * Note: This constructor is for internal use only. Clients should    * not call this constructor.    * @param registry The registry to use.    *     * @noreference This constructor is not intended to be referenced by clients.    */    public OverrideIndicatorLabelDecorator(ImageDescriptorRegistry registry) {     fRegistry= registry;    }   .... }  ImageDescriptorRegistry is an internal type. The API tooling builder warns that the class is leaking an internal type.  As the constructor is not referencable (and the class not subclassable), this should not be a problem.

title: 2 Unit test failures after moving back to "JRE 1.7"
desc: Assumed you noticed, but I didn't see a bug open, so thought I should in case you haven't noticed ...   When I changed the Windows JRE bat to 1.7, there are two unit test failures that appear related to the difference of running tests with 1.8 vs. 1.7.   Such as see  http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20140428-2000/testresults/html/org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.tests_win32.win32.x86_7.0.html  If these are merely related to "VM used" ... I'm not sure need to be fixed for M7 (unless easy to do) but perhaps should be disabled until they can be fixed for 1.7?)

title: Replace usage of System.getProperty("file.separator") in PDE
desc: The usage of System.getProperty("file.separator") can be replaced by File.seperatorChar / File.seperator

title: Memory leak due to requesting delta but never using it
desc: PDE API tools adds a save participant in the ApiPlugin class. In this participant you invoke ISaveContext#needDelta, which causes the resources plugin to record the workspace tree state from the save point to supply you with a delta when your bundle next starts up. However, when you startup, you never process the resource delta, which causes the workspace to retain that delta indefinitely. This results in a growing memory leak as the workspace continues to change (the old tree state is remembered as a delta against the current tree state, so that delta keeps growing). We eventually discard this delta automatically, but you should either:  1) Stop calling ISaveContext#needDelta  OR  2) Process the delta on startup by calling ISavedState#processResourceChangeEvents(IResourceChangeListener) when you register your participant.  We could likely optimize the memory usage within the workspace, but regardless there is no point in us recording the delta if you are never going to use it.  I'm marking this major since in my case it resulted in a 72MB delta in memory after several days of running. However I will also open a bug on the resources side to see if we can improve this.

Main is:  'API Tooling on org.eclipse.jdt.ui' Detail label is:  'Checking compatibility'  The main label should be more something like 'Building...' and the detail label should show the project in work (in quotes)  'Checking API compatibility...' title: Use scan API problems use a flag that collides with NO_FLAGS
desc: FUP to bug 310547  When the builder finds a use scan reference that has been deleted it creates a problem using the flag value 0 to mean deleted, but that value collides with IApiProblem.NO_FLAGS (value 0, used through out the tooling to determine if any flags at all are set).

title: Refactoring fails to update model caches
desc: Build Identifier: I20091210-1301 Seems PDE do some additional work often fails. I Paste my eclipse latest error log: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.refactoring.RefactoringUtils.createDeleteFilterChanges(RefactoringUtils.java:49) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.refactoring.FilterMoveParticipant.createPreChange(FilterMoveParticipant.java:56) at org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring.participants.ProcessorBasedRefactoring.createChange(ProcessorBasedRefactoring.java:307) at org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring.CreateChangeOperation.run(CreateChangeOperation.java:124) at org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring.PerformChangeOperation.run(PerformChangeOperation.java:209) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run(Workspace.java:1857) at org.eclipse.ltk.internal.ui.refactoring.WorkbenchRunnableAdapter.run(WorkbenchRunnableAdapter.java:87) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:121) The NPE because this invocation: /** * Gets the {@link IApiFilterStore} for the given {@link IProject} * @param project * @return the filter store for the given project or null * @throws CoreException */ static IApiFilterStore resolveFilterStore(IProject project) throws CoreException { IApiComponent component = ApiPlugin.getDefault().getApiBaselineManager().getWorkspaceBaseline().getApiComponent(project); if(component != null) { return component.getFilterStore(); } return null; } IApiComponent fails. title: Performance improvement and optimization in API tools
desc: Performance improvement and optimization in API tools.

title: API tooling project property page: wording
desc: 20080401  On a project that has API tooling installed open the property pages Go to the 'API Tooling Errors/Warnings' page  The first line is:   'Enable Project Specific Settings...'  Should be   'Enable project specific settings'  (Sentence style casing for checkboxed, '...' for buttons that open some new dialogs)

title: Report missing @since tags even if the corresponding member has a non-javadoc comment
desc: When a new API is added and is preceded with a line comment, we don't report the missing @since tags. I think we should.

title: Cannot ignore "the final keyword has been added"
desc: We have a case where the Javadoc specifies a static field as a constant but it was not marked "final" in the baseline. I would like to add the "final" modifier now but I was not able to ignore this using the project-specific settings.

title: @since tags should be checked for breaking api compatibility error only if they are additions
desc: If you add a final keyword to an existing static field, the @since tag validation is done even if this is not a new field.  Steps to reproduce: 1) Set up API tools for jdt.ui 2) Set the baseline to be 3.3.0 3) Go to the field org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaUI#ID_TYPES_VIEW and add the final keyword 4) Disable the two options: - The constant value is added - The keyword 'final' is added in the field preference section of the Compatibility tab 5) Rebuild JavaUI and you can see that a @since tag error is reported against ID_TYPES_VIEW.

title: removing API not recognizes as breaking change
desc: I am using a Mylyn 2.3.1 API profile that does not declare any packages as "x-internal" hence I am assuming that all classes in the profile are considered API by the tooling. In my workspace I have marked some packages as "x-internal" which removes API and I would expect this to constitute a breaking change requiring a version bump to 3.0.0. The tooling reports that I should keep the major version though: "The major version should be identical in version 2.3.1.v20080312-1300, since no API breakage occurred since version 3.0.0.qualifier".

title: None of the API Errors/Warnings preference pages has mnemonics
desc: I20100107-1410.  None of the API Errors/Warnings preference pages has mnemonics

title: Name collision for certain method keys causes false-positive illegal use to be reported
desc: I20100107-1410  Testing the new support for reporting illegal API use in the API use scans, I found that under certain circumstances key collisions would occur in our illegal method reference detector.  The example I found to debug was:  1. CompareEditorInput.dispose() would be added to the listing of restricted methods - CORRECT as it has a @noreference tag on it 2. any other method reference to any dispose() method - not just in CompareEditorInput - would be reported as illegal use. For example the following is reported as illegal use:    From: org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.AntEditor#void dispose()  Resolved To: org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.TextEditor#void dispose()  Kind: INVOKED_SPECIAL  which it is not - INCORRECT.

title: Race condition causes API filters to be removed
desc: I20100107-1410  testing the fix for bug 280619 and using the steps from comment #13 on that bug, I found that the workspace job to save filters was being preempted by the workspace baseline being disposed. This would cause the filter store to be closed, which would flush the filter map. Then when the job ran to save the filters it would delete the existing file thinking that there are no filters.  Steps 1. new workspace 2. bring in org.eclipse.ui.navigator 3. set baseline to 3.5 4. after build unused filters reported: OK 5. set project setting to remove filters automatically 6. after build the .settings/.api_filters file is gone and 4 problems are reported - which should remain filtered: BUG

title: no need to build API description for non-API enabled source projects
desc: We build API descriptions for all components in an API baseline - even for source projects that are not API tooling enabled. We should optimize API descriptions for such projects to be empty and not be persisted.

title: Javadoc tag autocomplete does not work at the end of a tag
desc: Version: 4.3.0 Build id: I20130416-0800  (also before this)  If you type in the complete tag and then try to autocomplete it nothing happens.  For example you type @noextend (carat next to 'd') and try to auto complete it nothing happens. We should be able to auto-complete the tag + fragment even if the tag is already typed.  The problem was in our completion proposal computer #acceptTag method, where we short-circuit when the tag name appears in a listing of existing names.

title: API use scan reports can be hard to read
desc: I20100107-1410  Thinking of ways to make the use scan reports look a bit better, I think it would be a good idea to have the version information not appear as part of the bundle name. Perhaps moving it to be alt text for the bundle name, or its own column would make it easier to immediately read the bundle name.

title: test if baseline type was already API
desc: 20080401-0851  - set the baseline to 3.3.2 - load 'org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring' from head (or v20080401-0800)  You will get an error on 'ParticipantExtensionPoint'  The method getName() has been removed.  ParticipantExtensionPoint was package visible in 3.3.2 and therefore new API in 3.4. The since 3.4 tag also reflects that.

title: Internal code usage scan does not consider split bundles
desc: I20100112-0800.  If a tool references internal code from bundle A and A gets split into A and B (or more general into B and C) with all fully qualified types names kept the same, then this is wrongly reported as breakage.  Test Case: org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.ITestKind.getDisplayName().

title: Internal code usage scan report should indicate return type change
desc: I20100112-0800.  The internal API scan report should indicate return type changes since those are hard to track down otherwise.

title: Missing full stop in Javadoc of @noreference for class and interface
desc: The Javadoc of @noreference tag does not have the full stop at the end of the sentence, for class and interface types (unlike @noextend and @noimplement).

title: [regression] API tooling complains about missing @since tag for an interface method that has @noreference tag
desc: API tooling produces "Missing @since tag on getEvaluation()" error message for	http://git.eclipse.org/c/cdt/org.eclipse.cdt.git/tree/core/org.eclipse.cdt.core/parser/org/eclipse/cdt/core/dom/ast/IValue.java line 35. API tooling in Eclipse 3.8.2 was satisfied by the @noreference tag.

title: Content assist does not work on an interface field or method unless explicitly marked as public
desc: 1) Open an API interface (i.e. IPluginModelBase in PDE) 2) Add a new field, do not mark it as public (String stuff = "stuff") 3) Add javadoc, type @noref, hit ctrl-space Result: Nothing happens, no content assist  If you fill in the @noreference tag manually, it is not marked as a bad tag. If you mark the field as public (public String stuff = "stuff"), content assist will work again.  A field in the interface is always treated as public, but our content assist isn't recognizing that.

title: CCE in TagValidator.visit
desc: Created attachment 232086 [details] stack trace  I'm getting a CCE during the full build: Errors running builder 'API Analysis Builder' on project 'org.eclipse.xtext.junit4'. Stack trace is attached. The corresponding project can be found here: http://git.eclipse.org/c/tmf/org.eclipse.xtext.git/tree/plugins/org.eclipse.xtext.junit4

title: what does @noextend mean on methods
desc: 20080401-0851  It's possible to mark a method as   @noextend This method is not intended to be extended by clients.  What does that mean exactly?  Normally methods are 'overridden'. One could say 'extending' means overriding and calling super.  So does '@noextend' mean that you can 're-implement' the method, just make sure to not call super. Do we then also need a tag for '@nooverride'?  Our API doc contains the definitions:  # Do not override a public or protected API method unless it is explicitly allowed. Unless otherwise indicated, treat all methods as if they had been declared final. (These are sometimes known as "soft final" methods). If the kind of overriding allowed is:  * "implement" - the abstract method declared on the subclass must be implemented by a concrete subclass * "extend" - the method declared on the subclass must invoke the method on the superclass (exactly once) * "re-implement" - the method declared on the subclass must not invoke the method on the superclass * "override" - the method declared on the subclass is free to invoke the method on the superclass as it sees fit

title: no need to persist methods/fields without restrictions in description
desc: Currently, our API descriptions (for source projects) get populated with entries for methods/fields even if they have no restrictions. We should not need to add these to the descriptions or persist/restore them.

title: would be good to have separate preferences for different kinds of API leakage
desc: We have several places in our API where we leak non-API types through inheritance. Usually, this is not a very good idea but it does not necessarily lead to unusable API.  However, referencing a non-API type in an API method (as an argument or return type) makes that method pretty much unusable, and I would like to see those cases flagged as an error.  Could you separate these two cases by way of two different preference settings?

title: NPE when opening existing workspace, I20100115-1100
desc: Created attachment 156382 [details] NPEs in the error log  I picked up a new build, I20100115-1100, and opened my existing 3.6 workspace.  It does a build, and then I got NPEs from API tools in the log.  I've attached the 3 errors, here's the example.  ex: !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 75 2010-01-18 09:34:22.958 !MESSAGE Errors occurred during the build. !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 75 2010-01-18 09:34:22.958 !MESSAGE Errors running builder 'API Analysis Builder' on project 'org.eclipse.ui.workbench'. !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.BundleComponent.createApiDescription(BundleComponent.java:365) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.model.Component.getApiDescription(Component.java:105) 	at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.comparator.ClassFileComparator.collectAllInterfaces(ClassFileComparator.java:963) ...

title: UI does not allow report of just illegal API use
desc: The API Use report now shows illegal API use. However, the UI enforces the user to select API references and or internal references. It would be useful to be able to run a report for just "illegal use".  I think this is just a UI validation that is not necessary.

title: Versions seem to be reversed in error message for major version update
desc: From bug 225517 comment 0, it looks like the version in the error message are inverted.

title: Versions are truncated in use scan report
desc: For some reason, bundle versions are truncated in the new "Version" column of the API use report.

title: use correct resource encoding when reading .java files
desc: API Tools should use the correct resource encoding from the workspace when reading .java files.  I use the setup from bug 377107 comment 9 (with the last attached charset64to32.jar), which transforms e.g. "long /*int*/" (ASCII bits on disk) into "int /*LONG*/" (Eclipse chars).  But now I get compiler problems like this, which don't make sense:  Missing @since tag on gtk_new(Device, int)	Cursor.java	/org.eclipse.swt/Eclipse SWT/gtk/org/eclipse/swt/graphics	line 550	@since tag problem  My API Baseline is also set to a 32-bit build, so everything should be fine with this declaration. And when I change the type to "int", then the problem disappears. It looks like the analyzer doesn't use the correct encoding, but the error message is issued against the correct IMethod with the "int" parameter type.

title: [use scan] scope not honored in various report scenarios
desc: Using HEAD.  I ran an API use report with the following settings:  Includes API References: true  Includes Internal References: true  Includes Illegal Use: true  Baseline Location: C:\SDK-I20100115\eclipse  Scope Pattern: org\.eclipse\.jface\..*  Reference Pattern: org\.eclipse\.debug\..*  Report Location: c:\temp\jface-scan\xml  API Patterns: None  Internal Patterns: None  Archive Patterns: None  Filter Pattern: None   The report showed *all* API references made by debug.* bundles rather than just those references to jface.*. It also included all references to system library code.

title: component.xml file of non-api projects is being over-written
desc: With the fix in for not creating an API description for plugin projects that are not 'API enabled', the component.xml file (if one exists) is being over-written as a .api_description file.  This has the net effect of: 1. removing the component.xml file 2. causing an out-going change to the project

title: The API generation task should always overwrite
desc: Currently is you run the API generation task and you already have a .api_description file where it would create a new one the task short-circuits and prints a non-descript message to the console that there was a .api_description file there already.  Personally I can't think of any reason why you would want to keep the old .api_description file when running the Ant task - its a pretty explicit set of steps to do no work.

title: Move API Tools to a 1.6 BREE
desc: We would like to investigate adding annotation support for API tools (replacement for using Javadoc tags), and will need to be 1.5+.

title: Field references are not always resolved to the correct owning member
desc: Created attachment 156877 [details] field resolution  I20100121-0800  When our reference extractor handles field references it does not correctly report references to fields from the class hierarchy- for example setting / getting a field value from a parent class.  I our current state we always consider field get / set instructions to belong to the type that the reference appears in. We should be resolving field get / set to make sure they are talking about the correct field.  The patch provides field resolution for class hierarchies, but I have not tested it to see if it will properly resolve the owning class for a field reference in an inner type where the field comes from the hierarchy of the enclosing type.

desc: Steps:  1. new workspace 2. new plugin project -> 1.8EE + compiler level 3. export as deployable 4. new API baseline - point to the export in 3. 5. build your workspace title: Warn when tag not supported on member
desc: We should create a warning if an API tag is used on a member where it is not supported. For example, if a @noreference tag is used on a type.

title: API Analysis builder is not cancelable
desc: I20080401-0851  The API Analysis builder is not cancelable (or does not poll often enough).  I accepted a few incoming changes in org.eclipse.pde.ui, and shortly after tried to accept other changes. CVS update was blocked by the builder, so I opened the Progress view and tried to cancel the 'API Analysis builder' (which was working on org.eclipse.pde.ui). I had to wait for about a minute until the builder was done.

title: non-API supertypes show as leaks even when they don't expose/leak anything
desc: Example:  JavaBreakpointConditionEditor extends non-API type AbstractJavaBreakpointEditor  I think this is a regression - API tools is reporting extension of non-API supertypes as a warning. However, the non-API supertype does not expose any additional methods/fields.

title: Convert API Tools Javadoc tags not converting tags on method
desc: I ran the conversion tool on "org.eclipse.jdt.junit" where it converts the @noextend Javadoc tag on class JUnitLaunchConfigurationTab to the corresponding annotation.  However, if I add the following javadoc to a method in the above class, say #getId, and run the conversion, it only converts the @noextend tag on class but leaves the @nooverride tags on the method as it is.  /**  * @nooverride This method is not intended to be re-implemented or extended by clients.  */

title: @nooverride and @noreference do not work for constructors
desc: Created attachment 95218 [details] example plugins TestPlugin and TestPlugin2  using: I20080401-0851  If you use the attached example plugins, having an @noreference tag or an @nooverride tag on constructors has no effect (i.e. we do not get an error)  The problem appears to be that we are not properly adding restrictions for constructors to the api description (inspecting the description shows that the constructors are present, but thta they have no restrictions).

title: Could not locate member when it is a constructor when the error is "Member visibility reduced"
desc: Step to reproduce: 1) Check ou jdt.ui from CVS 2) Set up API tools 3) Go to org.eclipse.jdt.ui.actions.FindImplementorsAction 4) Change the visibility of the constructor: FindImplementorsAction(JavaEditor) to protected. 5) The error is located on line 1 instead of being located on the line of the constructor declaration.

title: API Tooling Setup dialog improvements
desc: Using Eclipse 3.4 M6  Suggestions...  1.  Please add a filter field to allow the list of projects to be reduced.  Having this from the start would be ideal, since the dialog just does not handle large workspaces well.  2.  Consider grouping projects by Working Set.  This is another way to deal with the large workspaces.  3.  The "Delete component.xml after update is complete" checkbox stretches for the entire width of the dialog, which means that you can accidentally toggle it if you give focus to the dialog by clicking in the wrong place.  Toggling the check box should only happen when clicking the box or the label, but not horizontal whitespace.  By the way, I have no idea what "Delete component.xml after update is complete" even means.

title: Fields incorrectly assume type restrictions
desc: While testing bug 434320 I found that a field in a restricted class had assumed not-applicable restrictions.  Steps:  1. Change the fMethodsCacheKey field in JUnitLaunchConfigurationTab to:  /**   * @noreference This field is not intended to be referenced by clients.  */ public String fMethodsCacheKey;  2. run the conversion tool 3.notice it wants to add @NoReference (good) and @NoExtend(?? bad)  Our restriction resolution does ask parent elements for enclosing restrictions, but in this case a field cannot have noextend restrictions.

title: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.generator uses CPL
desc: While checking for missing copyright I found out that org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.generator still uses CPL.  Please check whether this is intentional or just an oversight.

title: Investigate to let external JAR builder run on auto-build
desc: 3.6 M5.  The pde.api.tools project has an external builder to build a JAR (good). If it's not too slow I would also register the auto-build target.  Two reasons for doing that: 1. it will build the JAR automatically for you when you modify the resources 2. the 'Build All' action which gets enabled and made visible in the toolbar due     to the missing auto-build functionality will go away again  On a side note: you probably also want to enable 'Refresh', so that the newly generated JAR automatically appears.

title: Java 8 API errors on ZonedDateTime#isBefore(ChronoZonedDateTime) and #toEpochSecond()
desc: BuildId: 4.4.0.I20140606-1215  The API execution environments for JavaSE-1.8 seem to be missing ZonedDateTime.isBefore(ChronoZonedDateTime).  Steps to repeat:  1. Create s plugin project with a JavaSE-1.8 EE with an activator and enable API analysis. 2. Paste the following snippet into the Activator's start() method:  	ZonedDateTime now = ZonedDateTime.now(); 	if (now.isBefore(now.plus(Duration.ofDays(1)))) { 		now.toEpochSecond(); 	}  3. Save.  Notice the isBefore() and toEpochSecond() methods are marked as API errors:     The method ZonedDateTime.isBefore(ChronoZonedDateTime) referenced in java8bug.Activator.start(BundleContext) is not defined in the bundle's required execution environment: JavaSE-1.8

title: NPE in ApiProblemReporter.isProblemFiltered(...)
desc: Build 3.4M6  When building a source workspace, I noticed the following in the log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 2 2008-04-10 15:16:32.417 !MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.core.resources". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException         at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiProblemReporter.isProblemFiltered(ApiProblemReporter.java:232)         at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiProblemReporter.addProblem(ApiProblemReporter.java:72)         at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.checkDefaultProfileSet(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:300)         at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:224)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633)         at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253)         at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.build(Workspace.java:330)         at org.eclipse.ui.actions.GlobalBuildAction$1.run(GlobalBuildAction.java:181)         at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55) Thu Apr 10 15:16:32 CEST 2008 - [Worker-3] Builder finished: ApiAnalysisBuilder(org.eclipse.debug.core) time: 4062ms

title: UseScanParser should parse out IReferenceDescriptors
desc: code from HEAD  with the addition of the descriptor IReferenceDescriptor our UseScanParser / UseScanVisitor should be updated to use this descriptor rather than passing a collection of data into the visitReference(..) method.  public void visitReference(int refKind, int refFlags, IMemberDescriptor fromMember, int lineNumber, int visibility)  should be:  public void visitReference(IReferenceDescriptor reference)  This will also allow extensibility if someone wants to create their own parser and visit a specialized IReferenceDescriptor.

title: API builder throws error when deleting a project
desc: I20100217-1031 (broken since R3.5).  1. check out 'org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring' from HEAD    (any other project with enabled API tooling should do the trick too) 2. wait until build is done 3. delete the project including files on disk ==> boom! error dialog appears and error logged.   Boy, this was hard to figure out because the API builder returns status messages it gets instead of wrapping them with the correct context, see bug 303285.

title: Filtering using patterns in api usage report seems to be too aggressive
desc: I tried to filter references to mylyn bundles inside mylyn api scan results so that I don't get references to mylyn from mylyn using the pattern: org\.eclipse\.mylyn\..*  and it ended up filtering all bundles. The result is empty where before I had multiple usage scan results outside of mylyn bundles.

title: Log entry each time I delete a *.java file
desc: I20100224-2242 - works fine in 3.6 M5.  Each time I delete *.java file I get a log entry from org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.cleanupUnsupportedTagMarkers(IResource)   Test Case: 1. check out 'org.eclipse.ltk.core.refactoring' from HEAD    (any other project with enabled API tooling should do the trick too) 2. wait until build is done 3. delete a *.java file ==> log entry

title: Ant task to generate .api_description file should not do anything for projects without the api tools nature
desc: The ant task should only run for projects that have the api tools nature.

title: Add version to the .api description file
desc: For future extensions, we might want to provide a version value inside the .api_description file.

title: Remove uneeded parameter for API usage scanning
desc: in ApiUseAnalyzer#findIllegalApiUse(..) we take an api pfofile as an argument, this profile is only used to get related components when building search conditions and is always the profile that owns the component we also pass in.  This parameter should be removed as we can simply make the call component.getProfile().

title: builder progress messages don't appear
desc: I know we have specialized progress messages from the API builder but all I see in the latest I-build is "Invoking 'API Analysis Builder' on 'project'".   Not sure why our messages are not making it to the surface.

title: IApiProblemDetector.createProblems() should take a progress monitor as parameter
desc: It could be a long running task and it prevents any sub detector to check for cancelation requests.

title: Execution Environment deltas should consider "compatible" EE
desc: Fup of bug 227593. When the old list of EEs is J2SE-1.4,CDC-1.0/Foundation-1.0,J2SE-1.3 and J2SE-1.4 is removed, this is not a problem as if it works on 1.3, it should also work on 1.4. So in this case I don't think we should report anything. Or at least this should not be seen as an API change.

title: 'Constructor with non-API parameter type' should not be flagged for @noreference constructor
desc: I20080415-1646  'Constructor with non-API parameter type' should not be flagged for @noreference methods. The @noreference already tells that the method is not API, so the parameter type is not a problem.  Problem:  Constructor with non-API parameter type org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.javaeditor.CompilationUnitEditor	AddDelegateMethodsAction.java	org.eclipse.jdt.ui/ui/org/eclipse/jdt/ui/actions	line 327	API Usage Problem  Method declaration (CompilationUnitEditor is an internal type):  /**  * Note: This constructor is for internal use only. Clients should not call this  * constructor.  *   * @param editor the compilation unit editor  *   * @noreference This constructor is not intended to be referenced by clients.  */ public AddDelegateMethodsAction(CompilationUnitEditor editor) {

title: Improve wording of EE related messages
desc: I noticed this in my workspace...  The method Boolean.parseBoolean(String) referenced in   org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.search.dialogs.FilteredIUSelectionDialog.IUWrapperLabelProvider.getImage(Object) is not   defined in bundle's required execution environment: J2SE-1.4  Are we missing a "the" there? in THE bundle's required...

org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:42) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) 	at
