title: [api tooling] Wrong deltas reported when code is refactored by pushing down some methods from the superclass
desc: In I20080430-0800, some code has been refactored in jface databinding and it is causing the API freeze check to report false positives. The previous code was like this:   NON-API TYPE ---- implements an interface    |    | API TYPE  The refactored code is: API TYPE ---- implements an interface  The interface methods were defined inside the non-api type so that they were also API for the API type.  The new code defined the interface methods directly inside the AP type and uses a double-dispatch to an internal instance of the former superclass which has been removed.  From an API perspective, this refactoring is right and the API type doesn't expose any new methods. So the deltas reported by API tools should support this case.

title: [api tooling] Visible methods of a non-API types must be seen as API for API subclasses
desc: The following case is not handled properly by the delta detection.  package p1 (x-internal:=true)   |   +------- NON-API public type                 public void foo()  package p2 (exported as public)   |   +------ API type that extends the NON-API type from package p1  In this case foo() is part of the API of the API type. Removing foo from the NON-API type should be seen as a breakage.

title: Missing error message for api usage
desc: There is a case in which a api usage problem is returned with: category = IApiProblem.CATEGORY_USAGE kind = ILLEGAL_REFERENCE flags = 0  With the missing break; statement in the method org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.problems.ApiProblemFactory.getProblemMessageId(int, int, int, int) this leads to the message for unsupported tags.  I'll investigate as this doesn't occur in the IDE, but it does occur in the ant task.

title: [api tooling] Extending an @noimplement interface should not be an error
desc: Build ID: I20080502-0100 (Eclipse 3.4M7)  Consider following rather common scenario:  /** @noimplement Do not implement directly. Extend abstract base Foo instead. */ public interface IFoo {   //... }  public abstract class Foo implements IFoo {   //... }  With following client code:  interface IFooBar extends IFoo {   public void bar(); }  class MyFooBar extends Foo implements IFooBar {   public void bar(); }  In this case, the client code legally implements IFoo, because it does so by extending abstract base Foo. This scenario should not be flagged as an error: Just extending an interface does not introduce any binary compatibility issues.  But currently the API Tooling flags IFooBar extends IFoo as an error.

title: Content assist should not propose @no* tags that are already present
desc: I20080502-0100  Content assist should not propose @no* tags that are already present.

title: Wrong "type of the field ... has been changed" for protected field in @noextend class
desc: I20080716-1200  In org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.launchConfigurations.JavaArgumentsTab, change the type of the protected field fPrgmArgumentsText to StyledText. API Tools report the wrong compatibility problem below.  Changing the type of this field is not an API breakage, since JavaArgumentsTab is tagged with @noextend. No client can legally have a reference to this field (since clients must not create a subclass and they must not live in a foreign API package).  The type of the field org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.launchConfigurations.JavaArgumentsTab.fPrgmArgumentsText has been changed	JavaArgumentsTab.java	org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui/ui/org/eclipse/jdt/debug/ui/launchConfigurations	Compatibility Problem	line 61

title: @nooverride and @noreference tags should not be allowed on private methods
desc: The tags @nooverride and @noreference should not be allowed as valid api tags on private methods since they are ignored anyways.

title: Should not allow @noreference tag on private fields
desc: To follow along bug 214989, we should also not allow the @noreference tag on private fields.

title: Addition of an ant task to run the API tools verification during Eclipse build
desc: This bug is a fup bug of bug 220637. We must define an ant task to provide a report during the Eclipse build.

title: Callers of org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.util.Util.getInputStreamAsCharArray(InputStream, int, String) must close the input stream
desc: There are two calls that are not closing the input stream. 1) org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiDescriptionManager.restoreDescription(IJavaProject, ProjectApiDescription)  2) org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.ApiFilterStore.initializeApiFilters()  This creates file handles leaks and potential problems to remove the corresponding files.

title: [Metadata] update version of org.eclipse.ui.navigator
desc: HEAD  Setting 3.3.2 as API Tools baseline gives:  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type The minor version should be incremented in version 3.3.100.qualifier, since new APIs have been added since version 3.3.2.M20080207-0800	MANIFEST.MF	org.eclipse.ui.navigator/META-INF	line 5	Version Numbering Problem

title: Api filter format could list the message arguments instead of concatenating them
desc: Instead of concatenating message arguments using '#', we could create an inner element like this:  <resource path="src/org/eclipse/jface/internal/databinding/provisional/swt/CompositeUpdater.java">         <filter id="305365105">                 <message_arguments>                     <message_argument value="org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.provisional.swt.CompositeUpdater"/>                     <message_argument value="org.eclipse.jface.databinding_1.2.0"/>                 </message_arguments>         </filter> </resource>  instead of: <resource path="src/org/eclipse/jface/internal/databinding/provisional/swt/CompositeUpdater.java">         <filter id="305365105" messageargs="org.eclipse.jface.internal.databinding.provisional.swt.CompositeUpdater#org.eclipse.jface.databinding_1.2.0"/>     </resource>  This would require the filter version to be incremented and we should support the old version on read and save the new format.

title: Removing api filters file doesn't trigger a rebuild
desc: When deleting the api filter file directly, no rebuild is triggered. A manual build needs to be done to get back the filtered errors.

title: detect unrequired change to plug-in minor version
desc: When there are no API changes in a plug-in and the minor version is incremented, API tooling should flag the problem.  I found when migrating Ant plug-ins to API tooling that the plug-in minor versions had been incremented since the previous release, but there were only bug fixes in this version (no API changes). We should be able to detect that the minor version has been incremented, but there were no API changes.

title: Changing non-final to final class should be a compatible change for @noextend class
desc: If a class is not supposed to be extended (@noextend), changing non-final to final should not be a problem. We need to double check this is properly detected.

title: Should not allow @nooverride tag on final methods
desc: Currently we allow the @nooverride tag on final methods, but they cannot be overridden anyways, so the tag is meaningless.

title: 3 api tools junit failures in 20210426-1800
desc: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.builder.tests.OSGiLessAnalysisTests	testAnalyzer	Failure	Wrong number of problems expected:<4> but was:<1>  java.lang.AssertionError: Wrong number of problems expected:<4> but was:<1> at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:89) at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:835) at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:647) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.builder.tests.OSGiLessAnalysisTests.testAnalyzer(OSGiLessAnalysisTests.java:70) at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:566) at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod$1.runReflectiveCall(FrameworkMethod.java:59) at org.junit.internal.runners.model.ReflectiveCallable.run(ReflectiveCallable.java:12) at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod.invokeExplosively(FrameworkMethod.java:56)

title: Binary Compatibility options for Annotations
desc: We have too many compatibility errors/warnings for Annotations - some of them are invalid. As well, we no longer support the @noimplement tag on annotations (@see bug 232404)  The following options should be removed:  * A field (annotation not tagged as @noimplement) has been added (since an annotation cannot be extended as is not to be implemented, adding a field does not break anyone?) * A method (annotation not tagged as @noimplement) has been added (it's only breaking if a method is added without a default value, and we have a separate error for this already) * A member type ... has been added (since not to be implemented, this does not break anyone) * A class bound has been added * An interface bound has been added * The interface bounds have been added * A type parameter has been added * A class bound has been modified * An interface bound has been modified * The interface bounds have been modified * A type parameter has been removed * The type parameters have been removed * A class bound has been removed * An interface bound has been removed * The interface bounds have been removed (annotations don't seem to support generics) * The superinterface hierachy has been reduced (annotations can't extend other interfaces or types)  I think we should just be left with the following:  * A method without a default value has been added * Converted to a class, enum, interface (3) * The restrictions have been modified * A field has been removed * A method with/wo a default value has been removed (2) * A member type has been removed

title: Simplify "converted to enum..." compatibility options
desc: For each type (class, interface, enum, annotation), we have 3 compatibility options like:  * Converted to class/interface/enum/annotation  I think it would be simpler to remove each of these options, and simply report such problems as a removed type (which is configured under the "Bundle" options). This would reomve 12 error settings, reducing complexity.  When such a thing happens there is a new type that has to have a new @since tag, and the old type has been removed.

title: Simplify type bound options
desc: For each type there are error settings like:  * A type parameter has been added * A type parameter has been removed * The type parameters have been removed  It feels like the 2nd/3rd options could be combined into one - there would just be multiple errors if multiple type bounds were removed.  And there are options for modifying type parameter bounds like:  * A class bound has been added * A class bound has been removed * An interface bound has been added * An interface bound has been removed * The interface bounds have been removed * A class bound has been modified * The interface bounds have been modified   Would it be simpler to have one top level group of error settings for a "Type Parameter" and have them apply to a type parameters for each type (class, enum, interface), rather than duplicating the same settings in each one?

title: Incorrect version warning for changed re-exported bundle
desc: I20080805-1307  Resolve version problems in org.eclipse.core.runtime.  See Bundle Version Warnings in http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/I20080805-1307/apitools/apitoolsverifications/html/index.html

title: Incremental build problem with fix for bug 229697
desc: When an internal type is modified, it doesn't get "check" on the next build by the api tooling builder. It should be checked if it is a super type of an API type.

title: No delta returned for adding or removing volatile modifiers from a field
desc: Right now this change is not detected. Trivial to add.

title: Bundle verification ant task should report non-api bundles
desc: We should report which bundles are not converted yet to api tools support.

title: org.eclipse.ui complaint about API
desc: AFAIK since we re-export both org.eclipse.jface and org.eclipse.ui.workbench, shouldn't we have to increment this version.  Boris?  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type The minor version should be the same for version 3.4.0.qualifier, since no new APIs have been added since version 3.3.1.M20071128-0800	MANIFEST.MF	org.eclipse.ui/META-INF	line 5	Version Numbering Problem  This is with I20080508-2000  PW

title: quickfix for bundle version replaces .qualifier with explicit build ID
desc: I used a quick fix to change a bundle version, and noticed a completely qualified version number was inserted - i.e. ".qualifier" was replaced with a build ID.

title: Minor and major version change should be detected after API freeze
desc: Between the 0507 and the 0508 builds, the version of org.eclipse.ant.core has been changed to 3.2 down to 3.1.300 (see bug  227556).  I would have expected this to be caught by the API tooling since now that we are API frozen this version change constitutes a breaking change.

title: Error for adding method to API class
desc: We have an Error/Warning severity setting for "A method (class not tagged as @noextend) has been added".  I believe that we allow adding methods to API classes no matter if there is a @noextend tag on the class or not.  When I wrote a test for this, and tried this in the IDE, no error was indicated. I think the setting should be removed (or the builder needs to be fixed to report an error).  Olivier - I think that in strict mode this may be an error in case a subclass already has a method with the same name, but in practice, we allow it. Can you confirm?

title: Invalid API problems for method that changed from private to @noreference public
desc: M20080813-0800 and I20080812-0800  - check out org.eclipse.ui.navigator from HEAD or R3_4_maintenance - remove .api_filters file  => Invalid error: The method org.eclipse.ui.navigator.NavigatorActionService.getActionProviderInstance(CommonActionProviderDescriptor) is no longer API  The method used to be private in 3.4 but the fix for bug 212389 turned it into: /**  * [..]  * @noreference This method is not intended to be referenced by clients.  */ public CommonActionProvider getActionProviderInstance([..]

title: Changing class hierachy reports "reduced" hierarchy instead of "changed"
desc: If I change DebugElement (org.eclipse.debug.core) from:       DebugElement extends PlatformObject   to:       DebugElement extends MyAdaptable      (where MyAdaptable implements IAdaptable)  Then I get the following error:  The superclass set has been reduced for type org.eclipse.debug.core.model.DebugElement  However, the superclass has actually changed.

title: adding abstract to a @noinstantiate class creates problem
desc: Currently, adding the "abstract" keyword to a non-abstract class tagged as @noinstantiate creates a compatibility problem. However, I don't think it should. In both cases the class cannot be instantiated and can still be subclassed.  There are 4 tests in the builder suite that should be modified when this bug is fixed:  ClassCompatibilityModifierTests: * testAddAbstractNoInstantiateI * testAddAbstractNoInstantiateF * testAddAbstractNoExtendNoInstantiateI * testAddAbstractNoExtendNoInstantiateF

title: No problem detected when public class becomes package visible
desc: If I change an API class from public to default/package visible, no compatibility errors appear. I would expect to get a "reduced visibility" error on the class.

title: reducing visibility of member types reported incorrectly as remove
desc: When I reduce the visibility of a member type in the following situations, the reduction is reported as a type removal. I think this is misleading to the user since the type has not actually been removed - it is just no longer visible.  * public to package * public to private * protected to package * protected to private   As well, if the enclosing type is annotated as @noextend, reducing the visiblity of a protected type results in a removed type error, when there should be no error (since the type is not visible according to API restrictions).

title: Adding @noextend or @noinstantiate to an API class does not create problem
desc: If I add restrictions to an API class that previously had no restrictions, there are no API problems reported. Doing either of these is a change in the API contract which should be flagged as a problem (@noextend or @noinstantiate).  These errors should only be detected if the baseline API component has an API description (i.e. creating the initial description should not create errors).

title: NPE building a fragment
desc: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.util.Util.getDocument(Util.java:968) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.createCompatibilityProblem(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:878) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.processDelta(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:995) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.checkCompatibility(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:628) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.analyzeComponent(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:191) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.buildAll(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:391) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:301) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:633) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:253) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:256) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:309) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:341) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:140) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:238) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:55)  Using latest.

title: no error when adding a member type to interface
desc: There is a severity setting, defaults to ERROR, for adding a member type to an interface when it is *not* @noimplement. However, adding a member type to an interface creates no problems.  Either the preference should be removed or an error should be reported.  The following test should be updated when this bug is fixed:  InterfaceCompatibilityMemberTests.testAddMemberType*()

title: Cannot filter error inside MANIFEST.MF
desc: When trying to convert org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry, I got some error for wrong bundle version. When trying to fix them using a filter, the errors are still reported after the build.

title: org.eclipse.pde.api.tools dependency on pde.core is broken with pde.core downgrade version
desc: pde.core changed version from 3.4.0.qualifier to 3.3.102.qualifier. This broke the version range of the dependency on pde.core inside the bundle org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.

title: Changing pde.core major version to 4.0.0.qualifier is not detected as an error
desc: This should be fixed for 3.4. We should detect that there is no need to upgrade the major version.

title: Split bundle version management preference to distinguish minor and major version errors
desc: We need to split this preference into two in order to support minor and major bundle version error separately.

title: [api tooling] No missing @since tag should be reported for a protected member in a final class
desc: I20080821-1005  Bug 218976 should be extended to methods and nested classes.  E.g take org.eclipse.jdt.ui.actions.GenerateHashCodeEqualsAction 1.18 and add a protected method or nested class. This gives an invalid error: "Missing @since tag on initialize(IType)".

title: adding super interface to interface does not create errors
desc: If I have an interface that clients are allowed to implement, and I add a new super inteface to it, no problems are reported.  I would assume a problem should be reported as this adds new methods to the API that must be implemeneted, breaking the existing API contract.  Test should be updated when this bug is fixed:  * InterfaceCompatibilityMemberTests.testAddSuperInterfaceA*()  This shuold only be allowed when the interface is @noimplement

title: no problem when adding @noimplement restriction
desc: If add a @noimplement restriction to an interface that had no restrictions in the baseline (but where an API description existed), then no problem is created.  I would expect a "restrictions modified" error to appear.  Test to be updated with bug:  * InterfaceCompatibilityMemberTests.testAddNoImplement*()

title: @noreference should suppress some field compatibility problems
desc: When a field is annotated as @noreference, it should suppress some compatibility problems (as it effectively makes the field private):  * Adding 'final' keyword * Adding 'static' keyword * Remove 'static" keyworkd * Reducing the visibility  Assoicated tests to be updated with bug fix:  in FieldCompatibilityModifierTests * testAddFinalNoReference*() * testAddFinalOnStaticNoReference*() * testAddStaticNoReference*() * testRemoveStaticNoReference*() * testProtectedToPackageNoReference*() * testPublicToPrivateNoReference*()

title: Redundant problems reported when removing "final" on constant
desc: When a "static final" variable is changed to "static" two problems are reported. The problems essentially mean the same thing and could be confusing to the user. Ideally, we should just report one problem.  For example, when changing       public static final String CONSTANT = "CONSTANT"  to      public static String CONSTANT = "CONSTANT"  The problems are:  (1) The constant value CONSTANT has been removed for a.fields.modifiers.RemoveFinalOnConstant.CONSTANT (2) The 'final' keyword has been removed for a compile-time constant static field a.fields.modifiers.RemoveFinalOnConstant.CONSTANT   Keeping the second problem would be sufficient.  Associated test:  FieldCompatibilityModifierTests.testRemoveFinalOnConstant*()

title: Convert xml reports from Bundle verification ant task into html
desc: We need a new ant task to complete this work and allow the integration inside the releng builds.

title: Reducing visibility of protected body declarations in @noextend class
desc: Reducing the visibility of a protected field in a class annotated as @noextend should not create problems as the field cannot be accessed outside the bundle.  Assocaited test:  * FieldCompatibilityModifierTests.testProtectedToPrivateNoExtend*()

title: API Baselines pref page - should be "Remove" (no ellipsis)
desc: 3.4 RC1 0510-2000  The API Baselines preference page has a button "Remove...".  It should be "Remove" (without ellipsis).  A long explanation is available if interested but if you look around you'll see that its usually "Delete" or "Remove".

title: @noreference should suppress some method compatibility problems
desc: When a method is considered @noreference, some compatibility problems should not be reported (as a @noreference method is considered private):  * Reducing the visibility of a method * Adding the 'static' keyword * Removing the 'static' keyword  As well, changing a protected method to priavate in a class marked @noextend should not be an error.  The following tests need updating pending this fix:  MethodCompatibilityModifierTests * testAddStaticNoReference*() * testRemoveStaticNoReference*() * testProtectedToPackageNoReference*() * testPublicToPrivateNoReference*() * testProtectedToPrivateNoExtend*()

title: pushing a method up the class hierarchy should not be error
desc: If a method is pushed up the class hierarchy a "method removed" error should not be reported.  Associated test case:  ClassCompatibilityHierarchyTests.testPushMethodUp*()

title: implicit/explicit class bound of Object should not be considered in add/remove/change
desc: When a class bound is implicitly or explicitly java.lang.Object, we should consider it to be empty in terms of error reporting. For example, changing a type declaration from <E> to <E extends Integer> results in a error of "changed class bound" rather than addition. Similarly, changing from <E extends Integer> to <E> results in change rather than remove.  As well, adding/removing an interface bounds results in two errors: 1) adding/removing the interface 2) adding/removing a class (Object)  The tests in ClassCompatibilityTypeParameterTests need to be updated with the fix to this bug:  * testAddClassBound*() * testRemoveClassBound*() * testAddInterfaceBound*() * testRemoveOnlyInterfaceBound*()

title: Coordinate compatibility options doc with latest prefs
desc: The documentation for API tooling compatibility errors/warnings needs to be updated to reflect the latests settings.

title: API Tools not finding @since tag when there is a comment in the javadoc after the tag.
desc: SWT.TRANSPARENT is being reported as missing an @since tag, but it's clearly there. If the "WARNING" comment is moved above the @since the error goes away.

title: Typo in org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.builder.tests.compatibility.ClassCompatibilityHierarchyTests.WORKSPACE_CLASSES_PACKAGE_A path
desc: There is a typo in the contents of the string. It should be "compatibility".

title: Message improvements on Compatibility problems tab
desc: I thinks we could improve the following:  (1) Since we refere to Baselines instead of profiles, "API profile" section should be renamed. Perhaps we should move this to the "Bundle" category?  And do we ever detect a removed bundle/component from a profile? We only analyze projects, so if your workspace is missing a project, we don't notice :-)  (2) "Bundle > A type has been removed" should say "An API type has become non-API".

title: Eclipse build Ant task should allow removed bundles to be filtered out
desc: The exclude list could also be used to filter out removed bundles like tomcat or resource.win32.

title: API breakage reported if removing extends of internal class
desc: I20080827-0935  Attempting to fix a problem where a public class extends an internal class (i.e. by removing the extends), API Tools now reports an API breakage saying that the superclass has changed.  Shouldn't it allow this "breakage" since it it fixing an invalid extends usage?

title: Preference page does not use dialog font
desc: 3.4 RC1  - go to General > Appearence > Colors and Fonts and change the dialog font. - Close and reopen the preferences, go to the API Errors/Warnings page  Tabs and control descriptions are still shown with the default font

title: [api tooling] NPE in API Analysis Builder on tm.discovery.model.edit project
desc: Created attachment 100899 [details] Logfile with the exceptions  Build ID: I20080516-1333 (3.4rc1)  During the initial build of my workspace after upgrading to I20080516-1333, I saw attached exception in my .log:  java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.checkBundleVersionsOfReexportedBundles(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:232) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.checkApiComponentVersion(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:1257) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.BaseApiAnalyzer.analyzeComponent(BaseApiAnalyzer.java:198) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.builder.ApiAnalysisBuilder.build(ApiAnalysisBuilder.java:607) [...]   The interesting thing is that I'm not aware of reexporting anything. Dbl clicking on the corresponding entry in the "PDE Runtime Error Log" view threw another NPE from jface -- see attached .log:   java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.views.log.EventDetailsDialog.updateProperties(EventDetailsDialog.java:344) 	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.views.log.EventDetailsDialog.createDialogArea(EventDetailsDialog.java:500) 	at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.createContents(Dialog.java:760) 	at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.create(Window.java:431) 	at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.create(Dialog.java:1089) 	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.views.log.EventDetailsDialog.create(EventDetailsDialog.java:173) 	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.views.log.EventDetailsDialogAction.run(EventDetailsDialogAction.java:96) 	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.views.log.LogView$15.doubleClick(LogView.java:512)         [...]

title: Removed type not detected in incremental build
desc: If I remove an API type, or reduce the visibility of an API type in a bundle, the error is not detected until a full build is performed.  The following tests need to be updated when this bug is fixed:  BundleCompatibilityTests: * testPublicToPackageI() * testRemovePublicClassI()

title: Error message missing arguments
desc: I created a @since tag on a member like:        @since 3.4.2  The problem message appeared like:  Invalid @since tag '3.4.2' on {1}; expecting two fragments  > Missing member name

title: Wrong problem removed using @noreference tag on inner constructors
desc: Created attachment 111598 [details] test project  using N20080901-2000  Steps:  1. using the test project build testCPL11 and notice two api problems for leaking params on the two constructors  2. add a noreferece tag where the TODO say to   3. save (incremental build)  Expected the problem is removed from the constructor the tag appears on  Happens the problem is removed from the other constructor???

title: Annotation/Enun should not support 'restrictions have been modified' option
desc: There is a left over error/warning severity setting for Annotations: "restrictions have been modified". I believe we no longer support any restrictions on annotations, and this should be removed.

title: Type or members with increased access can return inconsistent delta
desc: When a type is changed from package visibility to public (see org.eclipse.swt.dnd.URLTransfer), it can be seen as an added type on a full build, but it is seen as an increased access on an incremental build.  I think in both cases this is an increased access, not a type addition. The result of this increased access is the exposure of a new API type, but in this case the type itself is not new. It is simply more visible.  This leads to a missing @since tag error on full build that is not reported on incremental build. So this is confusing for the user.

title: Quick fix message is awkward
desc: If I have a @since tag as 3.3 that should be 3.4, the quick fix description says:     "Correct the version of @since tag using 3.4"  I think it should be:     "Change @since tag value to be 3.4"

title: no error reported when enum super interface removed
desc: An error should be reported when an enum's super interface set is reduced.  The following test case should be updated when this bug is addressed:  EnumCompatibilityTests * testRemoveSuperInterface*()

title: no error for malformed tag of form abc1.0
desc: If I have a @since tag that ends with the a number, but is not its own segment, there is no error. For example:  @since abc1.0  I think this should be an error, expecting "abc 1.0" or just "1.0".  The following test should be updated with this bug:  MalformedSinceTagTests * testMalformedTag*()

title: Naming of the column in the api verification report should be improved
desc: Daniel provided some feedback for the api verification report. The naming of columns is not clear and it seems to be confusing to know what the numbers in the column represents. Daniel, any suggestions ?

title: The preference for type parameter has been modified should be removed
desc: This preference is not used anymore. A type parameter can only be added or removed.

title: API Verification Report does not honor API Problem filters
desc: I20080521-2000.  On the build results page the PDE API Tooling report stuff for which I added API problem filters:  jface.text: org.eclipse.jface.text.TextViewer illegally instantiates org.eclipse.jface.text.projection.ChildDocumentManager org.eclipse.jface.text.revisions.RevisionInformation.applyDiff(Hunk[]) has non-API parameter type org.eclipse.jface.internal.text.revisions.Hunk  ui.workbench.texteditor: org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.ITextEditorActionConstants illegally implements org.eclipse.ui.IWorkbenchActionConstants  ui.editors: org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.ITextEditorHelpContextIds illegally implements org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.IAbstractTextEditorHelpContextIds org.eclipse.ui.texteditor.DefaultMarkerAnnotationAccess.getAnnotationTypeHierarchy() has non-API return type org.eclipse.ui.internal.texteditor.AnnotationTypeHierarchy   The report should honor the API problem filters.  Please fix this for RC2 as I spent lots of time adding the API tooling tags and fixing the API problems and hence I don't want my plug-ins to appear on that report ;-)

title: removing type argument from field should be an error
desc: Removing a type parameter from a field should be a compatibility error:  like "List<String>" becomes "List"  The following tests should be updated with this bug fix:  * FieldCompatibilityModifierTests.testRemoveTypeParameters*()

title: Lots of new API errors after switching to I20080521-2000
desc: I20080521-2000  After switching to I20080521-2000 I now have tons of these: - The super interfaces set has been reduced for type ... - The superclass set has been reduced for type ...  And due to those errors it also creates an error in the manifest: - The major version should be incremented in version 3.4.0.qualifier, since API breakage occurred since version 3.3.1.r331_v2007062   Neither restart nor full build fixes it. No problems in I20080520-2000 or RC1.  Test Case: 1. start fresh workspace using I20080521-2000 2. set R3.3.1.1 as API baseline 3. checkout 'org.eclipse.jface.text' from CVS ==> lots of errors

title: Reports wrong error on correct @since 3.4 tag
desc: I20080521-2000.   With this build I get errors on @since tags that look like this:  * @since 3.4 protected (was added in 2.1 as private class)  This is wrong. Also the suggested quick fix is bogus: Change @since tag value to be 3.4 protected (was added   in 3.4 as private class) ==> it wants to change 2.1 to 3.4   The text behind @since can be anything, as specified in: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/windows/javadoc.html#@since  @since  since-text     Adds a "Since" heading with the specified since-text to the generated documentation. The text has no special internal structure.    It also fails when using multiple since tags like: 	 * @since 2.1 private 	 * @since 3.4 protected

title: Delta should be reported for changed restrictions on a field or a method
desc: Since a field can be tagged as @noreference and a method can be tagged as @noreference or @noextend, we should check if this is not breaking existing clients.

title: API Verification Report: List of all non API bundles misleading
desc: I20080522-1800.  In the API Verification Report the following is a bit unclear:    List of all non API bundles  Actually it is not a list of non-API bundles but rather a list of bundles without API tooling setup.   List of bundles without installed API tooling support or  List of bundles not configured for API tooling support

title: [api tooling] Reports wrong error on correct @since 3.4 tag
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #233445 +++ I20080521-2000.  See 233445 comment 18. I would be trivial to support this case.

title: binary compatible instance field addition should not be flagged as binary incompatible
desc: We added a field to JFace's CellEditor.LayoutData in 3.4. The class was not marked as @noextend (arguably it should be) and thus the API tooling reported the field addition as a binary incompatible change.  If I read "13.4.8 Field Declarations" (JLS, Third Edition) correctly, the change does not constitute a binary incompatible change.

title: Tons of API tooling errors after importing binaries
desc: I20080909-1121.  I upgraded my workspace as usual to the latest I-build by importing all required plug-ins. Now, besides the floading of errors due to bug 246804 I also get tons of these:  The super interfaces set has been reduced for type org.eclipse.ui.ide.FileStoreEditorInputFactory  plus one of these for each manifest.mf: The major version should be incremented in version 3.5.0.qualifier, since API breakage occurred since version 3.4.0.I20080606-1300  We already had a similar issue which got marked as fixed, see bug 243136. Same symptoms: cleaning, restarting, deleting metadata does not help. BUT: this time starting with an older build (N20080904-2000) does not make the problem go away.   This is a blocker for using API tooling with latest I-build.

title: Externalized string has a typo
desc: The option description for added type parameter for a method has a typo. It says: A type parameters have been added.  instead of: A type parameter has been added.

title: Some compatibility options should be removed
desc: In the Enum section: - A field (enum not tagged as '@noextend') has been added - A method (enum not tagged as '@noextend') has been added  An enum type cannot be extended. There is no such restriction on an enum type.

title: Document fall-through cases in switch statements
desc: With the new compiler warning, we should document and enable all the fall-through cases.

title: Deleting equals()/hashCode() results in API error
desc: Using latest I-build:  * Delete the equals() and/or hashCode() methods from Breakpoint (org.eclipse.debug.core), and errors appear saying a method has been removed.  However, this is an inherited method and no errors should appear (I think).

title: [api tooling] @since tag error message doesn't refer to the right member
desc: When converting ecf bundles, I realized that the missing @since tags error message are always referring to the type name instead of the constructor/method/field/enum constant names. Even if the error itself is well located on the right member, it doesn't look good at all from the problem view. It is difficult to know what member has the problem.  The fix is trivial.  Darin, I would target 3.4 as this will be a common problem found by teams when they convert all their bundles to API tools.

title: Many errors due to wrong warning about changed restrictions
desc: N20080910-2000.  After 3.4 PDE API tooling started to warn if there's a @noextend on a final class (very good). Now, of course we've fixed that BUT HEY: now PDE API tooling reports an error saying that we changed the restriction:     The restrictions have been changed for type ...  This is just wrong.  Marking as 'major' because I now no longer see in my Package Explorer whether I have a real error on the project or not.

title: Some compatibility options can be removed
desc: On our pref page for compatibility options there are some options for constructors that could be removed:  1. The keyword 'abstract' has been added (you cannot use abstract on a constructor)  2. The keyword 'static' has been added (you cannot use the keyword static on a constructor)  3. The keyword 'static' has been removed (you cannot use the keyword static on a constructor)  4. The keyword 'final' has been added (you cannot use the keyword final on a constructor)

title: [api tooling] Should modify code to compile in 1.6 mode
desc: Fup of bug 228928. When compiling the api tooling code in 1.6 mode, several compile errors are reported, because the code is using String.compareTo(Object) method and this method doesn't exist anymore in 1.6. In 1.6 or 1.5 this is a bridge method so it cannot be directly invoked. We should cast the argument to String to invoke String.compareTo(String). This is what is done in the end anyway.

title: pde.api.tools.ui needs to be retagged
desc: The comparator states the the built version and version in the repo with the same tag have differences  canonical: osgi.bundle,org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui,1.0.400.v20111107 		Difference found for canonical: osgi.bundle,org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui,1.0.400.v20111107 between file:/builds/transfer/files/updates/3.8-I-builds/I20111207-2118 and file:/builds/I201112131443/org.eclipse.releng.eclipsebuilder/../src/reposource/ 			The class org/eclipse/pde/api/tools/ui/internal/properties/ApiFiltersPropertyPage.class is different. 	packed: osgi.bundle,org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui,1.0.400.v20111107 		Difference found for packed: osgi.bundle,org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui,1.0.400.v20111107 between file:/builds/transfer/files/updates/3.8-I-builds/I20111207-2118 and file:/builds/I201112131443/org.eclipse.releng.eclipsebuilder/../src/reposource/ 			The class org/eclipse/pde/api/tools/ui/internal/properties/ApiFiltersPropertyPage.class is different.

title: Must not warn for missing @since tag if extending method from Object
desc: I20080911-0800.  Extending a method from Object causes an API tooling problem saying that a @since tag is needed. This is wrong as that method belonged to the API contract since day of the concrete class.  Test Case: 1. have org.eclipse.text in source 2. add org.eclipse.jface.text.Position.toString() ==> api problem gets reported

title: Removing @noextend API restriction should not result in error
desc: I20080914-2000.  I wanted to open up a class for clients that so far has the @noextend tag. This seems to be a valid choice and hence  removed the @noextend tag. However, PDE tooling reports two erros: one that says it's an illegal change of the restriction and the other one on the manifest to increase the major version.

title: Delta CHANGED/RESTRICTIONS should be modified to be ADDED/RESTRICTIONS
desc: Since removing a restriction is fine, we should create a ADDED/RESTRICTION delta for restriction changes instead of the actual CHANGED/RESTRICTIONS.

title: API error reported when deleting non-API class (incremental)
desc: When a non-API class is deleted, an incremental build incorrectly report API errors. A full build does not report errors. For example, the following errors are reported when deleting "RemoveInternalClass" from a non-API package.  * The type a.version.internal.RemoveInternalClass has been removed from bundle.a_1.0.0 [ resource : </bundle.a/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF> range : <-1,1> category : <-1> severity : <2>] * The major version should be incremented in version 1.0.0, since API breakage occurred since version 1.0.0 [ resource : </bundle.a/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF> range : <137,142> category : <-1> severity : <2>]   The following test should be fixed when this bug is fixed:  VersionTest.testRemoveInternalClassI()

title: Adding back deleted type does not remove API error (incremental)
desc: The following steps results in an API tooling error remaining when it should not:  * Check out org.eclipse.ant.core from HEAD * Set the workspace baseline to be a 3.4 SDK * Delete the class ProjectInfo from org.eclipse.ant.core package > Errors appear for removed class and version change * Replace with latest from HEAD > Version error disappears but other error remains: "The type org.eclipse.ant.core.ProjectInfo has been removed from org.eclipse.ant.core"

title: [api tooling] API freeze task should also check for API removals
desc: Right now the API freeze check is only checking for API addition. It should also check for API removals.

title: Wrong "type of the field ... has been changed" for protected field in @noextend class
desc: I20080716-1200  In org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.launchConfigurations.JavaArgumentsTab, change the type of the protected field fPrgmArgumentsText to StyledText. API Tools report the wrong compatibility problem below.  Changing the type of this field is not an API breakage, since JavaArgumentsTab is tagged with @noextend. No client can legally have a reference to this field (since clients must not create a subclass and they must not live in a foreign API package).  The type of the field org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.launchConfigurations.JavaArgumentsTab.fPrgmArgumentsText has been changed	JavaArgumentsTab.java	org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui/ui/org/eclipse/jdt/debug/ui/launchConfigurations	Compatibility Problem	line 61

title: Invalid "constructor has been removed" warning on internal class
desc: I20080917-0100  Attempting to apply the patch from 245858 comment 1, I get the following warning: Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type The constructor org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.InternalCompletionProposal.InternalCompletionProposal() has been removed	InternalCompletionProposal.java	org.eclipse.jdt.core/codeassist/org/eclipse/jdt/internal/codeassist	line 32	Compatibility Problem  Since this class is internal, it should not warn in such case.

title: Adding @noextend and removing final modifier is not a pb if the class was a final class
desc: We should not report a changed/restrictions delta in a case where the class was a final class in the baseline and the class in the current profile is not final anymore, but tagged as @noextend. Before the class was explicitly not extensible using the final modifier. Now this is replaced with the restrictions @noextend. This doesn't change the behavior of the class and therefore should not be a compatible problem.

title: Error entries in .log
desc: 3.5 M2.  I found these two errors in the .log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 0 2008-09-22 10:37:05.218 !MESSAGE Could not locate method CompletionProposal()V  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 0 2008-09-22 10:37:05.280 !MESSAGE Could not locate method BuildContext()V  No further info got logged. Sorry, but no further info.

title: @nooverride and @noreference tags should not be allowed on private methods
desc: The tags @nooverride and @noreference should not be allowed as valid api tags on private methods since they are ignored anyways.

title: Problem should say ADDED restriction instead of CHANGED
desc: N20081018-2000.  The goal of fixing bug 247343 was to know whether a restriction got added or removed instead of just changed. The problem message however, still says CHANGED instead of ADDED.  Steps to reproduce: remove /org.eclipse.core.filebuffers/.settings/.api_filters and rebuild the project with enabled API tooling.

title: @noreference tagged method reported as "no longer API" when baseline has no API description
desc: Created attachment 115669 [details] Proposed fix  Eclipse 3.5M2  A method tagged with @noreference is reported as "no longer API" when the baseline bundle does not provide an API description.  The attached patch fixes it for me.

title: Should not allow @noreference tag on private fields
desc: To follow along bug 214989, we should also not allow the @noreference tag on private fields.

title: Should not allow @nooverride tag on final methods
desc: Currently we allow the @nooverride tag on final methods, but they cannot be overridden anyways, so the tag is meaningless.

title: Binary Compatibility options for Annotations
desc: We have too many compatibility errors/warnings for Annotations - some of them are invalid. As well, we no longer support the @noimplement tag on annotations (@see bug 232404)  The following options should be removed:  * A field (annotation not tagged as @noimplement) has been added (since an annotation cannot be extended as is not to be implemented, adding a field does not break anyone?) * A method (annotation not tagged as @noimplement) has been added (it's only breaking if a method is added without a default value, and we have a separate error for this already) * A member type ... has been added (since not to be implemented, this does not break anyone) * A class bound has been added * An interface bound has been added * The interface bounds have been added * A type parameter has been added * A class bound has been modified * An interface bound has been modified * The interface bounds have been modified * A type parameter has been removed * The type parameters have been removed * A class bound has been removed * An interface bound has been removed * The interface bounds have been removed (annotations don't seem to support generics) * The superinterface hierachy has been reduced (annotations can't extend other interfaces or types)  I think we should just be left with the following:  * A method without a default value has been added * Converted to a class, enum, interface (3) * The restrictions have been modified * A field has been removed * A method with/wo a default value has been removed (2) * A member type has been removed

title: Simplify "converted to enum..." compatibility options
desc: For each type (class, interface, enum, annotation), we have 3 compatibility options like:  * Converted to class/interface/enum/annotation  I think it would be simpler to remove each of these options, and simply report such problems as a removed type (which is configured under the "Bundle" options). This would reomve 12 error settings, reducing complexity.  When such a thing happens there is a new type that has to have a new @since tag, and the old type has been removed.

title: Remove compatibility checks for visible members in non-API supertypes
desc: We should remove the compatibility check for these errors and only report them through the leak detection where we can make the distinction between leaking super type and leaking specific methods and fields.

title: Error for API addition gets wrongly reported
desc: I20081022-0905.  1. start fresh workspace 2. define API baseline to 3.4 3. check org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring  from HEAD ==> I get two invalid API tooling errors:  1) Missing @since tag on     org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring.LanguageElementNode.internalAddChild(ChildNode)    ==> this method is there since rev. 1.1 (R3.2, 2005)  2) The minor version should be incremented in version 3.4.0.qualifier, since new     APIs have been added    ==> this is probably a follow-up of 1)  NOTE: same errors if I check out R3_4.

title: Incremental build reports incorrect errors
desc: After upgrading to I20081021-0905, and doing a build (incremental), I'm now getting a lot of errors related to @since on non-API methods (marked with @noreference). E.g.  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type Invalid @since 3.4 tag on convertCompilationUnit(int, CompilationUnitDeclaration, Map, boolean, CompilationUnit, int, IProgressMonitor); expecting @since 3.5	AST.java	org.eclipse.jdt.core/dom/org/eclipse/jdt/core/dom	line 255	@since tag problem  A full build doesn't report these errors.

title: Fup of 246114, org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.search.MethodLeakDetector#getSourceRange(IType, IDocument, IReference) should not return new Position( -1, 0)
desc: If no source range can be found, the method returns new Position(-1, 0). This will fail with an assertion error. I suggest logging the error and returning null.

title: Simplify type bound options
desc: For each type there are error settings like:  * A type parameter has been added * A type parameter has been removed * The type parameters have been removed  It feels like the 2nd/3rd options could be combined into one - there would just be multiple errors if multiple type bounds were removed.  And there are options for modifying type parameter bounds like:  * A class bound has been added * A class bound has been removed * An interface bound has been added * An interface bound has been removed * The interface bounds have been removed * A class bound has been modified * The interface bounds have been modified   Would it be simpler to have one top level group of error settings for a "Type Parameter" and have them apply to a type parameters for each type (class, enum, interface), rather than duplicating the same settings in each one?

title: Class marked with "super interfaces set reduced" without change in hierarchy
desc: Created attachment 115923 [details] ClassDeltaTests#test141()  Eclipse 3.5 M2  A class which extends a non-API type is identified as "super interfaces set reduced" when the baseline has no api description.  Attached patch illustrates this as a test case.

title: Incorrect version warning for changed re-exported bundle
desc: I20080805-1307  Resolve version problems in org.eclipse.core.runtime.  See Bundle Version Warnings in http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/I20080805-1307/apitools/apitoolsverifications/html/index.html

title: Cannot determine API breakage after incrementing major version
desc: When moving on to a new major version (e.g from 4.1 to 5.0) the api tooling no longer reports breaking API changes. This is a severe shortcoming, because although I decided to have some API breakage, I would want to keep the breakage to a minimum and thus have to be able to track the actual breakages.  One solution to that would be a preference that instructs the API tooling to report API breakages as errors/warnings dispite of the incremented major version. I then could use the filters to accept breakage by breakage and have a history of them.

title: Incremental build problem with fix for bug 229697
desc: When an internal type is modified, it doesn't get "check" on the next build by the api tooling builder. It should be checked if it is a super type of an API type.

title: CCE on code assist for @noextend
desc: Using the following jar inside a baseline and trying to modify the current version by adding a "@noextend" restriction led to : java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.SourceType at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.completion.APIToolsJavadocCompletionProposalComputer.acceptTag(APIToolsJavadocCompletionProposalComputer.java:148) at org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.ui.internal.completion.APIToolsJavadocCompletionProposalComputer.computeCompletionProposals(APIToolsJavadocCompletionProposalComputer.java:109) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.CompletionProposalComputerDescriptor.computeCompletionProposals(CompletionProposalComputerDescriptor.java:316) at title: Error for adding method to API class
desc: We have an Error/Warning severity setting for "A method (class not tagged as @noextend) has been added".  I believe that we allow adding methods to API classes no matter if there is a @noextend tag on the class or not.  When I wrote a test for this, and tried this in the IDE, no error was indicated. I think the setting should be removed (or the builder needs to be fixed to report an error).  Olivier - I think that in strict mode this may be an error in case a subclass already has a method with the same name, but in practice, we allow it. Can you confirm?

title: Invalid API problems for method that changed from private to @noreference public
desc: M20080813-0800 and I20080812-0800  - check out org.eclipse.ui.navigator from HEAD or R3_4_maintenance - remove .api_filters file  => Invalid error: The method org.eclipse.ui.navigator.NavigatorActionService.getActionProviderInstance(CommonActionProviderDescriptor) is no longer API  The method used to be private in 3.4 but the fix for bug 212389 turned it into: /**  * [..]  * @noreference This method is not intended to be referenced by clients.  */ public CommonActionProvider getActionProviderInstance([..]

title: Changing class hierachy reports "reduced" hierarchy instead of "changed"
desc: If I change DebugElement (org.eclipse.debug.core) from:       DebugElement extends PlatformObject   to:       DebugElement extends MyAdaptable      (where MyAdaptable implements IAdaptable)  Then I get the following error:  The superclass set has been reduced for type org.eclipse.debug.core.model.DebugElement  However, the superclass has actually changed.

title: adding abstract to a @noinstantiate class creates problem
desc: Currently, adding the "abstract" keyword to a non-abstract class tagged as @noinstantiate creates a compatibility problem. However, I don't think it should. In both cases the class cannot be instantiated and can still be subclassed.  There are 4 tests in the builder suite that should be modified when this bug is fixed:  ClassCompatibilityModifierTests: * testAddAbstractNoInstantiateI * testAddAbstractNoInstantiateF * testAddAbstractNoExtendNoInstantiateI * testAddAbstractNoExtendNoInstantiateF

title: No problem detected when public class becomes package visible
desc: If I change an API class from public to default/package visible, no compatibility errors appear. I would expect to get a "reduced visibility" error on the class.

title: reducing visibility of member types reported incorrectly as remove
desc: When I reduce the visibility of a member type in the following situations, the reduction is reported as a type removal. I think this is misleading to the user since the type has not actually been removed - it is just no longer visible.  * public to package * public to private * protected to package * protected to private   As well, if the enclosing type is annotated as @noextend, reducing the visiblity of a protected type results in a removed type error, when there should be no error (since the type is not visible according to API restrictions).

title: Adding @noextend or @noinstantiate to an API class does not create problem
desc: If I add restrictions to an API class that previously had no restrictions, there are no API problems reported. Doing either of these is a change in the API contract which should be flagged as a problem (@noextend or @noinstantiate).  These errors should only be detected if the baseline API component has an API description (i.e. creating the initial description should not create errors).

title: no error when adding a member type to interface
desc: There is a severity setting, defaults to ERROR, for adding a member type to an interface when it is *not* @noimplement. However, adding a member type to an interface creates no problems.  Either the preference should be removed or an error should be reported.  The following test should be updated when this bug is fixed:  InterfaceCompatibilityMemberTests.testAddMemberType*()

title: [api tooling] No missing @since tag should be reported for a protected member in a final class
desc: I20080821-1005  Bug 218976 should be extended to methods and nested classes.  E.g take org.eclipse.jdt.ui.actions.GenerateHashCodeEqualsAction 1.18 and add a protected method or nested class. This gives an invalid error: "Missing @since tag on initialize(IType)".

title: adding super interface to interface does not create errors
desc: If I have an interface that clients are allowed to implement, and I add a new super inteface to it, no problems are reported.  I would assume a problem should be reported as this adds new methods to the API that must be implemeneted, breaking the existing API contract.  Test should be updated when this bug is fixed:  * InterfaceCompatibilityMemberTests.testAddSuperInterfaceA*()  This shuold only be allowed when the interface is @noimplement

title: no problem when adding @noimplement restriction
desc: If add a @noimplement restriction to an interface that had no restrictions in the baseline (but where an API description existed), then no problem is created.  I would expect a "restrictions modified" error to appear.  Test to be updated with bug:  * InterfaceCompatibilityMemberTests.testAddNoImplement*()

title: @noreference should suppress some field compatibility problems
desc: When a field is annotated as @noreference, it should suppress some compatibility problems (as it effectively makes the field private):  * Adding 'final' keyword * Adding 'static' keyword * Remove 'static" keyworkd * Reducing the visibility  Assoicated tests to be updated with bug fix:  in FieldCompatibilityModifierTests * testAddFinalNoReference*() * testAddFinalOnStaticNoReference*() * testAddStaticNoReference*() * testRemoveStaticNoReference*() * testProtectedToPackageNoReference*() * testPublicToPrivateNoReference*()

title: Redundant problems reported when removing "final" on constant
desc: When a "static final" variable is changed to "static" two problems are reported. The problems essentially mean the same thing and could be confusing to the user. Ideally, we should just report one problem.  For example, when changing       public static final String CONSTANT = "CONSTANT"  to      public static String CONSTANT = "CONSTANT"  The problems are:  (1) The constant value CONSTANT has been removed for a.fields.modifiers.RemoveFinalOnConstant.CONSTANT (2) The 'final' keyword has been removed for a compile-time constant static field a.fields.modifiers.RemoveFinalOnConstant.CONSTANT   Keeping the second problem would be sufficient.  Associated test:  FieldCompatibilityModifierTests.testRemoveFinalOnConstant*()

title: Reducing visibility of protected body declarations in @noextend class
desc: Reducing the visibility of a protected field in a class annotated as @noextend should not create problems as the field cannot be accessed outside the bundle.  Assocaited test:  * FieldCompatibilityModifierTests.testProtectedToPrivateNoExtend*()

title: @noreference should suppress some method compatibility problems
desc: When a method is considered @noreference, some compatibility problems should not be reported (as a @noreference method is considered private):  * Reducing the visibility of a method * Adding the 'static' keyword * Removing the 'static' keyword  As well, changing a protected method to priavate in a class marked @noextend should not be an error.  The following tests need updating pending this fix:  MethodCompatibilityModifierTests * testAddStaticNoReference*() * testRemoveStaticNoReference*() * testProtectedToPackageNoReference*() * testPublicToPrivateNoReference*() * testProtectedToPrivateNoExtend*()

title: pushing a method up the class hierarchy should not be error
desc: If a method is pushed up the class hierarchy a "method removed" error should not be reported.  Associated test case:  ClassCompatibilityHierarchyTests.testPushMethodUp*()

title: implicit/explicit class bound of Object should not be considered in add/remove/change
desc: When a class bound is implicitly or explicitly java.lang.Object, we should consider it to be empty in terms of error reporting. For example, changing a type declaration from <E> to <E extends Integer> results in a error of "changed class bound" rather than addition. Similarly, changing from <E extends Integer> to <E> results in change rather than remove.  As well, adding/removing an interface bounds results in two errors: 1) adding/removing the interface 2) adding/removing a class (Object)  The tests in ClassCompatibilityTypeParameterTests need to be updated with the fix to this bug:  * testAddClassBound*() * testRemoveClassBound*() * testAddInterfaceBound*() * testRemoveOnlyInterfaceBound*()

title: Coordinate compatibility options doc with latest prefs
desc: The documentation for API tooling compatibility errors/warnings needs to be updated to reflect the latests settings.

title: Typo in org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.builder.tests.compatibility.ClassCompatibilityHierarchyTests.WORKSPACE_CLASSES_PACKAGE_A path
desc: There is a typo in the contents of the string. It should be "compatibility".

title: API breakage reported if removing extends of internal class
desc: I20080827-0935  Attempting to fix a problem where a public class extends an internal class (i.e. by removing the extends), API Tools now reports an API breakage saying that the superclass has changed.  Shouldn't it allow this "breakage" since it it fixing an invalid extends usage?

title: Removed type not detected in incremental build
desc: If I remove an API type, or reduce the visibility of an API type in a bundle, the error is not detected until a full build is performed.  The following tests need to be updated when this bug is fixed:  BundleCompatibilityTests: * testPublicToPackageI() * testRemovePublicClassI()

title: Wrong problem removed using @noreference tag on inner constructors
desc: Created attachment 111598 [details] test project  using N20080901-2000  Steps:  1. using the test project build testCPL11 and notice two api problems for leaking params on the two constructors  2. add a noreferece tag where the TODO say to   3. save (incremental build)  Expected the problem is removed from the constructor the tag appears on  Happens the problem is removed from the other constructor???

title: Annotation/Enun should not support 'restrictions have been modified' option
desc: There is a left over error/warning severity setting for Annotations: "restrictions have been modified". I believe we no longer support any restrictions on annotations, and this should be removed.

title: no error reported when enum super interface removed
desc: An error should be reported when an enum's super interface set is reduced.  The following test case should be updated when this bug is addressed:  EnumCompatibilityTests * testRemoveSuperInterface*()

title: no error for malformed tag of form abc1.0
desc: If I have a @since tag that ends with the a number, but is not its own segment, there is no error. For example:  @since abc1.0  I think this should be an error, expecting "abc 1.0" or just "1.0".  The following test should be updated with this bug:  MalformedSinceTagTests * testMalformedTag*()

title: The preference for type parameter has been modified should be removed
desc: This preference is not used anymore. A type parameter can only be added or removed.

title: removing type argument from field should be an error
desc: Removing a type parameter from a field should be a compatibility error:  like "List<String>" becomes "List"  The following tests should be updated with this bug fix:  * FieldCompatibilityModifierTests.testRemoveTypeParameters*()

title: Delta should be reported for changed restrictions on a field or a method
desc: Since a field can be tagged as @noreference and a method can be tagged as @noreference or @noextend, we should check if this is not breaking existing clients.

title: Tons of API tooling errors after importing binaries
desc: I20080909-1121.  I upgraded my workspace as usual to the latest I-build by importing all required plug-ins. Now, besides the floading of errors due to bug 246804 I also get tons of these:  The super interfaces set has been reduced for type org.eclipse.ui.ide.FileStoreEditorInputFactory  plus one of these for each manifest.mf: The major version should be incremented in version 3.5.0.qualifier, since API breakage occurred since version 3.4.0.I20080606-1300  We already had a similar issue which got marked as fixed, see bug 243136. Same symptoms: cleaning, restarting, deleting metadata does not help. BUT: this time starting with an older build (N20080904-2000) does not make the problem go away.   This is a blocker for using API tooling with latest I-build.

title: Document fall-through cases in switch statements
desc: With the new compiler warning, we should document and enable all the fall-through cases.

title: Many errors due to wrong warning about changed restrictions
desc: N20080910-2000.  After 3.4 PDE API tooling started to warn if there's a @noextend on a final class (very good). Now, of course we've fixed that BUT HEY: now PDE API tooling reports an error saying that we changed the restriction:     The restrictions have been changed for type ...  This is just wrong.  Marking as 'major' because I now no longer see in my Package Explorer whether I have a real error on the project or not.

title: Must not warn for missing @since tag if extending method from Object
desc: I20080911-0800.  Extending a method from Object causes an API tooling problem saying that a @since tag is needed. This is wrong as that method belonged to the API contract since day of the concrete class.  Test Case: 1. have org.eclipse.text in source 2. add org.eclipse.jface.text.Position.toString() ==> api problem gets reported

title: Removing @noextend API restriction should not result in error
desc: I20080914-2000.  I wanted to open up a class for clients that so far has the @noextend tag. This seems to be a valid choice and hence  removed the @noextend tag. However, PDE tooling reports two erros: one that says it's an illegal change of the restriction and the other one on the manifest to increase the major version.

title: Delta CHANGED/RESTRICTIONS should be modified to be ADDED/RESTRICTIONS
desc: Since removing a restriction is fine, we should create a ADDED/RESTRICTION delta for restriction changes instead of the actual CHANGED/RESTRICTIONS.

title: API error reported when deleting non-API class (incremental)
desc: When a non-API class is deleted, an incremental build incorrectly report API errors. A full build does not report errors. For example, the following errors are reported when deleting "RemoveInternalClass" from a non-API package.  * The type a.version.internal.RemoveInternalClass has been removed from bundle.a_1.0.0 [ resource : </bundle.a/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF> range : <-1,1> category : <-1> severity : <2>] * The major version should be incremented in version 1.0.0, since API breakage occurred since version 1.0.0 [ resource : </bundle.a/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF> range : <137,142> category : <-1> severity : <2>]   The following test should be fixed when this bug is fixed:  VersionTest.testRemoveInternalClassI()

title: Adding back deleted type does not remove API error (incremental)
desc: The following steps results in an API tooling error remaining when it should not:  * Check out org.eclipse.ant.core from HEAD * Set the workspace baseline to be a 3.4 SDK * Delete the class ProjectInfo from org.eclipse.ant.core package > Errors appear for removed class and version change * Replace with latest from HEAD > Version error disappears but other error remains: "The type org.eclipse.ant.core.ProjectInfo has been removed from org.eclipse.ant.core"

title: Invalid "constructor has been removed" warning on internal class
desc: I20080917-0100  Attempting to apply the patch from 245858 comment 1, I get the following warning: Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type The constructor org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.InternalCompletionProposal.InternalCompletionProposal() has been removed	InternalCompletionProposal.java	org.eclipse.jdt.core/codeassist/org/eclipse/jdt/internal/codeassist	line 32	Compatibility Problem  Since this class is internal, it should not warn in such case.

title: Adding @noextend and removing final modifier is not a pb if the class was a final class
desc: We should not report a changed/restrictions delta in a case where the class was a final class in the baseline and the class in the current profile is not final anymore, but tagged as @noextend. Before the class was explicitly not extensible using the final modifier. Now this is replaced with the restrictions @noextend. This doesn't change the behavior of the class and therefore should not be a compatible problem.

title: Error entries in .log
desc: 3.5 M2.  I found these two errors in the .log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 0 2008-09-22 10:37:05.218 !MESSAGE Could not locate method CompletionProposal()V  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.api.tools 4 0 2008-09-22 10:37:05.280 !MESSAGE Could not locate method BuildContext()V  No further info got logged. Sorry, but no further info.

title: Problem should say ADDED restriction instead of CHANGED
desc: N20081018-2000.  The goal of fixing bug 247343 was to know whether a restriction got added or removed instead of just changed. The problem message however, still says CHANGED instead of ADDED.  Steps to reproduce: remove /org.eclipse.core.filebuffers/.settings/.api_filters and rebuild the project with enabled API tooling.

title: @noreference tagged method reported as "no longer API" when baseline has no API description
desc: Created attachment 115669 [details] Proposed fix  Eclipse 3.5M2  A method tagged with @noreference is reported as "no longer API" when the baseline bundle does not provide an API description.  The attached patch fixes it for me.

title: Remove compatibility checks for visible members in non-API supertypes
desc: We should remove the compatibility check for these errors and only report them through the leak detection where we can make the distinction between leaking super type and leaking specific methods and fields.

title: Error for API addition gets wrongly reported
desc: I20081022-0905.  1. start fresh workspace 2. define API baseline to 3.4 3. check org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring  from HEAD ==> I get two invalid API tooling errors:  1) Missing @since tag on     org.eclipse.ltk.ui.refactoring.LanguageElementNode.internalAddChild(ChildNode)    ==> this method is there since rev. 1.1 (R3.2, 2005)  2) The minor version should be incremented in version 3.4.0.qualifier, since new     APIs have been added    ==> this is probably a follow-up of 1)  NOTE: same errors if I check out R3_4.

title: Incremental build reports incorrect errors
desc: After upgrading to I20081021-0905, and doing a build (incremental), I'm now getting a lot of errors related to @since on non-API methods (marked with @noreference). E.g.  Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type Invalid @since 3.4 tag on convertCompilationUnit(int, CompilationUnitDeclaration, Map, boolean, CompilationUnit, int, IProgressMonitor); expecting @since 3.5	AST.java	org.eclipse.jdt.core/dom/org/eclipse/jdt/core/dom	line 255	@since tag problem  A full build doesn't report these errors.

title: Fup of 246114, org.eclipse.pde.api.tools.internal.search.MethodLeakDetector#getSourceRange(IType, IDocument, IReference) should not return new Position( -1, 0)
desc: If no source range can be found, the method returns new Position(-1, 0). This will fail with an assertion error. I suggest logging the error and returning null.

title: Class marked with "super interfaces set reduced" without change in hierarchy
desc: Created attachment 115923 [details] ClassDeltaTests#test141()  Eclipse 3.5 M2  A class which extends a non-API type is identified as "super interfaces set reduced" when the baseline has no api description.  Attached patch illustrates this as a test case.

title: Cannot determine API breakage after incrementing major version
desc: When moving on to a new major version (e.g from 4.1 to 5.0) the api tooling no longer reports breaking API changes. This is a severe shortcoming, because although I decided to have some API breakage, I would want to keep the breakage to a minimum and thus have to be able to track the actual breakages.  One solution to that would be a preference that instructs the API tooling to report API breakages as errors/warnings dispite of the incremented major version. I then could use the filters to accept breakage by breakage and have a history of them.
